PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Harold Young) took the chair at 10.30 a.m., and read prayers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Foreman Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-
(a) expresses its grave concern at the Industries Assistance Commission's recommendations to lower the level of protection for the motor vehicle industry;
(b) condemns the IAC for its total disregard for the welfare of car industry workers in Australia; and
(c) calls upon the Government to abolish the Industries Assistance Commission.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate as a States House-
1. Congratulates the members of the South Australian Legislative Council Select Committee inquiring into uranium who made dissenting reports to the South Australian Parliament yesterday.
2. Is in full agreement with the dissenting report of Dr John Cornwall, Labor MLC and Mr Norm Foster, Labor MLC, who state they are opposed to uranium mining because-
(a) the development of the safe and safe-guarded nuclear program is somewhere between infancy and adolescence;
(b) horrendous physical, financial and moral questions remain to be resolved; and
(c) no adequate solutions for the indefinite disposal of high level waste are yet available.
3. Supports the dissenting report of Mr L. Milne, Australian Democrat MLC, which opposes uranium mining in South Australia because of the dangers in the later stages of the nuclear fuel cycle.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Prime Minister aware that both the Prime Minister and the Deputy Prime Minister committed the Federal Government to supporting the national soil conservation program at the last election only to have the razor gang announce that the Federal Government was pulling out of all soil conservation programs? Has the Minister had personal representations on this matter from the New South Wales Minister for Agriculture and Fisheries? Will the Minister confirm that New South Wales spends over half the amount of money spent annually in Australia on soil conservation and provides for this $20m plus expenditure out of its own revenue? Will the Minister explain how the Federal Government expects State governments to commit themselves to long term soil conservation programs when New South Wales is told that $1m made available for the national program is buried within an overall general allocation which has been reduced by over $300m in real terms?

—What has happened over the whole course of Federation has been the broad acceptance that both sovereignty and responsibility for soil conservation lie with the States. All the States have responded to that responsibility by developing very substantial soil conservation programs. The New South Wales Department of Agriculture developed particular skills, and I acknowledge that. The Commonwealth had indicated that it would make some national contribution to soil conservation programs. It had decided on an amount of $3m. It decided that its best way of contributing would be not to abandon that undertaking but to take that amount of money and incorporate it in the revenue distribution to the States so that there would be a continuous dissemination of that money to the States as an addition to their programs. So, in fact, the Commonwealth is adding, as it did, I think some $69m by way of absorption to the States. As I have said, the States have the primary responsibility and must always continue to do so. As to the question of the availability of moneys for the States, I remind the honourable senator that of all public finance spent in Australia 52 per cent-that is, the significant majority of it-is spent by States and local government and 48 per cent is spent by the Commonwealth, the minority spender of public finance. Therefore, the more abundant field of public finance available for this and other matters lies with the States.

—Is the Minister for Finance aware that artists, including those artists who are part time lecturers in tertiary institutions in photography, print-making and drawing, pay sales tax on raw materials or equipment at the rate of 30 per cent? In view of the difficulty that artists have in establishing themselves in Australia and the fact that they pay luxury tax on their final product, will the Government review the granting of a concession on the purchase of raw materials in similiar fashion to that applied to aids to manufacture in the manufacturing sector?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is a provision in the sales tax law that exempts works of art produced in Australia and works of art produced overseas by Australian artists. Materials and equipment used by an artist who produces works of art for sale are exempt from sales tax at the time of the purchase of raw materials and aids to manufacture. However, materials and equipment used by an artist who does not produce works of art for sale are taxable at the time of purchase. This is the matter to which Senator Watson has addressed himself. The Treasurer advises that in these circumstances materials and equipment used by artists are generally taxable at 17 1/2 per cent, although certain types of pens are taxable at 30 per cent. Artists' canvas is exempt from tax. The question has also indicated that photographic equipment and materials may be in issue. These goods are generally taxable at 30 per cent, although chemicals are taxable at 17 1/2 per cent. The matters that have been canvassed by Senator Watson in his question will be referred to the Treasurer for consideration as to whether he sees any change as being appropriate. As soon as I have a response from him I will see that Senator Watson is advised.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: COMMITTEE INQUIRING INTO ASSISTANCE FOR THE DISABLED

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security and refers to the committee set up by the Minister to look into the assistance given to disabled people in this country, a committee chaired by Mr Murray Sainsbury, a member of another place. I ask the Minister: Will the report and the findings of this committee be made available to the Parliament and the public? Will the report and the findings of the committee be made available to members of organisations concerned with the disabled so that they may comment on it, or is the report to remain a secret document until it falls off the back of a truck?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The status of the document referred to by Senator Grimes in his question is the same as the status of any document of advice given to me on matters of policy and prepared by my Department. Those documents are not normally published. I do not think they are normally regarded as secret in any sinister sense. They are simply documents of advice. I have said to the Australian Council of Rehabilitation of Disabled, which is the principal body representing the disabled, that I do not propose to make any changes to the programs about which it is concerned without having prior discussion with it. In other words, any action which might be taken with respect to any recommendations put forward by that group would first be subject to discussion with ACROD as the peak representative body of organisations for the disabled and, of course, in any event would have to be subject to government consideration in the normal way. As far as Senator Grimes's reference to documents falling off the back of a truck is concerned, I am quite aware that there is a tendency in some areas for documents to be leaked. I have no intention of changing my practices to take into account the behaviour of people which I think is out of line and has nothing to do with good, orderly and proper administration.

ANSWER.PARA: I draw the attention of the Senate to the fact that, even under freedom of information legislation which might be proposed by either side of the Parliament, there is not an assumption that all documents of advice would be open to public purview. It is not a matter of secrecy; it is a matter of getting advice and considering it. I think what is of concern to the public is that information which is relevant to decisions should be available to the public and to the people who are affected. I would always be prepared to make available any information which was requested and which was relevant to decisions.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I ask the Minister to elaborate on that part of the answer when he said that he did not think that there was anything sinister or secret about the document. If he does wish to have an informed debate and to provide information to the public-particularly to the disabled themselves-why not make available this document, which surely contains nothing that we should not know about, that we should not discuss, if we are to have sensible policy development in this country?

—Again I direct the honourable senator's attention to his party's attitude to freedom of information legislation, which admits that one is not seeking to make available all documents which are part of government process and that the advice which is given to a Minister by his department is not a matter to be published.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: STATE BANK OF NEW SOUTH WALES: PROPOSED CANBERRA BRANCH

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Finance to a report in the Sydney Morning Herald of Saturday, 31 October 1981, that the State Bank of New South Wales is seeking to establish a branch in Canberra. The stated policy of the Bank is indicated in that newspaper under the heading 'Invest here, bank here' and in a paragraph which said:

QUESTION.PARA: Under an agreement dating back to 1933 half of the profits that the CSB makes in NSW go to the local bank.

In view of that, I ask: Will the Minister ensure that a condition of State Bank entry into the Australian Capital Territory reciprocates the arrangements in New South Wales whereby the Commonwealth Savings Bank under a 1933 agreement pays half the profits it makes in New South Wales to the State Bank, so that the profits remain in the Australian Capital Territory for the benefit of this community?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I am aware of the report referred to by the honourable senator. The comparison drawn with the 1933 agreement between the Commonwealth Savings Bank and the New South Wales Government is not one which could apply in this case. In 1933 the Commonwealth Savings Bank took over, by agreement, the business of an existing savings bank owned by the New South Wales Government. It was considered that it would be in the national interest to merge the interests of the States in savings bank business into one national institution. The profit-sharing arrangement with New South Wales reflected the fact that the Commonwealth Bank acquired the State's savings bank business and its assets as a going concern. Of course, those circumstances do not apply in this case. I have noted the interest of Senator Reid in the matter. I will refer it to the Treasurer and seek a response from him in due course after consideration is given to the proposal that was the subject of the public comment mentioned.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Finance a question concerning promised tax cuts or increases in family allowances. I ask the Minister whether she is aware that on 15 October 1980, three days before the last election, the Prime Minister promised:

QUESTION.PARA: If there are further significant increases (in oil prices), then the first priority of the Government will be to return that to the Australian family through the taxation mechanism or through family allowances.
I ask the Minister whether she is further aware of the Prime Minister's undertaking as late as last Saturday:
. . . with the deficit virtually eliminated in this year's Budget, we will obviously have an enhanced potential for tax cuts.
Does the Minister recall the answer which the Leader of the Government in the Senate gave to me last Tuesday, in which Senator Carrick stated:
The Government has made it clear that it will use moneys from oil revenues to increase benefits to families and, indeed, . . . has done so.
Has the Minister noted the Treasurer's remark made yesterday, in which he said:

. . . the comments the Prime Minister made before the last election were related to an increase due to occur in January this year, and they were not made as to the generality of future (oil) levy increases.

In view of the repeated insistence of the Prime Minister that there will be tax cuts or increases in family allowances, and in view of the consistent views of the Treasurer and Senator Carrick that no such relief is to be necessarily expected in the near future, I ask the Minister for Finance whether she has another view to put to the Senate. I further ask whether she supports the Prime Minister's view on this question or the views of the other two Ministers. Finally, if she does not want to put a personal view to the Senate, can she say, as a member of Cabinet, whether the Cabinet has discussed the matter and what is its view?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Because the matter concerns statements of the Prime Minister, the question concerns me.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. Surely it is the right of a senator in this place to ask a question of any Minister whom he or she pleases? I would have thought it was the prerogative of a senator to choose the Minister whom he or she wishes to answer a question. If Senator Carrick wants to put a view relating to my question, I will be delighted to hear it. But I have already had his view and my question this morning is specifically directed to the Minister for Finance who, I would have thought, would be in a unique position to settle this question once and for all.
—Mr President, may I speak to the point of order?
—Yes.

—It is common practice, where a question is judged by a Minister as being more appropriate to be within that Minister's responsibility, for that Minister to accept the responsibility. I do represent the Prime Minister. The matter concerns the Prime Minister and I ask that you rule accordingly.

—In response to Senator Chipp's point of order, it is the right and responsibility of Ministers in this chamber to decide who will answer questions and in whose area of responsibility a particular question lies. The Leader of the Government in the Senate has risen. I call him to respond.

—The first thing I want to do is to correct the selective quotation made by Senator Chipp both today and yesterday. It is highly important that this be done. I quote from the Hansard which contains the quotation of the alleged promise made by the Prime Minister. On Tuesday Senator Chipp quoted as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: If there are further significant increases (in oil prices) then the first priority of the Government will be to return that to the Australian family through the taxation mechanism or through family allowances.
He repeated that today. In fact, I quote from the transcript of 15 October. It stated:
. . . if there are significant increases in the price of oil and therefore in the revenue from the levy . . .

There is a slight difference in the meaning! There is a total difference in the meaning. In other words, if as a result of oil prices there is a net increase in the levy, then these things will flow. So the first situation is that the premises that Senator Chipp raised were, of course, wrong. The claim made by the Australian Labor Party that there would be huge increases in oil prices was utterly wrong. Do not honourable senators remember Mr Keating talking about the price of oil rising to 40c with huge oil prices? He has been wrong on everything he has said. I now go on to read--

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order. Mr President, without making any reflection at all on your generous ruling on behalf of the Government, I point out that I simply asked Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle for a definitive view of the Cabinet on whether there will be tax cuts or increases in family allowances. I am not the slightest bit interested in what Mr Keating or anybody else has said about the oil levy. I ask you now to hold the Minister at least to relevance.

—Senator Chipp, it has always been the right and responsibility of Ministers in this chamber, irrespective of the government they represent, to answer questions as they see fit. The one qualification the Chair has always tried to put on both questions and answers is that they are kept as short as possible so that more questions can be asked and more answers obtained during the question period. I again call the Leader of the Government.
—Mr President, I go on to quote what the Prime Minister said on 15 October:

ANSWER.PARA: I need to add a rider to that, because it is a hypothetical question at the moment. The prices that have been made in the OPEC countries are ones that at this point lead to an increase in the price of petrol of less than 1c a litre, so the additional revenue coming from that is pretty minimal.
That is of absolute importance, but also in the Budget Speech of this year the Treasurer, in the section headed 'Family Allowances', said:

Prior to the last election the Government stated that any significant increase in oil revenue in 1980-81 over the Budget estimate would be returned to Australian families. In the event, receipts from this source last year were actually below the Budget estimate, as I have already indicated.
Nevertheless, we have reviewed the levels of family allowances and decided to increase the rates of assistance for third and subsequent children by 50 per cent, with effect from 1 January 1982.

I understand that in fact the full year cost of that assistance is about $120m. I understand that there was also partial tax indexation. So although there was no increase in revenue at all-and that was inherent in the promise-the Government has proceeded with family allowances and tax matters well within the lines of its promise.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Why did the Minister choose to answer the question instead of allowing Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle to answer it?

—I did so because the question related to what the Prime Minister said and what the Prime Minister promised, and I am the Minister in this chamber responsible for prime ministerial matters. A similar practice applies in both the chambers.

—My question is to the Minister for Social Security. In the light of the increasing evidence of wealthy people artificially manipulating their incomes in order to qualify for age pensions and fringe benefits and thereby making it more difficult for the Government to provide effectively for those who are entirely dependent on their pensions, has the Government given consideration to reverting to the system of including assets as well as income in the determination of entitlement to an age pension?

—The Government has not given consideration to the point raised by the honourable senator. I have already indicated that the Government proposes to strengthen the existing provisions of the social security legislation which relate to deprivation of income. The purpose of section 47 of the Social Services Act is, of course, to ensure that people do not get pension entitlements to which they would not be entitled if they got income which was available to them. As far as any changes beyond those announced are concerned, the social security system is, of course, under continous review and most of these areas are reviewed annually in the Budget context. But as the Prime Minister has recently indicated, there is no proposal before the Government for the reintroduction of an assets test. I am of the view that it is certainly desirable that there should be an effective income test if we are to be able to ensure that we can look after the aged people of Australia in an appropriate way. At the moment a part pension is payable to single pensioners who have incomes of something over $150 a week. For a married couple a part pension ceases to be payable only when non-pension income reaches $266 a week. That is a fair spread of income over which the Government does provide some supplementary assistance and I think it is an indication of the breadth of the pension system in Australia. When we have a situation in which people with very large incomes can, in quite artificial ways, dispose of that income and yet retain the benefit of it, the matter needs very careful examination. If the demands of the people of Australia, including members on this side of the Parliament and the other side of the Parliament, for us to do a better job with respect to more needy Australians are to be met, I believe we have to place some limitation on the amounts of money which go to Australians who are readily able to provide for themselves.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Finance. Did the annual report of the Commissioner of Taxation released on 29 October show that at the end of the last financial year $973m, accumulated in tax avoidance schemes and challenged by the Department, remained uncollected? Is this $200m more than the avoidance figure reported a year earlier and $550m higher than the avoidance figure of two years ago? Does the $973m accumulated in 1980-81 remain uncollected because of a shortage of personnel due to staff ceilings, or is there some other reason relating to government legislation why that figure is so rapidly accumulating?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I do not have the precise figures with me but I am aware of the figure of around $1,000m as being quoted by the Commissioner of Taxation this year. The problem of tax avoidance schemes has been discussed on a number of occasions. There are a number of difficulties in collecting as much tax as we would regard people as being legally required to pay. It was discussed in one of the Senate Estimates committees, or in one of the discussions held around the time of the Budget preparation, that staff figures were important in being able to use the resources of the Department as widely as possible in minimising tax avoidance. I will seek from the Treasurer information as to whether he believes the whole of the problem is related to staff shortages or whether, as I think would be the case, he would share a general view that a number of reasons exist for the inability to collect the appropriate tax from all the people who ought to be paying tax in this country. I will seek from the Treasurer the up to date position on his staff ceiling problems, whether he has been able to divert resources into that section to meet what he believes are the requirements of the Commissioner and whether he has been able to settle any additional staff which I know the Commissioner is seeking for the Australian Taxation Office at this time. I will seek that information and get as early a reply as possible.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport. Is the Minister aware of the consequences of the decision of his Government and Trans Australia Airlines to discontinue the uneconomic air service to Birdsville and to reduce other equally important services to outback areas? Does the Minister not realise that this service provides the people of Birdsville with their perishable goods and mail and brings children who are not able to attend local schools-because there are not any-home for their school holidays? Can the Minister give any assurances on behalf of this Government that it will provide a subsidy arrangement to maintain these services, as it does for services to Tasmania and for urban bus and rail services Australia-wide?

—It is, of course, well known that Trans Australia Airlines has continued to operate F27 services, in western Queensland in particular, despite heavy losses over recent years. However, in recent times those losses have grown to the stage where if TAA is to act as a commercial enterprise it has no option but to take further action to reduce those losses. As a first step TAA intends to introduce new schedules to operate from 1 December. Those schedules no longer include services to a number of very low traffic ports, including Birdsville. I understand that State and Commonwealth officials and TAA are actively exploring ways and means of ensuring that alternative air services are being maintained in that area. The Minister undertakes to monitor that situation very closely and to keep in touch with the situation to ensure that, where humanly possible, acceptable alternative services are made available to people in those areas, particularly with reference to the points which Senator Bjelke-Petersen raised.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer, follows the question asked by the Leader of the Opposition, Senator Button. In view of the Treasurer's statement that the Federal Government is taking effective measures to crack down on tax avoidance, will the Minister tell the Senate how this can be achieved with the Government's job cutting policy for the Public Service? Was the Commissioner of Taxation correct when he said that these job cutting policies are seriously affecting the ability of the Taxation Office to detect and to control tax evasion? Is the Minister aware of the dissatisfaction in the community where wage and salary earners are being taxed directly at source while other people seem to be able to evade or avoid paying taxes? With the continual cutting of jobs in the Public Service, how is the Government achieving its proposed aim of making taxation equitable in the community, or is the Treasurer's statement just a gimmick to keep wage and salary earners happy in the belief that something is being done?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I have nothing to add to what I said earlier with regard to the staffing position in the Taxation Office and the fact that I would seek an up to date response from the Treasurer. As to the other part of the question with regard to wage and salary earners feeling that they are bearing an undue burden of the personal income tax that is collected, I am aware that there is great resentment in the community that people are evading tax that properly should be paid by them. But perhaps we ought to extend just one step further what was said by Senator Elstob and say that equally there is resentment in the community at the use of the cash economy to avoid or evade tax. I think it is fair to say that a number of people who may be paying pay-as-you-earn tax as wage and salary earners are using the cash economy to evade tax on other income which they receive. There is equal resentment that that total income is not subjected to the level of personal income tax that is appropriate for the total income received.

ANSWER.PARA: However, as I said, I will seek from the Treasurer the up to date position of the staffing of the Taxation Office. I do not think anyone ought to infer that there is any gimmick about the efforts of the Government, the present Treasurer and the Commissioner of Taxation to collect the appropriate level of tax from people at certain levels of income. If all members of the community give support to the efforts that are being made I feel sure that more equity will result from the strenuous efforts that have been made by this Government over recent years. It certainly is a case of inequity if some people are avoiding their responsibilities. Every effort ought to be made to see that this is minimised.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question also is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. In view of the pressures in financing all social security benefits resulting particularly from continuing world-wide inflation, will the Treasurer have an investigation carried out with a view to developing a national superannuation scheme which may be principally administered by insurance and other financial organisations, with a view to ensuring adequate and equitable retirement benefits at manageable public cost?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — There has been an interest in this matter for a number of years. Some years ago, when I was Minister for Social Security, the report of the Hancock National Superannuation Committee of Inquiry was tabled and discussed. Subsequently it was said that the Government did not intend to proceed with the plan outlined in that report. The Treasurer subsequently investigated occupational superannuation matters, and I think he has made statements that there is no imminent introduction by the Government of a national superannuation plan. I am aware that in recent weeks the life assurance houses have put forward some proposals. Again I think it ought to be understood that a national superannuation scheme with benefits additional to those which are paid under present age pension schemes would require additional contributions, either by way of additional personal tax, if it is to be a non-contributory scheme, or by way of an identified contribution, which would have the same effect as additional personal income tax. As I understand it, the scheme that was proposed recently by the life houses acknowledged that over $1,000m extra revenue would be required to introduce that sort of scheme. So whilst we wish to see as generous retirement benefits as possible, that cannot be achieved without the contribution of the Australian people to ensure that more is done than we are presently able to do.

ANSWER.PARA: If there were continuing interest in the introduction of a national superannuation scheme, it would require a great deal of investigation and a great deal of discussion before such a plan could be introduced. It is rather facile to suggest that the introduction of a scheme will of itself result in greater benefits. It is the expenditure and the commitment of the Australian people to their retirement schemes that will ultimately result in their having a higher or more universal level of age pension or retirement benefits. If the honourable senator who raised the matter has a particular proposal he wishes to refer either to my colleague Senator Chaney or to the Treasurer, I will see that that matter is transferred.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: SOCIAL SECURITY PAYMENTS: COST OF LIVING ADJUSTMENTS

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Social Security. Is it true that the consumer price index calculated by the Australian Bureau of Statistics for pension increases is collated only in the June and December quarters of each year? Is it true that in the CPI calculations by the Australian Bureau of Statistics the collation of fuel statistics is done at the exact middle of the quarter; that is, for the December quarter, at 15 November? Noting that home electricity costs in Victoria are to be raised by 20 per cent on 17 November, I ask: Are any adjustments to the December quarter intended to be made to account for that increase? Is it true that, if no adjustments are made in the December quarter, the increased electricity costs in Victoria will not be counted until the June 1982 quarter and will not be compensated for in pension increases until 18 weeks after the end of the June quarter, that is, 4 November 1982, or almost one year after electricity costs are increased? Finally, is the Minister aware that the State Electricity Commission of Victoria has reduced its projections of increased consumption on the basis that next winter many aged Victorians will not be using electrical heating appliances?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable senator asked a number of detailed questions about the timing of the calculations of adjustments to the cost of living index in Australia, which calculations, of course, affect the adjustments which are made to pensions and benefits. I am not able to give him confirmation of the precise dates of the month which are the relevant cut-off points. I have seen those dates and I assume he is quoting them correctly, but I have no independent recollection of them; so I will need to check that point.

ANSWER.PARA: The heart of the honourable senator's question involves the fact that one can get an adjustment shortly after a cut-off date which will not be picked up until the next cut-off date when changes to the cost of living are being taken into account, and that therefore there can be lags in the pension adjustments which are required to cover those increased costs. I can only say that of course it is possible for the timing of increases in costs to be either benign or otherwise with respect to these calculations. I will examine the example which the honourable senator has raised and see whether the point which he has made is correct.

I point out that the adjustments which are made to pensions to take into account increases in the cost of living are, of necessity, imperfect and some of the imperfections will not favour pensioners but others will in fact favour them. Currently, for example, the cost of living index is being affected by the changes to the health scheme. Those changes add something like 0.75 of a per cent to the cost of living index. It is a fact, of course, that for the great bulk of pensioners and beneficiaries those changes in costs are irrelevant. In other words, there is a provision within the social security system, through the pensioner health benefits card, which ensures that pensioners are insulated from that part of the rise in the cost of living. That is a fortuitous gain for pensioners. It means that they get some part of the next increase to cover an increase in the cost of living to which they are not subject, in the main. So there are those sorts of compensating and offsetting adjustments. Indeed, in respect of the adjustments made in 1981 and 1982, automatically under the legislation introduced by this Government, in November and May there will be rises which cover costs not required to be met by the bulk of pensioners.

I will examine the point raised by the honourable senator. It has certainly been drawn to my attention in the past by my Department. I accept that any system which we have to adjust pensions will have some imperfections, because it is impossible to dictate the date on which all changes in costs of living will occur. But I think that the basic protection which is given to pensioners in this country by the twice-yearly indexation of pensions is as sound a system as has been found to date to ensure that those members of the community who most need to be protected do get protection from the ravages of inflation.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is also directed to the Minister for Social Security, is in the same area as the previous question. It concerns the automatic increases in the age pension which, twice each year, catch up fully with rises in the cost of living index and, more precisely, two aspects of this year's Budget-the matter to which the Minister has just referred, namely the new health care arrangements, and the new indirect taxes, including the new levels of sales tax. Is it true that the consumer price index will be increased by three-quarters of a per cent for both these items, and that therefore the age pension increase, in respect of these items alone, will automatically be $1.05 a week? Is it also true that, despite this $1.05 a week rise, it is objectively calculated that for pensioners there will be an increase of less than 50c a week in costs? Accordingly, can the Minister confirm that age pensioners as a group will in no way be disadvantaged by the decisions of this year's Budget?

—The facts in the broad indicated by the honourable senator are, of course, correct. Those pensioners and beneficiaries who are in receipt of indexed benefits will see changes to their pensions and benefits in accordance with changes to the cost of living which are caused by the changes to the health care arrangements and by the indirect taxes. In that sense, therefore, there is protection, for that part of the community which is reliant upon indexed pensions and benefits, from the changes which have been mentioned by the honourable senator. I think that the precise figures mentioned by the honourable senator are pretty close to correct. There is an increase of somewhere around $1 a week involved. I will need to check the precise figures and I will give the honourable senator a supplementary reply.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. When it is alleged that an overpayment of a social security benefit has occurred, does the Department of Social Security take no recovery action while an appeal to the Social Security Appeals Tribunal is pending? If an appeal is subsequently forwarded to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, does the Department of Social Security similarly take no recovery action until that Tribunal makes a decision on the matter? If there is a difference in departmental action in relation to the two levels of appeal, what is the reason for that difference?
—As far as I know recovery action is postponed with respect to appeals in each case, but I will verify that point. If there is a difference I will advise the honourable senator.

—The Minister representing the Minister for Education may be familiar with what is now known in Western Australia as the O'Brien case involving the University of Western Australia, which pursued one of its senior lecturers in the courts for what are now acknowledged to have been very trivial matters. Is the Minister aware that the magistrate in the particular case, Clifford Young, said that the case should never have come to the courts? Because of the large Federal commitment to the University of Western Australia I ask the Minister whether he will ascertain the costs to the University of Western Australia of the court case, the instructing lawyers' fees and how many lawyers there were, the fees of the Q.C.'s involved and the cost of the University staff in preparing such litigation. Will the Minister find out whether the University Senate approved this litigation and at the same time, perhaps, inquire as to how many prosecutions for offensive language the University has undertaken? If the answer to this question is no, will the Minister ask the University whether there is any connection between the fact that Mr O'Brien is the only person to have been prosecuted by the University of Western Australia for using offensive language and the fact that he has criticised the university administration from time to time? Does the Minister consider that to prosecute a single critic of the university for offensive language has potentially dangerous implications for the principle of free speech? Can the Minister say whether the university issues any guidelines as to what language and other behaviour may or may not be tolerated by the university?
—Order! I ask the honourable senator to complete his question.
—I think that there is enough there for the Minister to answer.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I understand it, Senator Martyr is referring to a case brought to a magistrate's court concerning a Patrick O'Brien.
—His old mate Paddy O'Brien.

—I noted the interjections of the Opposition which, of course, were entirely contrary to what the magistrate said. It is very important that this should be said. As I understand it, the magistrate was critical of the university decision to bring the matter before a court of law. One would not expect an academy of higher learning to put on display its internecine conflicts and the immature behaviour of its members. In other words, it was said that this was a matter for the University of Western Australia, it having the sole responsibility for its internal affairs. The magistrate pointed out that in his view this was not a proper matter to be brought into public display. This appears to be a matter arising out of conflicts of viewpoints within the university. I do not canvass that.

ANSWER.PARA: I was asked a series of questions regarding costs. The magistrate concerned has apparently made it quite clear that in his view the case ought never to have proceeded to law or to have involved costs. I will ask the Minister for Education whether he can pursue this matter and the other relevant matters in Senator Martyr's question.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. In view of the Prime Minister's apparent willingness to permit the private funding of staff employed by members of Parliament-in spite of a Liberal Party rule to the contrary-can the Prime Minister give the Parliament an assurance that no person currently employed in these circumstances will end up doing 13 years in Long Bay gaol for fraud like Mr Fraser's former privately funded research assistant, Keith Compton Gale?

—I reject the question on the facts. Mr Gale was never a research assistant of Mr Fraser. Therefore, the question is based on an entirely false premise. I have no doubt at all that the Australian Labor Party, in asking these questions, will be very willing in future to reveal all private sources of funding of any staff of its members, whether front or back bench.

—I draw the attention of the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs to the recent adoption of a resolution by the United Nations which declared, in effect, that the question of East Timor is unsettled despite Indonesia's claim to have incorporated the former Portuguese colony. I note that Australia cast a negative vote on this resolution and ask the Minister why this Government negated the inalienable right of these people to self-determination and independence; or does the Minister have only a technicolour view of what is happening in this neighbouring country?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — The resolution on East Timor has again been adopted, at this year's meeting of the General Assembly, by the Fourth Committee of the United Nations. Australia has voted against resolutions of this kind on East Timor since the 1978 United Nations General Assembly because they are considered unrealistic and impractical. The Australian Government accepts that East Timor is now part of Indonesia.
—A double standard. That is what it amounts to, Senator, and you know it.

— I have made that statement before on behalf of the Government and say again that the Government accepts that East Timor is now part of Indonesia. If the Minister for Foreign Affairs wishes to make any comment on any aspect of the honourable senator's question I will see that the Senate is advised.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport but, since I understand that part of the statement to which I shall refer was made by the Prime Minister, I will understand if the Leader of the Government chooses to answer instead. I refer to a report in this morning's Adelaide Advertiser of a joint Federal and South Australian Government statement that an international terminal is to be built on the site of the Adelaide Airport by October 1982. I ask: Is the Minister aware that Adelaide Airport is surrounded by residential suburbs most of which were established before the airport was built and certainly before any likelihood of an international service was envisaged? If the Government sees an urgent need for an international service in Adelaide, why will it not build a proper international airport on a separate site before the turn of the century, the completion time envisaged? In the meantime, what steps will be taken to protect the residents of those suburbs surrounding Adelaide Airport from the additional noise nuisance inherent in the proposed new air traffic? What changes, if any, will be made to existing curfews to accommodate the proposed international flights? What restrictions will be placed on the number of new flights, the type of aircraft used and the capacity of those aircraft which will be going in and out of Adelaide Airport? Finally, what general safety measures will be taken to ensure that residents in surrounding suburbs are not subjected to the increased danger of aviation accidents because of the change in status of the airport?

—I have not seen the report in the Adelaide Advertiser to which Senator Haines has referred but I am aware that progress is continuing at the Adelaide Airport in generally upgrading standards so as to allow for the handling of wide-bodied jet aircraft. It is, of course, a matter of record that unless progress is made towards the establishment of an international type of airport in Adelaide it will be the only remaining capital on the mainland without such an airport. With regard to the various matters that Senator Haines raises, in particular the question of noise nuisance, I refer her to a very interesting question which was asked by Senator Collard a week or two ago in connection with the noise levels of jet aircraft such as the Airbus in which, significantly, he pointed out that the levels were lower for such aircraft than for other aircraft which are currently operating in Australia. So it would seem that this may not be a very significant problem for people living in the western suburbs of Adelaide. The more detailed matters to which Senator Haines addressed her question-curfews and restrictions of flights-obviously will need consideration by the Department of Transport as and when the services are established.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry aware that since 1979 the governments of eight major markets for Australia's meat-namely, Korea, Egypt, Mexico, Algeria, Malaysia, Libya and Iraq-have approached the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation for supplies of meat and sheep on an ongoing basis? In aggregate this amounts to 100,000 tonnes of beef and 30,000 tonnes of sheep meat. I ask: Why are we unable to negotiate long term contracts where such agreements have a place in international commodity markets? Why do we not pursue long term contracts in the light of the United States of America countercyclical legislation which will reduce access to lucrative United States markets from the mid-1980s?

—I have no information on the matters raised by the honourable senator. I assume that the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation has been pursuing those markets which it regards as giving the best return to Australian beef producers. The honourable senator in his question has drawn attention to the possibility that with the changing terms of trade with the United States, other measures, and in particular long term contracts, might be more appropriate to protect the interests of Australian beef growers. I will certainly draw that suggestion and the question to the attention of the Minister for Primary Industry and get a more detailed reply for the honourable senator.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry. Did the Minister for Primary Industry on 24 September enter into a stabilisation agreement to apply to the dried fruits industry? Does this arrangement provide assistance to the dried fruits industry? Is it a fact that no reference of this matter was made to the Industries Assistance Commission as required by the Industries Assistance Commission Act? If so, why?
—I will refer that question to the Minister for Primary Industry for a reply.

—I have a question for the Minister representing the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs. It is about the prominent labelling of packages as 'Made in Australia' when what is not infrequently meant is that the package is made in Australia but the product is imported. Sometimes a product has been laundered in some way or other through an Australian factory with some minor modification, and is then prominently labelled 'Made in Australia'. I am aware of a case in which a fully imported citizens band transceiver was given a very minor modification in Australia and prominently labelled 'Australian Made'. On examination it was found that 99 per cent of the product in fact had been made in South Korea. I ask: What are the limitations, if any, on the use of the label 'Made in Australia'? Is the Government considering any action to tighten the limitations on the use of the label or any other action which might otherwise protect both Australian producers of products actually made in Australia and consumers in Australia from this practice?

—I had some indication that Senator Lewis wanted to ask a question concerning this area and I have sought some advice on the limitations on the use of the expression 'Made in Australia'. It is my understanding that with respect to some goods imported there are local requirements which impose an obligation on the importer or the seller to vary the quality of the goods or to carry out some modification to the goods. In the area that was mentioned by the honourable senator-the importation of some radio equipment-I understand that there may be a legal requirement for some imported equipment of this nature to be modified to meet the Australian communication standards. That applies in particular to marine transceiving equipment. It may be that that sort of modification has given rise to the use of the label 'Made in Australia'. Clearly, the matter raised by the honourable senator is important. I will seek an early response for him from the Minister for Industry and Commerce.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister for National Development and Energy, arises from statements to the Senate this week by the Minister to the effect that moneys from oil revenues this financial year will be in the order of $220m less than was foreshadowed in the Budget due to industrial unrest in the oil industry and the shipping industry. I ask: Is it not a fact that when announcing world parity pricing for Bass Strait oil the Minister claimed that the decision was made solely for conservation purposes due to an oil shortage? In view of the Minister's recent answers, is he now at last admitting that the application of world parity pricing to Bass Strait oil was for no other purpose than revenue raising and not for conservation purposes, as he has so often claimed?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is really the most convoluted question I have heard in this Senate. The fact of the matter is that the International Energy Agency, unanimously speaking on behalf of the 21 major oil consuming nations of the world, has said that for conservation purposes the price of oil in each country should be at world scarcity price. It is not only this Government's view but also the unanimous view of the free world that the way to get oil conservation and the way to get an energy balance in this world is by import parity pricing. What I have said before and what the Government has said before stands. The fact of the matter is that import parity pricing has caused both a conservation of oil and a stimulus to exploration and development. The stimulus to exploration and development has been such that I was able to say that the incentives could scarcely be improved upon. The basis of the Government's policies remains impeccable.

ANSWER.PARA: What I have said on revenue is correct; that is, that the Budget estimated a certain amount of money coming from Bass Strait, Barrow Island and Moonie on the basis of the free movement of oil. There have been delays for a variety of industrial reasons. The result of those delays is that there will be a shortfall in the order of $220m in revenue. If one takes into account the proposed increase in the Saudi light crude market, to function from 1 January, the net loss to revenue would be in the order of $120m. That basically is the fact of the matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. In view of the answer given by the Minister that my question was a convoluted one, I now ask him: Why is he endeavouring to blame the trade union movement for a loss of revenue because of the non-availability of oil products to the community which, in effect, is a saving of oil products? In his view this would be conservation. He is now trying to blame the trade union movement. I ask him why he does that?

—The Indian rubber man would declare himself an amateur and cease practice on the basis of that convolution. That is a most remarkable situation. The facts are that due to industrial troubles in the oil industry, there has been a shortfall in the production of oil in Australia resulting in a revenue fall. It is fair to say that that does not create conservation. It means that that we have to buy oil at a higher price from overseas. So, rather than conserve, it in fact wastes and causes more costs to the Australian people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bonner Sen N.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I seek leave to make a personal explanation.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer to an answer by Senator Carrick to a question I asked him in his capacity as Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer in particular to his words 'or in the technicolour in which Senator Bonner has described'. I maintain that those words impute that I deliberately or unknowingly coloured that article. I delivered a copy of the article to the Minister yesterday morning. As the words attributed to the Honourable Johannes Bjelke-Petersen were actual quotes, I fail to see how the Minister could conclude that I was seeking to embellish or in any way to misconstrue such alleged statements, thereby giving false information to this chamber. I deeply resent the imputation that I would mislead this chamber and suggest that in future when I extend the courtesy of making available to any Minister a copy of an article from which I intend to quote, he or she reciprocates by reading same, thereby ensuring that he or she does not malign a member of this chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CARRICK
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a personal explanation.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I say emphatically that my words were in no way a reflection on Senator Bonner. They referred to what I described as the technicolour words used by the Premier of Queensland. The colour of the words as repeated by Senator Bonner were, shall we say, the colourful phrases of the Premier of Queensland. There is no way in the world that I intended to reflect in any way on Senator Bonner in answering the question. What I did was to draw attention to the fact that if one put aside the technicolour nature of the words of the Premier of Queensland one could get down to the hard facts. I want to make it perfectly clear to Senator Bonner that if he drew such a conclusion it was not of my choosing that he should do so.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — On 10 November I promised Senator Watson I would refer his question on New Caledonia to the Minister for Foreign Affairs to see whether any further information could be provided on the situation in New Caledonia. I am advised that the political situation in New Caledonia has been tense for some weeks following the assassination in September of a leader of a pro-independence party, Mr Pierre Declercq. Tension between the Melanesian community, which generally supports independence, and the European community, which opposes independence, has been rising and this no doubt contributed to the disturbances at the weekend. The most significant of these was an attempt to damage a large Gaullist Cross of Lorraine on a hill overlooking Noumea, since this monument has come to signify French sovereignty over New Caledonia.

ANSWER.PARA: We, as a close regional neighbour, will be watching with concern further developments in New Caledonia. The Australian Government has noted that the French Government has repeated its willingness to conduct a dialogue about New Caledonia's problems. The French Secretary of State for Overseas Territories has also indicated France's intention to consider the political aspects of the Melanesians' problems and not to rely only on economic and social reforms.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — On Tuesday Senator McIntosh asked me a question about the Indonesian response to enquiries by the Minister for Foreign Affairs about recent reports dealing with events in East Timor. The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following information: Comment was sought from the Indonesian authorities on an alleged report from the East Timor Regional People's Representative Assembly expressing concern about aspects of the situation in East Timor, including reports of violations of human rights. The Indonesian Department of Foreign Affairs has provided the following official response to the request from the Australian Embassy in Jakarta for comment on recent Press reports about East Timor:

ANSWER.PARA: The Government has taken the matter into its attention and is still processing it to verify the authenticity of the document itself. As for the sensational news reports, it is noted as an annual exercise before the United Nations General Assembly session commences. It is aimed to attract public sympathy and to discredit the efforts made by the Indonesian Government in East Timor.
The Embassy will continue its contacts with the Indonesian authorities on this issue.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 22 September 1981 Senator Jones asked me a question without notice in my capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry in the Senate. The question related to specie testing for meats such as kangaroo, buffalo, horse and donkey. A reasonably long answer has been provided by the Minister for Primary Industry. I seek leave to incorporate it in Hansard.

ANSWER.PARA: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows-

Following the detection in the United States of America of substitution in meat exported from Australia the Department of Primary Industry introduced a species testing program for beef products exported to the USA. Assistance was obtained from a number of laboratories both Commonwealth, State and private, throughout Australia, with ability to undertake the required tests. Two tests were used; an agar gel diffusion test (AGDT), most commonly, and an iso-electric focusing test (IEFT), on a limited number of samples. Procedures to be followed in the AGDT were advised to participating laboratories in early September and the assistance of the CSIRO Division of Meat Research obtained to evaluate these and other candidate tests in terms of reliability, sensitivity, specificity, simplicity and cost so that standardised procedures may be drawn up. The test methods for the AGDT which are in routine use have been approved by the US Department of Agriculture as have the sampling procedures being employed.
The laboratories that have performed species tests on export meat for the Department of Primary Industry are:
New South Wales-Australian Government Analytical Laboratory (AGAL)
Queensland-Quantum Ltd; Government Chemical Laboratory, Department of Health, Queensland (State Government)
Victoria-Veterinary Research Institute, Department of Agriculture (State Government); AGAL
South Australia-Department of Science and Technology (State Government); AGAL
Western Australia-AGAL
Tasmania-Mt Pleasant Veterinary Laboratory, Department of Agriculture (State Government).

From 14 September the population sampling program on meat being held in store for export to the USA was progressively replaced by a planned program of statistical sampling and testing of meat from all registered export establishments. Export meat from any species and for all destinations is included in this testing program. Detailed directions have been given to inspection staff on the statistical procedure to be used in selecting samples for testing and over 2500 samples per week are now being tested.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 15 October 1981 Senator Jessop asked a question of me, again as Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry, relating to the price at which United States almonds are being offered in Australia. Senator Jessop asked whether there was an agreement between the United States and Australian producers. I am advised by the Minister for Primary Industry that there has not been an agreement at government level in respect of prices at which United States almonds are offered on the Australian market. I am assured that Co-operative Almond Producers Ltd is not a party to such an agreement. I am not aware that United State producers have given any commitment to any sector of the Australian industry.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: AGENT ORANGE: COMMONWEALTH INSTITUTE OF HEALTH STUDY

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday Senator Giles asked me a question with regard to appointments to the Commonwealth Institute of Health in Sydney. I now have some information for her. Neither Dr Michael Fett nor Dr Julian Gold, to whom Senator Giles referred in her question, has been specifically appointed to the agent orange herbicide study in place of Associate Professor McLennan or Dr Karen Blyth. Dr Fett was appointed as Medical Officer Class 2 on the agent orange study on 13 July 1981. His qualifications are as follows: Bachelor of Medicine and Bachelor of Surgery, 1st class honours, Monash, 1978; Bachelor of Medical Science, 1st class honours, Monash, 1978; and Master of Public Health, Harvard, 1981. Dr Fett has also had experience in Australian teaching hospitals and has undertaken training in the United States.

ANSWER.PARA: Dr Gold commenced duty at the Commonwealth Institute of Health as Research Medical Officer Class 1 on 21 October 1981 on a temporary basis. His permanent appointment as RMO 1 lecturer in epidemiology and Director of the National Health Surveillance Unit is proposed. He is assisting the herbicide study team. His qualifications are as follows: Bachelor of Medicine and Bachelor of Surgery, Sydney, 1974; and Diploma in Epidemiology and Medical Statistics, London, 1976. He has completed the requirements but is not registered for the American boards of preventive medicine. Dr Gold has had considerable experience in epidemiological work, including periods at the Centre for Disease Control, Atlanta, Georgia, in the United States of America, and with the World Health Organisation.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 22 October 1981 Senator Siddons asked me a question concerning an article which appeared in the Australian Financial Review about aid to home buyers. The Minister for Housing and Construction has provided the following information: The Government is currently examining the effect of rising interest rates and housing costs on home buyers and reviewing the need for new or amended policies to assist families into home ownership. The review will seek to identify groups in the community which are most affected by recent changes, the need for new measures and whether existing programs are providing value for money. It must be remembered that the Government's total commitment for housing and accommodation in the Budget last year was $555m. This year there was a substantial increase to $660m, which is an increase of 18.9 per cent. The Government is concerned about housing for Australians and the effect of recent changes on the building industry. The Government will continue to give high priority to encourage home ownership across all groups in the community.
