SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I rise because of my disturbance at the contents of this report of the Commissioner of Taxation, Mr O'Reilly. We are confronted with a situation where the Commissioner is unable to collect almost $1 billion worth of revenue due to the Federal Government. This is largely because of the inadequacy of the staffing arrangements made by the Government to support the legislation which this chamber and Parliament have worked at so assiduously over the three years that I have been a member of the Senate.

I wish to refer to the key paragraph of the report under the heading 'Tax Evasion and Fraud'. At page 15 the Commissioner noted that tax evasion and fraud may have denied to the Federal revenue some $167m and that overall tax avoidance amounted to some $973m. But in speaking about evasion and fraud he said:

It is appropriate to comment that as at the time of making this report, resources employed in enforcement activities have had to be considerably reduced owing to the recent decrease in staff ceilings. The combined effect of this reduction and the need to deploy substantial resources to the investigation of tax avoidance activities has seriously affected capacity to detect and control tax evasion and, as I have stated in previous Reports, is a matter of considerable and increasing concern to me.

We have a situation where this Parliament has attempted on behalf of the Australian people to deal in legislative terms with the subversives in our society-those socially subversive tax bludgers who refuse to contribute their fair share to the revenues of this nation.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are strong words, Senator.

—They are strong words for a situation which I believe has brought the Australian people to the limits of their tolerance. We have a situation where an inequity and injustice are caused within the system not only because of the failure to contribute revenue, and that has an immediate impact on the ability of democratically elected governments to carry out their programs, but also because within the system there is generated an inequity: Continually, pay-as-you-earn taxpayers are forced to bear the burden of the avoidance, the evasion and the fraud of those who are not within the PAYE system.

SPEECH.PARA: In the 10 years from 1971-72 we have seen this inexorable shift in the burden of personal income tax, and indeed of all total tax payments, on to the PAYE taxpayer. In 1971-72, personal income tax as a proportion of total tax was 48 per cent. In 1981-82 it is expected to be 55 per cent. In 1971-72 PAYE collections as a proportion of all personal tax were running at the rate of some 77 per cent. Now they are running at a rate of 83 per cent. Those figures, shortly stated, symbolise the way in which the burden of tax paying has been shifted on to PAYE taxpayers. How can this Parliament go any further in attempting to deal with tax avoidance, the activities of these people who pervert the best legal and accounting brains of this country to their own selfish ends? The Australian Labor Party has supported in this chamber amendments to section 260 of the Income Tax Assessment Act. It has supported in this chamber legislation which directs the courts when interpreting all legislation, but particularly tax legislation, that they should take into account and use as a major criterion for interpretation the social purpose designed to be achieved by legislation directed as tax avoidance, evasion or fraud.

We in the Labor Party say that a further step should be taken and that the Government ought to be more robust in the retrospective application of laws to tax avoidance schemes. But the question then is: What sort of partnership do we as a Parliament have with the Government in dealing with these tax avoiders? I am afraid that the report from the Commissioner of Taxation reveals that the Government in its doctrinaire insistence on cutting back employment within the public sector is hamstringing the Commissioner in dealing with tax avoiders in the way in which this Parliament desires and all honourable senators support.

We find that the same conclusion has been reached by a Senate Estimates committee. It appears that only a month or so ago the Australian Taxation Office revealed to an Estimates committeee of this Parliament that staff cuts will result in an estimated revenue loss of some $46.8m simply because there are not enough officers to chase tax avoiders. That information is contained in an official letter from the Commissioner of Taxation to a Senate committee. The salaries saved by reducing staff would amount to $1.5m, leaving a net revenue loss to the Australian people-a loss which has to be borne by other taxpayers if the programs of government are to be maintained-of $45.3m. In other words, over a quarter of a million dollars in revenue is forgone for every officer which this Government refuses to allow the Commissioner of Taxation to employ in order to carry out the task which this Parliament has assigned to him. I quoted at length from one section of the report on tax evasion and fraud. The same sorts of comments are scattered throughout the early pages of the report. For example, with regard to tax avoidance, on page 12 the Commissioner says:

The number of experienced staff required to be allocated to the additional work of detecting, monitoring, investigating and contesting tax avoidance schemes continues to make serious inroads into resources available for other administrative functions.

Indeed, on the very first page of the report the Commissioner is forced to make the plea that, from a management viewpoint, the Government should come to his aid because as a result of his moving, as the Parliament has required him to move, experienced officers into the tax avoidance area other sections of his administration are suffering deleterious effects.

In these few short comments I am afraid that one comes to the very sad conclusion-an indictment against this national Government-that it is prepared to forgo revenue, it is prepared to see injustice amongst taxpayers flourish, while it pursues its doctrinaire attack on employment within the public sector. It is doing this not only to its political shame but also in a way which I believe does not have the support of this chamber-I am speaking of all sides of the chamber-and, more importantly, is of very grave detriment to the revenues of this Government, or of any elected government, and therefore in a way which makes the Government an aider and abettor of the most subversive elements within this society, the tax bludgers who are undermining our very social structure.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make just some brief comments about the same report. Senator Tate has made a number of thoughtful observations about the report of the Commissioner of Taxation and I want to add very briefly to them. We are talking about one of the greatest inequalities in our society today-the way in which people at the highest level of the income scales are paying less tax. We would argue that because of somewhat feeble attempts to close off avoidance schemes these people are pocketing hundreds of thousands, even millions, of dollars. Of course, it is millions of dollars in terms of the report of the Commissioner of Taxation. At the other end of the income scale, low and middle income earners have to make up the loss which is incurred through tax avoidance by the wealthier section of the community. I think there is very little argument about this. I do not in any way derogate from the fact that the Treasurer (Mr Howard) has repeatedly expressed concern about this matter. Whether that concern has been followed up by appropriate action is the question which must concern us as a Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: The Commissioner's report shows the extent of this activity. The number of tax avoiders in Australia last year rose by 30 per cent, and it has doubled over the last two years. Tax avoidance is now operating at a rate 26 times greater than it was in 1975 and 1976. The report for 1980-81 identifies 22,366 people involved in tax avoidance schemes, involving a revenue loss of $973m. Twice as many tax avoiders were identified by the Commissioner as were identified two years earlier, when $424m in revenue was lost. The previous report in 1979-80 referred to 17,233 identified tax avoiders responsible for $711m in lost revenue. The amount being lost is skyrocketing both in gross terms and in the amounts that individual tax avoiders are getting away with. In 1978-79 tax avoiders were pocketing, on average, $37,500 a year each. The following year the figure had risen to $41,300, nearly four times the amount of the average annual salary. In the year of the Commissioner's report, 1980-81, the figure had risen again to $43,500. I remind the Senate that in 1975 there were only 861 identified tax avoiders. The number of tax avoiders has risen by over 2,600 per cent.

In attempting to grapple with this problem the Government has pursued a policy of legislating against tax avoidance schemes from the time they are discovered. This, of course, allows many schemes to operate for up to two years before they are closed off. What happens, in classic terms, is that the Government attempts to close a series of stable doors after various horses have bolted. Even then, the amending legislation designed to close those stable doors results in new loopholes being opened up. One of the reasons for the failure of the belated legislation relating to this problem is that the Government refuses to use fully retrospective legislation. I know it is argued in this Parliament that retrospective legislation is inherently bad, but if retrospective legislation is used to try to close off a scheme such as the Curran scheme then in a sense one has conceded the view that the social evil of tax avoidance is so considerable that it is justifiable to use retrospective legislation. Retrospective legislation of a general kind is the most damaging weapon against tax avoidance schemes. I am not suggesting that even that weapon can totally wipe out tax avoidance schemes, but it is the most effective weapon for dealing with the issue of tax avoidance known to parliaments and governments. We have made our view on the matter quite clear. Whilst we generally do not support retrospective legislation, the social evil of tax avoidance is so great that general retrospective legislation is, in these circumstances, socially desirable.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that accepted by the whole party and is it part of your policy for the next election?
—Yes, and it was part of our policy at the last election.
—That is why they didn't vote for you.

—Senator Lewis's party won, but I would argue, of course, that it won not so much because it was looking after the interests of 22,000 tax avoiders, although they undoubtedly helped the party coffers, but because of a number of promises which were made and which have since been dishonoured in legislation introduced into the Senate. I was referring to the question of retrospective legislation and Senator Lewis drew me out, as they say, on what our attitude to this was generally. What we are concerned about is that the Government's use of the tax system to provide tax concessions to favoured groups also provides wide scope for abuse. It is a matter which should be examined much more closely by the Parliament. In this report, the Commissioner of Taxation makes this comment:

SPEECH.PARA: Incentive measures of this kind . . . are usually settled on by professional tax avoiders to generate benefits never intended to be conferred.

Not only is the tax avoidance industry growing and not only are the avoiders getting away with much more on average, but also the prospect is that it is an industry that will continue to flourish under this Government. If one looks at the Government's record the only growth industry which can be pointed to is that of tax avoidance, unless Senator Chaney can point to another. One of the principal reasons for this is that the Taxation Office, as I have said, is already fighting a losing battle and has been denied staff to meet the challenges of people involved in tax avoidance. That is not a matter of Government admission but it is a matter about which questions have been directed to Government Ministers and no satisfactory responses have been received. Staff ceilings are preventing the Commissioner from detecting and pursuing tax avoiders.

A 3 per cent staff cut this year is being rigidly pursued and it will mean a reduction of 179 officers in the enforcement section responsible for uncovering tax avoidance schemes. As the industry grows, the staff is reduced, this year by 179 officers responsible for dealing with tax avoidance schemes. The Taxation Office estimates that this will mean a loss of $45.3m which represents a quarter of a million dollars forgone for every officer lost from the enforcement section of the Taxation Commissioner. That is a matter which one would have thought must be of grave concern to this Parliament and to the Government. It is a matter which might be quickly rectified without damaging the Government's ideological commitments in relation to Public Service ceilings.

Yesterday, I mentioned the idiocy of the razor gang decisions in relation to many of these staff ceiling matters. There is further evidence in this report of the extent to which the ordinary Australian citizen is carrying the wealthier sections of the community where tax avoiders and the bevy of lawyers and accountants advising them operate. This is shown by the amount by which pay-as-you-earn taxation has risen since 1975. Up to this financial year, PAYE tax payments have gone up by 146 per cent. Over the same period, wages and salaries have gone up by 98 per cent. In the last year of the Labor Government-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

—I ask that Senator Button be granted another five minutes. He is raising some vital questions affecting not only the economy in this country but also the survival of any sort of ethics in the country.
—Two minutes will suffice.
—I have an indication from Senator Button that two minutes would be sufficient. I suggest that Senator Button seeks leave to speak for two more minutes.
—You can have two minutes of my time. I will take only eight.

—Thank you, Senator. I seek leave for that purpose. I am grateful to the Minister for that concession because I overlooked the new 10 minute rule that the Standing Orders Committee, of which I am a member, has imposed on the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was making the point that, in the last few years, there has been an enormous increase in PAYE taxation; on the other hand there has been an enormous increase in tax avoidance; and the PAYE taxpayers are having the burden of tax avoidance imposed on them. As I pointed out, PAYE taxation has gone up by 146 per cent. Salaries and wages have gone up by 98 per cent in the same time. In the last year of the Labor Government, PAYE receipts as a proportion of wages and salaries were 16.9 per cent of the total amount paid in wages and salaries. In the current year that figure has gone up to 21 per cent. By any measurement taxation of middle and lower income earners in Australia has risen to unprecedented levels. I challenge the Government- as we did at the last election-to prove otherwise. I also challenge the Government to stop favouring a few at the top of the financial heap by avoiding questions of political and social responsibility relating to retrospectivity of legislation outlawing tax avoidance. I challenge the Government to bring to an end the games wealthy tax cheats play. Until there is evidence that tax avoiders are to be pursued seriously, no Australian can do other than conclude that this is a government that encourages, if not thrives on, inequality in Australian society.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I speak briefly to endorse everything that Senator Tate and Senator Button have said. Morally, tax dodging is theft, whatever it might be legally. Senator Guilfoyle this morning referred to the cash economy, lamenting the alleged belief that wage earners also substantially evade tax by asking for cash payment instead of payment of which there is some record. Certainly it is regrettable if wage earners are doing this. I think though that it ought to be noted that if they are doing it they are only following the example set by Barwick as Chief Justice and by the present Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser).

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I think Senator Walsh was saying that people who avoid tax, who indulge in the cash economy, are following the example set by the present Prime Minister. I believe that is quite contrary to the provisions of the Standing Orders, particularly Standing Order 418.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I did not mean to imply that the Prime Minister and Sir Garfield Barwick go out and mow a lawn for $2. They devise much more sophisticated means for evading taxation and take advantage of them.
—Order! Senator Walsh, the allegation is objectionable and I ask you to withdraw it.

—Very well, Mr Acting Deputy President, I withdraw. Tax evasion is theft. Tax avoidance is theft. Every dollar stolen in that way by tax evaders and tax avoiders is paid by other taxpayers. Principally, of course, it is paid by wage and salary earners, particularly those on lower incomes who can least afford to pay to make good, to make restitution for the theft of others. It is not just a question of loopholes in the Act due to careless drafting or unforeseen circumstances or the sequence of bizarre judgments from the High Court under the tutelage of the former Chief Justice. There is also the problem of governments actually devising laws the effect of which and the intent of which is to facilitate tax avoidance. We have the notorious film industry case.

SPEECH.PARA: We have another scheme current, designed by this Government, under which very high income earners, who also have some interest in farming or some income from farming, may lend, with gilt edged security, to the Government for one year $25,000 and to receive almost $2,400 in interest. They can borrow from the Government, by way of deferring taxation, $15,000 for three years on which they pay no interest at all. Moreover, the taxpayer who does that permanently evades more than $2,200 in tax. That scandalous rort, engineered and enacted by this Government, is misrepresentative of a scheme to help low income farmers. Of the 200,000 odd taxpayers eligible to participate in such a scheme, only 12,000 have in fact done so. Hardly any of them are low income farmers. In fact the scheme, as the former director of the Bureau of Agricultural Economics has stated on several occasions, actually harms not only smaller and lower income farmers but also anyone in general who wants to remain in agriculture-to be a farmer rather than to get some nominal interest in agriculture to take advantage of the tax haven provisions which were not inherited but designed and built by this Government. The scheme to which I referred is not a scheme to help small farmers; it is one which will harm them. In fact, it is a scheme designed to help the very wealthy who have some interest in and derive some income from agriculture rob their fellow taxpayers by tax avoidance and tax evasion.

The final scandal-not irony-is that almost half the members of the Fraser Cabinet, who designed and enacted this incredible scheme for tax evasion and avoidance, are well placed to participate in it themselves. We have no evidence that almost 50 per cent of the members of the Cabinet which designed and enacted this scheme are, in fact, exploiting it, but on several occasions Senator McLaren and I have sought guarantees from the Prime Minister via Senator Carrick that the Ministers in question are not exploiting this scheme for tax evasion and tax avoidance designed and enacted by those Ministers. No guarantee has been provided. Senator Carrick has refused to give such a guarantee and the Prime Minister has refused to give such a guarantee. So, in the absence of any such assurance, it is only reasonable to conclude that those Ministers have something to hide, that they are in fact exploiting the tax haven which they designed and built.

TALK.START.PARA: —Weak in logic and weak in morality, too.

—Will Senator Baume produce a guarantee that these Ministers are not exploiting the haven that they built? Senator Baume's silence speaks for itself. That shows how much confidence he has in those Cabinet Ministers who designed the scheme. He will not give any guarantees because, whatever else he may be, Senator Baume is a man of considerable personal integrity on matters such as that and he will not risk his reputation or compromise his integrity by giving a guarantee on behalf of Ministers who he clearly suspects are also exploiting the tax haven that they designed and built.

SPEECH.PARA: In quantitative terms this scandal to which I have referred is, of course, quite small. The amount of tax evaded up to now has not exceeded $30m a year compared with almost $1 billion a year lost through other forms of tax avoidance to which the Commissioner for Taxation has referred. Qualitatively, however, it is terribly important because it is an insight into the pysche of these Ministers governing this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Walsh, you are speaking contrary to Standing Orders. I think you have made your point and I ask that you do not pursue it further.

—I was just about to finish, Mr Acting Deputy President. It is an insight into the psyche of the Ministers who have made these laws and who are governing this country that they do not actually think there is anything wrong with tax evasion and tax avoidance unless too many people get into it and it becomes too costly to revenue. That is not good enough. The continuation of this practice of some privileged taxpayers robbing their fellow taxpayers year after year is not only threatening the Government's revenue base but also it is eroding the moral fibre of our society, and it has to be stopped. It will be stopped only when the present pack of Ministers is swept from office.

—It is absolutely scandalous for Senator Walsh to say some of the things that he did say and to use broadcast time to make allegations about which he unequivocally said that he did not have any evidence at all. He specifically said that he did not have any evidence at all to support the allegations, yet he persisted in making them. That is absolutely scandalous.

—I raise a point of order. I redirect to you, Mr Acting Deputy President, the point of order raised by Senator Baume. Is the information being given now by Senator Martyr relevant to the sixtieth annual report of the Commissioner of Taxation? It may well be a reaction to what Senator Walsh has said but it is hardly relevant from my reading of paper No. 1.
—Senator Martyr, I must ask you to direct your remarks to the paper.

—Certainly, I will obey your ruling, Mr Acting Deputy President. The report contains many things which are of interest to the Senate. Amongst those things are matters that Senator Walsh raised. In answering the matters that were raised by Senator Walsh I felt it was absolutely essential to clear the reputations that he has tried to damage. It seemed to me that--
—Do you support tax evasion?

—Charges have been made by Senator Walsh that this Government encourages tax evasion. It is not so very long ago that I was in the other place and I gathered the very strong impression that the Treasurer (Mr Howard) was almost fanatical in his pursuit of tax evaders and tax dodgers. There is not any doubt at all about that or about the integrity of the Government. My main reason for rising is to make clear that Senator Walsh has no evidence whatsoever for any of the scandalous allegations that he has made about the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) and various others, and they ought to be withdrawn.

—I raise a point of order. Senator Martyr is defying your ruling, Mr Acting Deputy President. You quite clearly directed him to direct his remarks to the report but he is circumventing your ruling and I think he ought to be brought into line.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, it seems to me quite improper that a speech can be made by one senator making certain assertions without a right of response. We are speaking to the report of the Commissioner of Taxation. Considerable latitude was given to Senator Walsh in making his assertions. I ask in terms of normal Senate usage for people to acknowledge that Senator Martyr is attempting to respond to those allegations. I am surprised that the Labor Party, having heard one of its members make the allegations, is now trying to muzzle someone who is trying to respond.
—You tried to stop him and you were not effective.

—No, I am sorry, I did not take a point of order as to the subject matter to which Senator Walsh was speaking. I just ask that Senator Martyr be allowed to answer the points made by Senator Walsh as a matter of normal courtesy and justice.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I think Senator Robertson really summed up the correct position in relation to this debate. Senator Baume tried to stop Senator Walsh and was ineffective. —Will you give the guarantee that Senator Baume very prudently refused to give?

—Senator Walsh, why do you not grow up? Fancy asking anybody a thing like that! How can anybody give a guarantee about anybody else's affairs? TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Martyr, you must direct your remarks through the Chair.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mulvihill Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.
The Government's policy objective is contained in the statement by the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Macphee) when he said:
The new system will strongly favour skilled applicants and those with close family in Australia.

The Opposition approaches this matter cautiously because it almost verges on a contradiction. We do not quarrel with the system favouring skilled applicants provided up to date statistics show that the apprenticeship intake for this year forms a fairly sizable part of the work force. One of the problems shared by people considering immigration policies is that they forget, in the first instance, that somebody who is brought to Australia at the age of 25 will be looking for employment for the following 30 years.

It is true that the concept of having guest workers in this country has been resisted, and rightly so. There are fat cat countries in Europe which, on the one hand, are pretty lousy in providing aid to distressed parts of the world but which, on the other hand, are quite happy to use people as guest workers and then pack them off. Australia does and should maintain a conservative attitude in that regard. I say that because it is completely repugnant to everybody in this chamber to talk about industrial cannon fodder. Job security is vital, regardless of whether the person coming into the work force is native born or from overseas.

The other aspect of this policy is that relating to family reunion. The matter of close family ties is, of course, a bit delicate. Whenever families in Australia say that they will create for a relative a job which is not in a scarce employment area, it might be argued that an unemployed unit from Granville or Footscray will be pushed away from obtaining that job because it had been created for a family member. This is a very delicate area. Yesterday, in discussions with Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle, I questioned whether the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs was teed up administratively to meet all the immigration problems. At the moment it is not. I prove it this way: I had a case involving a girl from Britain who was working as a technical investigation claims officer with Multicon Engineering Pty Ltd on a working visa. My immediate reaction was that she was here on a visa and I did not favour conversion of that visa. She said that she was prepared to go back to Britain and enter the queue to migrate to Australia in the normal way. When she got back, of course, the Minister announced the new system. She fronted up in Manchester. In the meantime, Multicon-I probed this very closely-said that it had searched for four months to find a suitable replacement for her. I checked with the Federated Clerks Union of Australia as to whether it disputed this and it did not. One would assume that after four months the bureaucracy in Manchester would have cleared this girl to come here. It has not. It has argued that it is unaware of the credentials and the submissions that Multicon had made. It could be argued that that submission was still in the regional director's office in Sydney. Of course, this gets back to the point of how quickly the Department can process these matters. As late as yesterday I spoke to members of the Minister's staff. It was conceded that probably there is a case. I am deliberately being objective in trying to relate job opportunities in Australia with those sorts of situations.

Another example is where the firm Climax Equipment, a firm that specialises in fork lifts and tractors, ran into industrial difficulty and wanted to bring one of its trouble shooters from overseas. That firm got sick of waiting for documentation. That person is here now. The problem now is if he wants to go back to visit his family briefly for Christmas and then come back to Australia how is that situation to be unravelled? I have just mentioned those cases where I believe the Department was not not really staffed to meet the situation. Further on in his ministerial statement the Minister referred to the fact that Australia's refugee intake has remained unchanged. I do not necessarily quarrel with the figures. But I believe that if we want more harmony we have to treat every continent on an equal basis. Senator Chipp and Senator Evans in particular have been vigorous critics of our pussy-footing attitudes towards political suppression in Latin America. Peru is surrounded by four fascist or semi-fascist countries. It is a very slow process to bring people here on family reunion, much less people who have been persecuted for their political activities. An exodus from Poland could symbolise European political refugees, we have Latin America via Peru, which is the only country that has a reasonable democracy where people come across the border and there is also the South East Asian syndrome.

The last part of the Minister's statement dealt with the difficulties that these people face in obtaining employment. We have a situation where we skip the physical attributes of political refugees. That is very nice, but when people come on the assembly line and argue that some of the work is too hard and state that someone else should do it, the union is faced with a very difficult problem. I am not being a devil's advocate. I am trying to be fair in order to portray the problems in this area of industrial relations. That brings me to my punch-line which I have advocated before. I know that the present Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs has been very reasonable to deal with. The shadow Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, Mick Young, would agree with me. It has been generally accepted that if I pulled off my request for a Senate committee to monitor immigration over a 12-month period, a joint committee might be set up by the other place. As I said before, I think this is due to the guerilla activities of my Western Australian colleague, Peter Walsh, when dealing with some of the members of committees and some National Country Party members who were shell-shocked when this proposal went before Cabinet. I believe that, disliking the role of some committee activities in the rural sector, Liberal Ministers agreed that there could be a very excellent job for a joint committee, but that National Country Party Ministers revolted.

At a later stage I will be seeking to resurrect the concept of a committee to study this situation. I have said respectfully to the World Council of Churches and to those Catholic people involved with refugees: 'You have a fixation on the numbers of refugees that you bring to Australia. Then other people have to help those refugees adjust to the job opportunities'. It is quite wrong. I believe that a standing committee of some sort could obtain a better balance if rival groups were to testify and then the different submissions were evaluated. No doubt other honourable senators have received aid memorandums from the Vietnamese community arguing that Mr Macphee was a bit hard in his concept of refugees. I have written to these people and have said: 'Have you ever looked at other continents and realised the persecutions and ordeals people are suffering in Latin America?' I have told people of both Protestant and Catholic persuasions that they had better look at their brethren in Latin America and other continents. I expect another response from the Vietnamese groups. I say quite candidly that I accept what Mr Macphee said. If people are on a losing side, irrespective of the ideological battle, they are entitled to feel that they ought to be saved from further reprisals when the armistice has been sounded. If Vietnam is to rehabilitate-which it will have to do-people living there have to face taxation to rebuild their country and there should not be a continuing exodus. Poland and Latin America face a different situation.

The Minister's statement contains a contradiction concerning family reunion. We need to know how many people we will take in an unskilled category when there is an outflow from another area. Many post-war migrant children encounter a maths barrier and will find employment difficult. They will not get a tradesmen's status in the work force. I appreciate the dedication of the Minister and senior officers of the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, but I do not believe we have a linking with the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Viner) or the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs (Mr N. A. Brown). My Tasmanian colleague, Senator Tate, on an earlier occasion on an Estimates committee, referred to Scandinavia having a vast computer system which can pin-point job shortages and help people to know what to aim at. We have not got that facility yet. A very fine Minister, Clyde Cameron, sought sanction for it. In subsequent years we felt that economy-wise such a scheme should not happen. I believe that we should get a close link between the two ministries. We do not yet completely have such a link. I do not quarrel with the objectives of this statement but I believe that justice has to be done. I will finish on that note of wisdom.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to the motion that the Senate take note of the statement on the new migrant selection system, I am cognisant of the fact that I gave an undertaking that I would cut my speech short because Senator Button was given an extra period in which to complete his speech. I will endeavour to keep my speech short. I quote, as did Senator Mulvihill, from page 4 of the statement which we have under review. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: The new system will strongly favour skilled applicants and those with close family in Australia.
Further on, the document states:
From 19 April 1982 applicants for immigration to Australia will be considered in one of five eligibility categories.
Those categories are then listed. I am interested in the second category 'labour shortage'. Under the heading 'occupations in demand' it is stated:
Applicants whose occupations are in demand in Australia will be admitted subject to:
Four categories are listed. They are:
a satisfactory Economic/Employment Assessment;
a satisfactory assessment of settlement prospects;
good health; and
good character.

I am very concerned that the Melbourne Age dated Tuesday 10 November in an article entitled 'Migration drive in US attracts 1500' under the by-line New York 9 November talks about the migration drive which is being conducted by the Consul-General in Los Angeles, Mr McLeay, who also comes into the category of jobs for the boys-

TALK.START.PARA: —He got out just in time too.

—He got out just in time because of other things, but I am not here to talk about that today. I am concerned that the Australian Government, through its agent in Los Angeles, the Consul-General, Mr McLeay, is conducting a massive and no doubt very expensive campaign to attract migrants to this country. The article, under the by-line of New York of 9 November, states:

SPEECH.PARA: Australian immigration officials in California are being swamped with inquiries by skilled workers wanting to migrate to Australia.
A spokesman for the Australian Consulate-General in Los Angeles said that 1500 inquiries were received in five days, recently.
This followed a promotional visit to them by the Consul-General, Mr John McLeay.
The article goes on to say:
We are looking for those with good academic qualifications and with three to five years' good business experience or application in banking or industry, Mr Slater said.
He is a spokesman for Mr McLeay. The article continues:
Mr McLeay's visit included radio and television interviews over three days in Arizona.
By the time he returned, the consulate was deluged with inquiries-most of them from the type of workers Australia was seeking.
The embassy also has found increased interest since it launched an advertising campaign in US newspapers recently.
The end of the article states:
In the past financial year Australia took 3236 migrants from Canada and the United States-a 29 per cent increase on the previous period.

This country has massive unemployment, and any amount of people capable of carrying out the jobs for which the Government is trying to recruit people in the United States of America. With the amalgamation of banks many very experienced banking officials in this country are now on the scrap heap because no jobs are available. Yet here we have this Government trying to recruit people in the United States of America with banking experience when we have people with such experience here. What sort of a government do we have in this country? Why does it want to bring these Americans into this country when we have thousands of our own people who could easily fill these jobs? Let us look at some of the other categories of people that the Government is looking for. The article says:
Some of the people we are most particularly interested in are those in the computer industry-programmers, systems analysts and computer salesmen.

We have all those people with those skills in this country who would be only too willing to carry out the work if it was made available to them. But they are being bypassed by this conservative Government trying to bring people into this country to fill jobs which we ought to be filling with our own residents.

There is another matter I am concerned about. When I look at those figures I see that in the past financial year 3,236 migrants from Canada and the United States have come to this country. I was in Canada recently and I learned that Canadians who are issued with visitor's visas to come to Australia are also given work permits. But there is no reciprocal arrangement for Australians going to Canada on a visitor's visa. They are not allowed to work in Canada, and I agree with that. Canada has unemployment too. Australian citizens going there should not be allowed to take the jobs of Canadians. But here in Australia we do not say that Canadians who come here on visitor's visas cannot take a job at the expense of our own work force; they are allowed to do it. We have this document put down by the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Macphee) giving us all the categories of the new system under which the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs is going to work, yet there are all those anomalies in it. I have no doubt that if I had the time to go through the document and time was available to me to speak about it today I could find many more anomalies.

I have raised two matters which are of great concern and which people who are out of work have brought to my attention. The fact is that this Government is advertising overseas for skilled people to come here when we have any number of suitable people to fill those jobs here in Australia. It is only recently, I think over the last six months, that I have had to draw to the attention of Senator Chaney-it has been a long, protracted discussion with questions in the Parliament and letters to and fro-the fact that a journal in the United States of America which is circulated in Australia is telling people in America that thousands of jobs are available in Australia. Senator Chaney wrote to me recently that the Minister was looking at the matter and would endeavour to take some action, if possible, to point out to the people in America that this was false advertising. I took Senator Chaney's word that the Government would endeavour to do something about it but I was amazed when I picked up the Melbourne Age today to see that the Government itself is advertising, at the behest of Mr McLeay, the Australian Consul-General in Los Angeles, for people to come to Australia. So if the answers I got from Senator Chaney are correct-and I have no reason to doubt that they are not-the Government is engaging in misleading advertising, trying to attract United States citizens here for work which our own people are quite well equipped to do. I hope that the Governmment will put a stop to this practice as soon as it possibly can in the interests of our own Australian citizens.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

The presentation of this report affords us a very limited opportunity to examine and to debate some of the basic questions which are contained in it. At least it does give us a chance to examine the activities of the Industries Assistance Commission since it was established in 1974 following an acknowledgement by the major political parties in this country that the work of the Tariff Board had limited scope and that there was a need, therefore, for another organisation not only to carry out the work which was formerly the responsibility of the Tariff Board but also to act in an objective fachion, an advisory fashion, to government, to industry and to the community generally. I think it has to be said that the legislation establishing the Commission sought to establish guidelines by which objectivity could be achieved. However I have to say, having looked at the activities of the IAC in the intervening years, that a great many of the recommendations of the Industries Assistance Commission lack objectivity and, in fact, do not put into effect the guidelines upon which the organisation was to operate. That is due to deficiencies in the legislation and to the fact that we have within that organisation an influence, which can be generally described as economic rationalism, which does not take into account the views of the Parliament when the organisation was first established.

What the Commission has done in its examination of various industries in the intervening years has been to create a lot of objective analysis of the industries and to provide the Parliament with statistics and information about the way in which Australian industry, particularly manufacturing industry, operates. In coming to its conclusions and in providing the Parliament with information the IAC has created a climate of uncertainty and confusion in many sectors of Australian industry. Australian manufacturing industry in particular has reacted very strongly to a number of the assumptions that the Industries Assistance Commission has made. Of course, in recent times the IAC, particularly with its latest report on the automobile industry, has created a climate that one can only say has contributed to dismay by management and labour in the industry. Probably, the time has arrived when the organisation ought to have new guidelines established.

I think that the IAC, with its emphasis on efficiency, on rationalisation and on trying to put Australia into a situation in the changing world economy-the world economy is now undergoing tremendous changes as a result of the internationalising of capital and the consequent effect of that on labour-is dovetailing its work with that concept rather than establishing in Australia a climate of self-sufficiency and certainty which would enable investment decisions to be made, with all that that means in respect of the viability of our industrial and manufacturing base. Therefore, I find myself attracted to the view that the IAC should be replaced by an authority which would plan for a diverse, balanced and self-sufficient industry base in this country. IAC inquiries contribute to a great deal of unease not only within the industry but also within the Public Service and within the Government itself. I refer to a report in the Melbourne Age of 6 November, which reads:

The Department of Industry and Commerce is believed to have advised the Federal Government to ignore the Industries Assistance Commission recommendations and maintain high protection for Australia's car industry.

Cuts in protection, as recommended by the IAC would cost thousands of jobs in the industry in Victoria and South Australia, where Liberal State Governments are due to go to the polls before the end of next year.
The IAC, the Government's independent advisory body on protection and tariffs, submitted its final report in August on proposed assistance to the car industry after 1984.

We know, of course, that the companies and the unions involved in the motor car industry have considerable unease and concern. This has a destabilising effect upon those areas and regions of our country where the automobile industry is a vital component of decentralisation. Certain factors have to be taken into consideration. Parts of our nation are vulnerable to changing world trends and to changes in the relationship between our own industries. It seems to me that the IAC does not take that fact sufficiently into consideration. For example, on page 17 of the report, in speaking of the automobile industry, it talks about the extent to which some industries bear the burden of protection, yet it does not address the advantages that accrue from maintaining the provision of some assistance to those industries. I refer, of course, to the component industries in particular. That point has well and truly been made not only by the manufacturing unions in the automobile industry but also in the course of an important statement issued by the Repco company.

On page 8 of the report the IAC expounds its own basic view. However, it seems to me that the IAC does not properly apply itself to advising the Government, the Parliament, and the Australian community for that matter, on the need for specialisation in our manufacturing industries. We do have certain skills in this area. We should be encouraging a wide and diverse manufacturing sector, but all too often the IAC's view of specialisation is limited and fails to take into consideration alternatives that would enable Australia to become both self-sufficient and efficient in many areas. That can be achieved by specialising in certain aspects of manufacturing industry. A view expressed widely by industry, and one with which I tend to agree, is that all too often the IAC's concept of rationalisation is the limited one of mere rationing; that it is prepared to see written down very important and valuable industries of this country, as happened with regard to clothing, textiles and footwear. I recall what I regard as the disastrous decision taken in 1974-75 to cut by 25 per cent the tariffs which applied to clothing, textiles and footwear.

The Parliament should be demanding that the Government make clear the need for the IAC to have new objectives, new guidelines, new concepts and perspectives concerning the international pressures which obviously are bearing down upon important sections of our economy. After all, whatever may be said about the problems which face our economy, it has provided us with a significant standard of living and the time has arrived for the Parliament to be given an opportunity to debate in the future this very important question.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Foreman Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to comment on the Industries Assistance Commission and its recommmendations regarding the motor vehicle industry. The IAC argues that the elimination of quotas and the reduction of tariffs would result in lower prices for imported motor vehicles and that this in turn would restrain the prices of domestically produced vehicles. According to the IAC, these price reductions would stimulate demand to the tune of 11,000 vehicles per annum which would, of course, represent only 2 per cent of the average new motor vehicle registration figure per annum. The IAC also argues that lower priced vehicles would contribute to an increase in the real aggregate income of consumers and would lower the cost to other industries. This, it says, would increase the overall level of economic activity and create sufficient job opportunities to offset those lost in the car industry. However, to arrive at this conclusion, the IAC assumed that a reduction in the price of motor vehicles would cause a decrease in the consumer price index, which in turn would cause a drop in money wages and further reductions in the consumer price index. Not only did it assume that money wages would drop but also it assumed that the loss of jobs from the motor vehicle industry would not affect the overall demand for goods. However, history has shown that, as unemployment increases, the demand for goods is restrained and real incomes fall.

SPEECH.PARA: Quite clearly, the IAC has overestimated the effect of the consumer price index and, as a result, has overestimated the likely gains from any increases in demand. The IAC admitted that some plants would close and the overall size of the motor vehicle industry and the component manufacturing industry would decrease, but it deliberately ignored the impact of any increases in unemployment on economic activity. According to some economists, the impact of cheaper vehicles would be swamped by the general downturn in economic activity which would result from a contraction of the motor vehicle industry. The Melbourne-based Institute of Applied Economic and Social Research produced a paper which showed what would happen if tariffs were reduced by 7.5 per cent and import quotas were raised by 20 per cent to 40 per cent of the market. The study predicted that, after three years, 21,400 jobs in the motor vehicle industry would be lost; a total of 51,300 jobs throughout the economy would be lost; and motor vehicle production would decrease by 35 per cent. This would happen after only three years with a tariff reduction of only 7.5 per cent.

The Government must not accept the IAC recommendations. The cost in human terms would be just too great. Unemployment in South Australia and in the Geelong area of Victoria would soar if the IAC recommendations were accepted. Already South Australia has the highest unemployment rate of any State in Australia and if quotas on car imports were abolished unemployment in South Australia would rise to something like 11 per cent. Of course, the importers group of the Federal Chamber of Automotive Industries and the National Farmers Federation could not care less about what happens to the car industry workers. They are the only ones who stand to gain from the adoption of the IAC report. They talk a lot about lower car prices but where were they when the Government increased the sales tax on motor vehicles and when the Government imposed the crippling petrol tax?

It is interesting to note that in 1980-81 this Government earned $4,000m from the combined effect of the sales tax on motor vehicles and the petrol tax. In the same year it earned only one-quarter of this amount from tariffs on cars. Obviously the Australian motor vehicle is not operating as efficiently as it could be but to argue that abolishing quotas and reducing tariffs would fix this is far too simplistic. Surely, if quotas were abolished Australian made cars would not stand a chance against the flood of Japanese imports. Even the United States has to protect its car industry from the Japanese to ensure its survival. The importance of the motor vehicle industry to the Australian economy cannot be underestimated. The IAC has outlived its usefulness and should be axed before it kills off the Australian industries. The time has come for the establishment of a motor vehicle authority, comprising government, employer and union repesentation, to thrash out these complex issues and work towards the development of a more efficient car industry. The introduction of the Export Complementation Scheme in 1982 is already threatening jobs in the component industry. Technological change is also posing a threat to the jobs of car industry workers. The issues are far more complex than the IAC has suggested and can only be resolved by responsible long term economic planning. It is this sort of long term planning which is seriously lacking in Australia. It is about time the Government recognised this fact.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not always see eye to eye with my colleague Senator Arthur Gietzelt but his comments in relation to the Industries Assistance Commission made a lot of sense to me. In the brief time available I would like to speak about the uncertainty which is created in the minds of industry by the manner in which the IAC presents its reports and the delays and attitudes of governments in responding to those reports. I refer particularly to the problems that are inherent in the system itself. The IAC's types of recommendations, in focussing unduly on tariffs, quotas and subsidies, inherently attack the whole basis of long term certainty in business planning. There is also a need for a social evaluation of a lot of the recommendations. All too often the IAC compares one industry's concessions within Australia with another rather than looking at the global situation; that is, examining what other major producing countries are doing in relation to industry assistance. If Australia is going to compete and trade on a world basis it must compare industry by industry on a global basis rather than on an Australian basis.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that all too often, by cutting the heart out of industry, we do not provide long term security for employment or for long term survival of industry, with detrimental consequences such as unemployment. The IAC pays far too little attention to the problems of decentralised areas. I believe it should be paying far more attention to securing mechanisms. For example, we all recognise we have far too many manufacturers in the motor car industry. But the IAC says that it wants to cut the heart out of the industry, which virtually puts everybody at risk, rather than create a situation whereby we can have some mechanism for amalgamation. We have five car manufacturers in Australia whereas there are three in the United States. Surely to goodness the IAC should have enough sense to bring forward recommendations for the merging of these industries. We will only reduce prices to the consumers by getting economies of scale. Only through manufacturing are we able to introduce high level technology. Because of the time available I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
