SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill seeks to reform the law of parliamentary privilege as it relates to the power of the two Houses of Federal Parliament to punish for contempt of parliament. Before outlining the major provisions of the Bill, I would like to make some preliminary remarks about the well-documented inadequacies of the existing law.

The power which lies in the hands of either House to punish for contempt is an extraordinary one. It is capable of being exercised without any regard being had to modern precepts of safeguards, checks and balances in the administration of justice. For example, there is no requirement for the alleged offender to be given notice of any hearing; there is no requirement that he be charged; there is no requirement that he know the evidence against him; he cannot cross-examine his accusers; there are no guidelines within which the House is constrained to operate in coming to a finding; the accused has no right to legal counsel; the chamber trying him can act inquisitorially or aggressively.

TALK.START.PARA: —That sounds like the Federal Executive in 1975.

—Yes. And it need not demonstrate that it has reached a correct conclusion on the evidence. If all these things were true, undoubtedly Senator Harradine would support the Bill. He has been aggrieved by these experiences. Perhaps most alarmingly of all, the contempt power quite dramatically flouts the two basic requirements of natural justice.

SPEECH.PARA: The parliamentary chamber sits as jury, prosecutor and judge in its own cause. The accused has no right to be heard in his own defence. Given these facts, it should be seen as all the more alarming that the Houses of Parliament are the only civil body which can imprison someone without any right to appeal. I would suggest that not only ought any chamber be extremely sparing in its use of such a power while it exists but also it ought to do what it can to bring about a situation where the parliament is protected from vexations and damaging abuse in a way which is more consonant with modern legal safeguards. Clearly the way to do that would be to place the contempt power in the hands of the courts. It was with these sorts of considerations in mind that a joint select committee of this Parliament in 1908 recommended just such action. In 1908 when Australia was one of the more progressive social democracies in the world, parliamentary conservatives and progressives alike came to the following conclusion:
The ancient procedure for punishment of contempts of Parliament is generally admitted to be cumbersome, ineffective, and not consonant with modern ideas-
This is in 1908-

and requirements in the administration of justice, it is hardly consistent with the dignity and functions of a legislative body which has been assailed by newspapers or individuals to engage within the chamber in conflict with the alleged offenders, and to perform the duties of prosecutor, judge and gaoler.

All the . . . witnesses who gave evidence . . . were agreed that it would be competent for the Commonwealth Parliament . . . to assign to the ordinary courts of law jurisdiction to deal with . . . persons charged with and found guilty of contempt of Parliament . . . such legislation would not create new offences, or offences previously unknown to the law of Parliament; it would merely provide a new tribunal for adjudication and determination and possibly a new measure of punishment.

The new tribunal so exercising power could fairly be equipped with a greater discretion in the infliction of punishment than that possessed by either House. It could be authorised to punish libellers and slanderers of, and other offenders against, Parliament by imposing fines of a moderate or severe character, according to the heinousness of the offence or, in the alternative, imprisonment. It could also be authorised to impose upon the offenders the costs of the prosecution.

Those words were written in 1908 and in those words the Parliament was talking about a contemporary view of the law. A Bill was drafted to put part of that report into effect in 1910. It was never introduced. In 1934 the Attorney-General in a conservative government, Mr J. G. Latham, as he then was, prepared the 1910 Bill for re-introduction. It was never introduced.

The nature of the contempt power, as I have outlined it, should make us suspicious that the power is prone to abuse. A brief look at a few examples from the past indicates that exercise of the power has often involved abuses, and has rarely, if ever, acted to promote the dignity of parliament as viewed by the public. Perhaps the most celebrated and most frightening example was the Browne and Fitzpatrick case in 1955. There, the Bankstown Observer contained a series of allegations suggesting that the then Federal member for Reid had been mixed up in an immigration racket. Following a committee hearing, the transcript of which was never made public, the House called Browne and Fitzpatrick before it. Neither was permitted legal representation. Fitzpatrick apologised to the House. Browne pointed out to the House that he was to be convicted of an offence without any charges having been laid; that the case against him had nowhere been properly proved; that he had not been able to cross-examine his accusers; that he could not appeal. The House's response to that was summarily to convict both Browne and Fitzpatrick of contempt of parliament, and have them incarcerated at Goulburn Gaol for some months.

This is not an incident of which this Parliament can be particularly proud. Again, it was an incident in which the Parliament was seen by the public to behave in an undignified way; an ironic result when one remembers that the Parliament was seeking to preserve its dignity. As evidence of that, I seek leave to have copies of three newspaper articles of the time incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The documents read as follows-
THE 'SYDNEY MORNING HERALD'
Friday, June 10, 1955Trial by Parliament

'Behold, how great a matter a little fire kindleth!' When Mr C. A. Morgan, M.P., feeling aggrieved by charges made against him in the Bankstown 'Observer', decided to take his complaint to the House and its committee of privileges, instead of instituting legal proceedings for damages, he set in motion a remarkable train of events. These led yesterday to the protraction of a session of the Federal Parliament which was due to end last night, and to a decision to call the owner and editor of the paper before the Bar of the House.

Parliament is properly jealous of its rights, dignity and privileges. It is essential to the working of our democratic system that members in the performance of their duties, should be protected against improper influence or intimidation from outside. But Parliament, in exercising its rights, must be careful not to infringe those of ordinary citizens by procedures inconsistent with the normal processes of the law. In asserting its dignity, it should be sure that the occasion really demands the invocation of its traditionally imposing powers; otherwise a loss rather than a gain in prestige is liable to result.

Many people will not feel satisfied that these conditions are being met in the present case. Persons conducting an obscure suburban newspaper were summoned before the privileges committee, sitting in private. They were not allowed representation by counsel, though it happened that the chairman of the examining committee was himself a QC. Then a report was tabled, and duly published, containing selected portions of the evidence of Fitzpatrick and Browne. The extracts, very evidently, were those best calculated to support the committee's finding that a serious breach of privilege had been committed. But they were also, necessarily, the portions containing the most damaging admissions by the two men-answers which, however disgraceful, might have been given a somewhat different complexion if counsel had been present to assist or protect them.

Mr Fitzpatrick and Mr Browne were, in effect, on trial. It is unfortunate that the hearing, in its secrecy and the exclusion of counsel, partook of the nature of a star chamber. Parliament is the supreme law-making body. When it or one of its instruments proceeds to arraign citizens for alleged offences, not against any law, but against the privileges of the House, ordinary legal safeguards and practices should be scrupulously observed. If they are disregarded, if Parliament sets itself up as a tribunal exempt from the customary methods of enforcing British justice, there is bound to be generated a public sympathy for the defendants which they may not deserve.

On the face of the committee's report, a report based on the procedures above indicated, a gross breach of privilege undoubtedly has been committed. What is the House, assuming it endorses the finding-and the brutal candour of Fitzpatrick in particular, has clearly caused a strong wave of Parliamentary feeling-going to do about it? There is talk of imprisonment.

Whatever penal powers Parliament possesses, or believes it possesses, so drastic an application of them would be most undesirable. In this country and in these times public opinion would strongly oppose the gaoling of any person except by due process of the Courts appointed to administer the law. Archaic precedents notwithstanding, it is not for Parliament to usurp the functions of Judge and Jury. An apology to the House is plainly due. The offenders would be well advised to offer it. And Parliament, in the words of the privileges committee in relation to other articles in the ''Observer'' would 'best consult its dignity' by then letting the whole matter drop.
THE 'CANBERRA TIMES'
Saturday, June 11, 1955
Parliament Unfit to be Judge

If the dignity, status and the very institution of Parliament depends on a repetition of the proceedings of the last few weeks, God help the Commonwealth of Australia. There has seldom been anywhere in any British country a poorer showing of conduct and a demonstration of unfitness than that which has been revealed by proceedings. Nevertheless, the function of legislation should be the supreme exercise of reason and power known to mankind, and it is of supreme importance that Parliament, as the very cornerstone of our liberties, should be fit to discharge its high function. If there are doubts in the minds of the Australian people, they have been put there by the eyes and ears of those who have watched sadly the poor standards so often displayed and ill disguised by all the outward show of dignity cheek by jowl with misbehaviour and medocrity.

The deep sense of misgiving which has spread through Australia during the last 24 hours did not begin or end in the proceedings by which two persons guilty of serious breach of privilege were committed to prison. It may be that other ends of justice will be served by the decision of the House, but the fitness of the judges is a matter of greater concern than sentences which may fortuitously have a salutary effect in other directions.

Parliament is a court for determining breaches of privilege and the matter in which breaches shall be punished. Parliament as a court makes its own rules of procedure, and being the highest source of rule making, makes its own rules. It is a pertinent commentary on the mental indolence that so often has characterised the discharge by Parliament of its duty to the people that it has done nothing to make modern rules with respect to that which it affects most dearly to prize, namely parliamentary privilege. Thus, it has happened that Parliament acts as judge in matters on which it has exerted neither wisdom nor power to define in accordance with modern democratic concepts. Indeed, the proceedings in the House of Representatives yesterday suggested that some of the judges were rather unwilling to accept the obligations that their own neglect had left at their doors. There is a certain abjectivness about some aspects of the Browne and Fitzpatrick cases. The original complainant was obviously disturbed at the consequences of his appeal to Parliament to defend him, and he scuttled out when it came for him to vote. There can be little doubt that no member of Parliament is undisturbed by the consequences of the use of power that was unleashed when the Committee of Privileges brought in its report. What then followed was admission in many words of the unpreparedness and unfitness of Parliament to apply precedents which have been left by its own careless custodianship of power. Surely, it was never thought when the Constitution was framed that for 55 years there would be no action by Parliament to declare by original act its own powers, privileges and immunities. What happened in Parliament yesterday was no precedent, but slavery to outmoded precedents which are the relics of other days and long faded circumstances.

The first proceedings of Parliament when it again meets should be concerned with positive action to review the entire procedure in relation to privilege. It would be fitting if Parliament were to impose heavier penalties on those which, by persistent misbehaviour, lower dignity and breach privilege. It is imperative that the proceedings of Parliament with relation to persons who commit breach of privilege outside Parliament shall be shaped in accordance with modern ideas of human rights. We believe that the power of Parliament must be upheld, and that the institution shall be protected so that the liberty of the subject shall be guaranteed and protected. We deplore that the Parliament of the Commonwealth is not better conditioned to achieve these ends, and that in consequence its power to defend liberty may breed fear in the minds of those who best cherish and defend freedom.
THE 'SYDNEY MORNING HERALD'
Saturday, June 11, 1955
The Gaoling of Browne and Fitzpatrick

In Canberra yesterday two men were ordered to be imprisoned for three months. They were convicted and sentenced without a trial in the ordinary sense of the word, without being allowed representation by counsel, and finally, so far as the House of Representatives was concerned, without right of appeal.

This is an event without precedent in the history of Federation. Never before has the Commonwealth Parliament thus arbitrarily exercised its powers to punish for breach of privilege or contempt. It had not, in 55 years, even troubled to declare or define those powers, but had merely accepted them as a vague heritage from the House of Commons, transmitted through the Constitution. This lack of definition had two extraordinary results in the case of Fitzpatrick and Browne. First, the House was uncertain whether, while possessing the right to inflict the major penalty of imprisonment, it was legally entitled to impose the lesser penalty of a fine.

Then, and more importantly, it meant that the two men were arraigned for an offence, hazy in itself, for which no penalty had previously been prescribed. In ordinary criminal cases the offender knows in advance, or should know, the punishment to which he will become liable. Even for contempt of Court the nature of the penalty-usually a fine, though imprisonment may be ordered-is well understood. But here, not only were the perpetrators of contempt of Parliament unaware-because no precedent or precise rules existed-of the penalties they might be incurring: Parliament itself was in doubt and divided upon the degree of punishment it could or should impose.

This dubiety, and the novelty of the circumstances ought to have counselled the House to act with more restraint than it showed yesterday. To say this is not to condone in the slightest degree the conduct of Fitzpatrick and Browne. Their offence was gross, and in Browne's case it was aggravated by a defiant refusal to apologise. Nor is any reflection intended on the House's approach to its task. On the contrary, with one regrettable exception, the historic debate was in the best Parliamentary tradition of dignity and fairness.

But the sentence passed was severe in the extreme. Not only so. The verdict was reached and the penalty fixed (by majority vote) in an end-of-session atmosphere of haste utterly unsuited to the importance of the matter, and following procedures in the committee of privileges-secret hearings and denial of counsel-contrary to ordinary conceptions of justice. The House should at least have had access to the whole of the evidence, and not merely to selected portions of it, before it made up its mind.

More time for reflection, in place of yesterday's flurry of behind-the-scenes consultations and arguments, might have convinced more members that Parliament would do itself a disservice in the public esteem by invoking the ancient and outmoded sanctions of privilege and applying them so harshly. By so doing it has risked making martyrs of two inconspicuous and rather contemptible persons. And it has raised up a strong public feeling that no citizens of this free country, whatever their misdemeanours, should be gaoled except by due process of the law and the Courts.

TALK.START.PARA: —The power exists in State Houses of Parliament also. That means that 13 groups of politicians in Australia have the power to hold inquisitions in secret, to intimidate and to punish summarily without trial, without permitting the accused a right of appeal. State Houses too have abused the privilege power. I cite a case from as recently as 1968 in South Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: In South Australia in 1968, a select committee of the South Australian Legislative Council heard evidence to do with the introduction of the Scientology (Prohibition) Bill from one K. E. Klaebe. Mr Klaebe later wrote to the Secretary of the Committee which was inquiring into these matters in these terms:

Re the honourable Mr Hill (the Chairman of the Committee) although I accepted at the time the reassurance of the Committee re its impartiality, on further reflection I feel I must make the following statement:

As I understand it from the comments of the honourable members during evidence on the 30th inst., if I believe that the abovenamed is unduly biased against scientology, I must formally charge him with that short-coming. I now take up that suggestion. In doing so I restate the allegations I made in my evidence which I may point out the honourable gentleman was not prepared to deny.

In my view, Mr Klaebe was exercising his democratic rights in writing that letter. He was doing so, I suggest, with some dignity and with some moderation. Mr Klaebe was called before the Bar of the Legislative Council and was given only the opportunity to apologise. He was not allowed counsel. He was not given any opportunity even to speak in his own defence. He was then addressed in these terms by the President of the Legisla- tive Council.

Mr Klaebe, I have to inform you that in the opinion of the House the writing and sending of the letter was highly improper conduct and the House, without proceeding to the question whether that conduct constitutes a contempt of the House, issues a warning to you to refrain from a repetition of such conduct in the future, which could be attended with most serious consequences. To deliberately attribute to the chairman of a select committee a lack of impartiality is a contempt of the Legislative Council which, on being duly established, can be severely punished.

Honourable members, when individually engaged on official duties both inside and outside the chamber, are obliged to make up their minds and speak out as they think fit, but when sitting as members of a select committee they are, whatever they may have said before, under a strict duty to be impartial, and they invariably discharge their duties. That concludes the proceedings, Mr Klaebe, and you may withdraw.

I suggest that that is a ludicrous statement and that the dignity of a chamber of Parliament will not be sustained by this sort of sanctimony. After reviewing these cases and others, one of Australia's leading authorities on parliamentary privilege, Dennis Pearce, had this to say:

There would seem to be many advantages in empowering the courts to deal with questions of contempt of Parliament-it would avoid the use of the contempt procedure for political purposes, it would deter hasty allegations of the commission of contempt, it would ensure a person the chance to put his own case properly-to mention some of the more obvious. Perhaps more importantly, the dignity of Parliament would be enhanced as it would avoid the aspersion case against it of being both prosecutor and judge.

The authors of the book Freedom in Australia, Enid Campbell and Harry Whitmore, are of the same opinion. This Bill now seeks to remove most of the parliamentary contempt power to a court. The Bill creates a series of offences against Parliament. The word 'contempt' is not used, but the offences created are modelled on offences which have been traditionally held to be in contempt of Parliament. These matters are dealt with in clauses 7 to 22.

Clause 11 dealing with defamation of Parliament is perhaps the most topical. The clause creates the offence of publishing 'defamatory or scandalous matter tending to adversely affect the reputation of either House or its members or to impair the respect due to the authority of either House.' The Latham Bill of 1934 created a similar offence. However I have added to the earlier Bill to accommodate more modern ideas, and to create the defences of truth, reasonable mistake, and fair comment. This is in line with the Australian Law Reform Commission report on defamation.

The report of the House of Commons Select Committee on Parliamentary Privilege of 1967 also recommended that similar defences be recognised. I note further that Messrs Birney, Holding and Jacobi, members of the House of Representatives, in their dissenting report call for privilege law on defamation of Parliament which takes into account the relationship between the Press and Parliament. That is what was done by the Law Reform Commission and the House of Commons Select Committee. I have drafted clause 22 accordingly.

Clause 4 (2) provides that if an Act is an offence as set out in the Bill, the House of Parliament may not proceed against such Act except according to the procedures laid down by the Bill. That means that the House cannot punish, but may refer the matter to a court for trial. If the accused is found guilty, he may be punished accordingly by the court. In deference to the views of the Select Committee of the House of Commons on Parliamentary Privilege no attempt has been made to codify exhaustively offences against Parliament, although the offences created in the Bill range fairly widely over the whole ambit of contempt of Parliament. Accordingly there may be a residuum of offences against Parliament which are not covered by the Bill. The Parliament remains free to decide what those further offences are. It may punish in such cases but cannot, without referring the matter to a court, imprison a person. That is dealt with in clause 4 (3). This would enable the Houses to retain exclusive jurisdiction over their own precincts by way of orders to their officers. Also, either House may order a person to desist from behaviour. If such order is within the authority of the House, disobedience of it discloses an offence under clause 14 of the Bill.

Clause 4 (4) enables a court inquiring into an offence, or other non-compliance with the Bill, to examine records of the proceedings of Parliament, but only so far as is necessary for making its determinations. Any proceeding against an alleged offence against the Act takes place in two stages. Firstly, either House of Parliament may investigate the matter through its privileges committee. The committee can then recommend that the House require the Attorney-General to prosecute. If the House then passes a resolution to that effect, the Attorney-General institutes proceedings in the courts. The court then hears the matter de novo-that is, it shall hear all the evidence and come to its own conclusion on that evidence as to whether an offence has been committed, and what penalty is appropriate within maximum penalties prescribed by the Act. That maximum penalty is one year's imprisonment or a $10,000 fine, or any lesser maximum penalty that the House provides for a particular case.

Also, parliamentary investigations of possible offences are to be made only according to certain safeguards. These are as follows: Committee hearings are to be heard in public if a witness requires; the alleged offender is to be given the right to legal advice at all times; the alleged offender has a right against self-incrimination; where a person's conduct is raised that person has a right to be heard in his own defence; the Committee is required to give the alleged offender notice of the time, place and nature of any hearing investigating the possible commission of an offence, to which that person is called to give evidence; and unless large numbers of members are involved, the Committee will as far as is possible not include members with a personal interest in the matter. Clause 29 empowers the High Court to make orders or declarations to ensure those safeguards are complied with.

It is appropriate at this stage for me to explain why I have seen it necessary to draft and introduce this Bill at this stage. I should explain that my intention was not to prejudice the report by the House of Representatives Privileges Committee on the Oakes case. At no stage did I have any special knowledge about the deliberations of that Committee. When announcing my Bill, I assiduously avoided any direct comment on the Laurie Oakes case. My purposes were to ensure that the possibility of referring contempt cases to a court was widely discussed in the community, and to put before the Parliament and the people a concrete proposal.

Since then, I have been gratified by the report of the House of Representatives Privileges Committee which calls for review of privilege. I have been gratified by the concern expressed by some parliamentarians about this issue. In particular, I refer to Mr Hodgman's views as expressed in the House on 29 October. Mr Hodgman said that the right of a person against whom allegations have been made to be heard in his own defence was: 'absolutely fundamental to the administration of justice'. I agree with him, and applaud him for that statement. However, his conduct on the Privileges Committee may have belied it. He went on to say:

The most humble and menial defendant charged before the most inferior court of competent jurisdiction in the land on the most trifling charge imaginable has, as the law demands, the total, absolute and fundamental right to be heard on his own behalf.

The most humble and menial defendant charged before the most inferior court of competent jurisdiction in the land on the most trifling charge has more rights than the right to be heard on his own behalf. He has the right to legal counsel; the right to notice of the charge against him; the right in most cases to cross-examine his accusers; the right to be heard by a body with no personal interest in his case; the right to reasons for a decision; and the right to appeal against any decision. I would be happy if this Parliament took it upon itself to provide those basic rights to someone accused of a breach of parliamentary privilege because there is no way of doing that other than to provide that such cases be heard by an independent judicial tribunal. I hope honourable senators will consider that very seriously.

It is natural for honourable senators and members of the House to seek to retain a maximum of discretion in this area. As they will be exercising that discretion, perhaps they believe it will not be abused. Common sense should indicate that that trust is naive. History shows it is unfounded. It is said that a move to remove the privilege power to courts would be in derogation of parliamentary sovereignty and the principle of separation of powers. I should like to offer my Bill as an opportunity for this Parliament to exercise its sovereignty by expressing its will in an Act of Parliament. Such an Act would in no way derogate from parliamentary sovereignty. In the words of Professor Colin Howard which appeared in the Melbourne Age of Friday, 6 November:

Parliamentary sovereignty asserts the supremacy of Acts of Parliament over decisions of the courts and the executive. It is not in the least dependent on arbitrary power to imprison ordinary citizens on grounds which need not be communicated to them and which they have no legal right to dispute.

Nor is the Bill in conflict with the principle of separation of powers. In fact, the power to punish for contempt should be characterised as a judicial power, that is, a power to assess the legal quality of Acts according to pre-existing legal rules. Returning that power to the courts would accordingly be more in harmony with the doctrine of separation of powers as enshrined in our Constitution than leaving it in the hands of parliament. Indeed, in 1955 the Sydney Morning Herald commented:
Archaic precedents notwithstanding, it is not for the Parliament to ursurp the functions of judge and jury.

I suggest to the Senate sincerely and very seriously that this Bill is one which will enhance the dignity and the public confidence in the Parliament. If I as an individual were threatened, molested, defamed or maliciously misrepresented, I would not welcome the public odium of referring that matter to my colleagues for summary determination in secret meetings. I would feel better protected if I could take that matter to a court.

I put it to honourable senators and members of the House that in any serious case in which the privileges of this place have to be defended, they will be grateful to be able to refer that matter to a court and to escape the political odium of being judge, jury and prosecutor in their own cause. The Browne and Fitzpatrick case may well have been such a case. Would it not have been advantageous for the parliamentary institution for the House to have had a verdict and sentence passed by a court? In that case, Browne and Fitzpatrick could have been punished-if indeed they deserved punishment-and the Parliament could have been defended without the public spotlight falling on 'the deep sense of misgiving' and 'the mental indolence' of Parliamentarians to which various daily papers referred in their editorial leaders on the occasion of Browne and Fitzpatrick's incarceration.

The majority report of the House of Representatives Committee of Privileges notes the lack of progress on the issue of parliamentary privilege. I am introducing this Bill because I believe that unless the Parliament adopts it progress will again be thwarted in this area. I have good grounds for that belief. Those grounds are provided by the sorry history of privilege reform in this country and in others. In Australia, that begins over 70 years ago with the Quick report of 1908, the draft Bills of 1910, 1932, 1933 and 1934. Then no action was taken despite specific proposals by the Committee, and draft Bills available for passage.

Since then we have seen the Parliament's privilege power used, and sometimes abused, on several occasions. On each occasion there has been much publicity, much public call for reform before the issue was quickly forgotten-until the next time it was raised. In 1967, a House of Commons select committee on privilege reported with fairly comprehensive recommendations. Again, nothing has been done as a result of that. In Australia, in 1978 the House of Representatives Committee of Privileges strongly recommended that the whole question of privilege should be referred to it for investigation and report. The House then agreed in principle to such an inquiry, but no such inquiry eventuated. Now, less than four years later, the same suggestion for a general review is being made.

It is my suggestion that either no such investigation will be set up, as in 1978, or alternatively any comprehensive proposal will not be implemented, as happened in 1908, 1910, 1932, 1933 and 1934. Accordingly, so that we may at last have some action on this matter, so that the Australian community will not condemn us for being unprepared to back up words of concern with action, I appeal to all honourable senators in a spirit of compromise to vote for this Bill if they believe, as I do, that it will improve our procedures on privilege-if they believe it will improve the standing of the Parliament in the community both now and on the future occasions when we have to act in defence of our privileges. I point out to those who may be able to see possible difficulties with this proposed law that it is an area which is difficult and complex enough to ensure that no solutions will be free of problems. It is also an area in which the present law is such that, as a number of commentators have pointed out, almost any reforms would represent an improvement.

Should this Bill pass into legislation, it shall remain within our competence to amend it so as to change our procedures. I have given considerable thought to this Bill to seek to ensure that it might be capable of acceptance from as wide a number of members of parliament as possible. I propose it to them with confidence and enthusiasm. However, from the beginning I have sought to produce a reasonable solution to this so far intractable problem, and a solution which would involve constructive and thoughtful contributions from all members of parliament. In that spirit, I wrote to all senators and members inviting their comments. I remain of that frame of mind. But I urge senators to bear in mind the necessity for comprehensive reform of privilege. I urge them to consider that in most modern Western constitutions, particularly those of Western Europe, legislative bodies retain their sovereignty and retain their privileges in a more dignified and modern way than has so far been available to our Parliament. Those countries include Austria, Belgium, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Israel, Italy, Japan, The Netherlands, Norway, Sweden and Switzerland. I shall conclude by quoting one of the minority reports on the Oakes case which says:
The law of privilege has been static for nearly three centuries while the world of politics has changed dramatically.
Implicit in those words is a challenge to all of us who sit here. It is only by meeting that challenge that we can discharge our duty to those we represent.
Debate (on motion by Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle) adjourned.

TALK.START.PARA: —When Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1981-82 was last before the Committee of the Whole, the Committee was considering the votes for the Department of Administrative Services, Divisions 130 to 161, 250 and 252. The question is: That the votes contained in Group C be now passed without requests.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mulvihill Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to refer to the evasiveness of the Department of Administrative Services in explaining to me how many members of the Australian Federal Police are used to check on citizenship applications. I raised this matter when we dealt with the Supplementary Estimates and, as Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle would be aware, I also raised it in the ambit of my questions on the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. I again take the opportunity to raise this matter, and I hope that I will not get the same reply as the one I received from the office of the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr Newman): 'Senator, it is going to be attended to'. That is not good enough.

SPEECH.PARA: There is a massive backlog of citizenship applications in Sydney and Melbourne. I would like to know specifically what the role of the Australian Federal Police is. I am not playing party politics because I also took up the matter of the force's responsibility with the New South Wales Minister for Police. It is not good enough, when we are dealing with the Estimates, that we cannot get specific information just because the Minister is away. I want to know whether five members of the Australian Federal Police are on that citizenship applications job. I have an idea that members of the State police forces have access to the fingerprint records of people who have convictions. Let us break it down and set out what is the responsibility of the State police and what is the responsibility of the Australian Federal Police. At the moment the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs says that that is one of the major factors in this backlog. That may be true, but let the Minister for Administrative Services or whoever acted for him when he was away, come clean and tell us in specific terms just what is the state of play.

TALK.START.PARA: — It is more than two weeks since the Committee of the Whole last assembled on the estimates for the Department of Administrative Services. At that stage I asked Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle who had made the decision regarding staff entitlements for non-Government and non-Opposition senators and who had communicated that decision to Senator Harradine and to the Australian Democrats. It was said that an answer was not available at that time. I repeat the question and ask whether an answer is now available.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coates Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On the estimates for the Department of Administrative Services I want to raise a matter which concerns the Minister for Administrative Services, Mr Newman. Honourable senators would be aware that, as a Minister, Mr Newman is entitled to a chauffeured car from the pool to drive him at his instruction. That would include driving him within his electorate of Bass in Tasmania. What has happened in recent times is that the Minister has decided not to take advantage of the privilege of being provided with a driver but instead to drive himself in a car drawn from the Department of Administrative Services car pool-a Datsun 200B. I guess that is fair enough as it is his decision although of course it involves a loss of work for his driver and a loss of overtime which does not help his driver's income. If the Minister is entitled to do that as a general privilege, that is fair enough.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to know from the Minister for Finance (Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle) how many Ministers have been supplied with cars in which to drive themselves when they travel around their own electorates. Presumably the situation is that the Minister for Administrative Services is embarrassed to travel in his electorate in a chauffeured car. Perhaps the voters may think that he is not one of them if he is driven around in that way. I seek from the Government justification for the availability in the pool of drive-yourself cars for Ministers.

What is a far worse aspect of this matter is that the Z plates, the Commonwealth Government plates, on the car that was supplied to the Minister have been replaced with ordinary Tasmanian registration plates so that to all appearances the car is a private vehicle and not a Government vehicle. The Minister is driving that car and presumably the costs of his travel by that vehicle are being charged to the Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who else is travelling in it?

—I do not know who else is travelling in it or who else is able to drive it. But it strikes me that this is a blatant cover-up by the Minister for Administrative Services in respect of the provision for himself of a service that is within his responsibility. Presumably the Government's justification or the Minister's justification for that action is the saving in costs; that is, if he drives himself the cost of an official driver is saved. If that is the sole justification, why is it necessary to replace the Z plates with ordinary Tasmanian number plates? This strikes me as a means by which the Minister seeks not to be seen as having the privileges of office. At the same time he is being supplied with them at Government expense. He is seeking to cover the matter up in this way. I ask for a response to this matter from the Minister.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise one issue in relation to the estimates for the Department of Administrative Services. As a senator who took his place in this chamber this year and who chose not to have an office in the central Commonwealth Government building in Brisbane but rather in a shopping centre, I wish to make a couple of observations on the practice that is employed in this country compared with that which is employed in other countries in relation to the entitlements of members of parliament. It seems to me that, despite the good will, dedication and constant attention of members of the Department of Administrative Services in Brisbane, a good deal of money is still being wasted in providing facilities for members of parliament. I believe that this results for a number of reasons. Probably the most obvious is that, when government departments buy, they buy according to a series of regulations which may or may not have anything to do with what a member of parliament is looking for.

SPEECH.PARA: I have made the point before that if one is terribly interested in rubbers, pencils and books, then certainly, tonnes of those are available. Computer facilities in which one might be interested are absolutely nil. I have since provided myself with those facilities at my own expense. It seems to me that a far simpler way of providing facilities for members of parliament would be to follow the American model and provide a lump sum of money to the member of parliament. Let him set up his own office according to his own priorities. I would much prefer to sit on packing cases and have a good computer terminal and operating mechanism with which to serve my electorate than to have a very nice chair. I will not inform the Parliament how much my chair cost but it was a one-off deal. I was quite staggered when I heard how much it cost. Indeed, if I had been allowed to buy my own furniture I would have bought it from my own personal contacts at a price far lower than what was paid for it. Indeed, I could have furnished the entire office for the amount it cost to provide my office with one desk. I believe that the amounts of money expended are not large in terms of the total Budget of the country but it is encumbent upon members of parliament to look very closely at that expenditure. I believe new offices could be set up much more efficiently and effectively if the money could be provided to the member concerned so as to allow him or her to make the choice from those things that are available according to what he or she may consider to be in the best interests of the electorate.

Finally, I feel that the officers of the Department of Administrative Services from time to time have to put up with a great deal from members of parliament. The officers who assisted me in setting up my electorate office in Brisbane were most helpful and, indeed, most solicitous. Nevertheless, I gained the feeling from them that they could see far more efficient and effective ways of operating. I gained the impression that many of the regulations which bound them were not, in fact, the most effective regulations. I wonder whether, not only in relation to this Department but also in relation to other departments, it might not be possible for officers at the work face to have more imput into how those departments operate so that they may bring more effective and efficient methods to bear.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Macklin is very lucky to have an office in the suburbs. I want to relate what happened to me. I decided, having won the Senate position, to have my office in the suburbs. I made that decision late last year. Early in March officers of the Department of Administrative Services accompanied me to the geographical location in which I wanted the office. We spent three hours searching for appropriate premises and found them. The negotiations with the landlord for those premises took about five months. The Department finally agreed to a price for the premises after a lot of haggling. That occurred in mid-September. The lease was signed on 1 October and the Government has been paying for the lease since that date. I am still nowhere near occupying those premises. The Department of Housing and Construction is dragging its feet and is refusing to put up the partitions. First of all the money was not available. Now the money is available the Department says it is too busy. Maybe at the end of the month it will spend the two days necessary to put up the partitions in that office to make it usable. That is a total waste of money. It could have put the partitions up early in October. I have been receiving this one response all the time: 'You will be in in two weeks'. I rang at the end of the two weeks and was told that I would be in in another two weeks. It has gone on and on.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not think that is good enough. It is causing problems. The furniture of the senator I replaced has been in storage for well over 12 months. Material from the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting needing to be stored in Melbourne cannot be moved into storage because my furniture is still in that storehouse. Senator Macklin can consider himself lucky to have a regional office. It is a very difficult task. I think it is a lot harder than getting endorsement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to follow through the examination of the estimates for the Department of Administrative Services, and relate it to a number of the questions that we asked when we had the task of reviewing the Government's decisions following the Review of Commonwealth Functions earlier this year. I wish to relate it also to some of the evidence that is now available and to seek some justification for the decisions that the Government has taken in the matter of staff ceilings. I just wonder when we will have some sort of cost benefit analysis of these decisions. It must surely be agreed that as a result of the Review of Commonwealth Functions earlier this year and the implementation of those decisions, there has been a great deal of disclocation of staff formerly working under the jurisdiction of the Department of Administrative Services which has caused a great deal of anxiety and concern, some of which perhaps has been temporarily allayed as a result of a Press statement issued yesterday by the Minister for Administrative Services, Mr Newman. Senator McLaren and other members of the Estimates Committee asked questions on this matter. We were told what was being done in respect of staff ceilings, private contractors and so on. Mr MacDonald, in reply to a question asked by Senator McLaren, put it in these terms:

SPEECH.PARA: Firstly, it is consistent with the general philosophy of the Government as expounded in the RCF statement by the Prime Minister . . .

I make no criticism of that response to Senator McLaren's question. It seems that a great deal of information has been given about the problems associated with staff ceilings in various government departments and particularly in this Department. But we do not have any evidence or information available to show whether there has been any saving of public funds which ostensibly was the motivation for the Government's changes in the whole gamut of functions of the Department. Therefore, on the basis of some philosophical view that the Government has we are supposed to endorse these changes that have been made without any evidence that there will be saving in public sector spending or that the cost to the taxpayer will be significantly reduced. I note that it was reported in the National Times that the Minister for Administrative Services, Mr Newman, told Parliament:

One clerk earned just under $15,000 in salary last financial year but $22,000 in overtime. A stenographer received $13,743 in salary and $19,986 in overtime. Another received $14,242 in salary and $18,696 in overtime.

Now that is one aspect of concern, although there are other aspects of concern about the transfer of work that was previously done by the Department and which is now being handed over to private surveyors. After receiving approval of the Minister in attendance, Senator Guilfoyle, Mr MacDonald made this admission:

If you use more private surveyors, an increase in the cost will result. I do not have a precise costing. I cannot say what would be the cost for a particular job to be done by a government surveyor or a private surveyor, so I cannot tell you whether in any individual circumstance one would be cheaper or more expensive than the other.

This is a very strange set of circumstances with which we are faced. There has been a great dislocation of staff and many former government employees have suffered. As a result, I have had to interview three separate deputations and address three meetings on the front lawns of Parliament House concerning changes that have been effected as a result of the Government's decisions to transfer projects to the private sector.

A couple of days after the Senate Estimates Committee reviewed the estimates of the Department of Administrative Services Alex Moss, the Executive Director of the Professional Officers Association, made a statement. Whilst conservative politicians will argue that they have a vested interest in this matter, I do not think that necessarily their views should be put aside. Just because a person has an interest does not mean that he is not entitled or able to be objective in his observations. Mr Moss raised a number of questions. He stated:

But it becomes a matter of great concern if the reviews are simply and blindly aimed at reducing expenditure regardless of the overall effect such reductions may have on the well-being of the Australian people.

In fact some evidence is available which reveals that the cutbacks in government expenditure, under the guise of increasing Public Service efficiency, are costing more than it was suggested would be saved. The Committee is entitled to have precise information to assure us that transfers will increase the efficiency of the Department, that the staff will not be disadvantaged and that, in fact, there will be substantial savings to the taxpayers. Yet we have no information about what the private contractors system will mean in terms of savings arising out of the razor gang's recommendations. Despite the assurances given by the Minister we have abundant evidence to suggest that public employees are being displaced without any guarantee of definite employment by private contractors. I do not want to misquote Mr MacDonald, but he said that whilst the Department was able to carry out its role satisfactorily it was in a very tight situation and would have to reduce staff levels even further. He hoped that this could be done without retrenchments.

I think in recent times we have had some evidence of the tremendous effect reduced staff levels have had upon collecting tax revenue in another department where staff ceilings have been applied per se without any understanding of the various responsibilities of the department. It does not necessarily follow that the public interest is protected. We have raised these matters consistently in the Senate and in the Estimates committees but we have not yet been given a satisfactory answer. I am sure there are misgivings about the absolute way in which the Government's philosophical position is being applied. The answers that have been given to us and the evidence that has subsequently become available show that transferring functions from the public sector to private consultants in a whole variety of ways does not necessarily result in a cost saving from the point of view of the department or the public generally. I do not know whether the Minister or her departmental officers are now in a better position to give us more precise information. It is now some six weeks since we first raised the matter, but so far we have been able to get only partial answers. I am not in any way criticising the officers concerned because they were not able to provide the sort of information required. But we ought to be provided with such information because we are dealing with the careers of a large number of people; we are dealing with a change in administrative functions and we are dealing with public funds in a rather cavalier fashion. I think we are entitled to more information than has been given to us to date.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Walsh raised a number of questions on the last occasion that we were dealing with this matter. Specific questions were raised by him and I have answers to those questions. The first question was: Who made the arrangements for appointing an additional staff member at Ministerial Officer, Grade 1 level to Senator Harradine's staff? The response to that question is that a position of Assistant Private Secretary was granted to Senator Harradine in 1976. The decision was conveyed to him by the then Minister for Administrative Services on 2 July 1976. The position was reclassified to Ministerial Officer, Grade 1 following a request from Senator Harradine. This decision was made by the Government and conveyed to Senator Harradine by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) on 25 February 1981. Another question concerned the level of the position approved for Senator Townley and what travel rights were attached to that position. On 15 August 1974 Prime Minister Whitlam wrote to Senator Townley and said:

I confirm that you may have secretarial assistance during the coming Sessional period. The position will be located in Canberra and will be at a salary level of $8058 to $8537 per annum with provision for overtime payments where appropriate, with the actual salary rate payable to the person you wish to appoint being dependent upon that person's experience and qualifications. There would be no entitlement for travel.

I cannot agree to the same assistance being provided for you as for Senator Steele Hall, since the Senate has recognised him as the leader of a party. I acknowledge, however, that as a senator who does not belong to a party you are entitled to assistance in dealing with the additional amount of legislation which is being brought before the Senate since you were first elected to it.
The salary quoted in Prime Minister Whitlam's letter was for the position of Assistant Private Secretary. A further question was asked by Senator Walsh which stated:
Did Senator Carrick authorise or take any part in the decision authorising this additional staff member for Senator Harradine?
That was for the Ministerial Officer Grade 1. The response to that question is:
Decision to provide Senator Harradine with a Ministerial Officer Grade 1 position was taken by the Government and communicated to Senator Harradine by the Prime Minister.
Another question was:

Was Senator the Hon. Dame Margaret Guilfoyle correct when she advised Senate Estimates Committee C on 21 September 1981 that Prime Minister Whitlam had approved in August 1974 the provision of an assistant private secretary position for Senator Townley, then an independent Senator?
The response to that question is:
Yes. The classification of the position was not specifically mentioned in the Prime Minister's letter but the salary quoted namely, $8,058-$8,537 was at the Assistant Private Secretary level.

Those were the questions raised at that time and those are the responses that I have. Senator Coates has today raised a matter with regard to the use of cars by the Minister for Administrative Services. I have some information on that matter. The Minister for Administrative Services does hire a Commonwealth self-drive vehicle which is based in Launceston. This arrangement commenced in August 1981. This vehicle is hired on a permanent basis from the self-drive fleet of the Department of Administrative Services and is a compact and modest four-cylinder sedan. The hiring charge is $40 a week including fuel and oil. Larger cars at more expensive hire rates would have been available from the Department's self-drive fleet.

A Minister is entitled among other things to the unrestricted permanent allocation of a car and driver for himself and his wife in his State of residence. Most Ministers have ready access to a Commonwealth car with driver or a hire car of similar standard in their home States. However, there are no Commonwealth chauffeur-driven cars currently stationed in Launceston and departmental investigations have shown that it would be expensive to arrange for a Commonwealth car and its driver to be moved there either permanently or for temporary periods from Hobart. In certain circumstances the Minister is obliged to use taxis in Launceston with the occasional use of a Commonwealth car with driver from Hobart. The cost of this mode of operation in Tasmania during 1980-81 was some $10,200. This compares with car hire charges incurred by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden) and the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Lionel Bowen) in their States of residence of some $41,000 and $21,000 respectively.

In view of the circumstances in Launceston it was felt that the use of a Commonwealth self-drive vehicle on a permanent hire basis would provide a more cost effective answer to the Minister's needs as a Minister. The permanent hire cost for the compact sedan of $40 a week compares favourably with the hire charges of $16 a day or $80 a week which would apply if the car were hired on a temporary basis only. This permament hire charge compares with a hire rate for a Commonwealth car with driver of $19.10 per hour plus travelling allowance for the driver where overnight stays away from Hobart are involved. The hire rate also compares favourably with hire or rental charges made by private firms. It is correct that the Minister's hired self-drive vehicle carries Tasmanian, not Commonwealth, registration plates. This was arranged for security reasons. The Minister has received a number of threatening phone calls and has been subject to other incidents in Launceston.

A comment was made by Senator Macklin with regard to his feeling that he would prefer to exercise choice and priorities in the conditions and facilities that are offered to him as a senator. I will draw the Minister's attention to those comments and to the comments also of Senator Robert Ray who is experiencing difficulties in having his office accommodation settled. With regard to the matter raised by Senator Gietzelt, I have no specific information. After all, we have no specific incident which we are trying to compare. If we had a particular contract in which we might be looking at a particular service that is to be provided perhaps there could be some comparison made. But the whole of the function of the Review of Commonwealth Functions Committee was to look at those areas where it may be appropriate for the Commonwealth Government to move away from the monopoly service or the service that may be given and perhaps to share that with the private sector. In some instances this will be undertaken.

As was stated yesterday in the Senate it is expected that the Review Committee's decisions will result in some 16,000 fewer Commonwealth staff being employed and that over a period, as is reflected in the Budget, savings in excess of the expected $560m saving will be effected. The concern of Senator Gietzelt with regard to the effects of change on the Commonwealth employees involved is recognised. Where a total function is to be sold or disposed of to private concerns one of the matters for negotiation is the staffing involved in the transfer, but these are matters of precise detail relating to particular instances and I am not able to state in a generalised way the effect of any of the particular decisions unless it is possible to make a comparison at a particular time concerning a particular function. Having provided those additional items of information I now commend the votes to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a few remarks to make concerning the estimates for the Department of Administrative Services because the answers to questions which I asked during the Estimates hearings have now been provided and are not quite to my liking. First, I would like to comment on the remarks made by Senator Macklin and Senator Robert Ray in regard to office accommodation. Although I have never had any personal problems with officers in the Department of Administrative Services I wish to draw attention to a problem which does exist. It is not the fault of the officers but of the penny-pinching practices of this Government. In Murray Bridge, South Australia, a new Commonwealth office complex is being constructed to house branches of the Commonwealth Electoral Office, the Department of Social Security and the Commonwealth Employment Service. Although the sign on the board outside describes the latter as a job centre, I do not know how that term can be used because the service cannot find jobs for most people; there are simply none to be had. The complex is also to contain an office for myself.

SPEECH.PARA: I have had complaints from a couple of the people who will be staffing the other offices that no provision has been made for a rainwater tank for the complex. Hundreds of thousands of dollars are being spent, yet the Government cannot find the money to install a rainwater tank. I ask the officers present, through the Minister, whether provision could be made for such installation. The complex is still under construction. Why cannot some $2,000 or $3,000 be found for a rainwater tank and the necessary connections to the kitchen which services those four offices?

During the Estimates hearings I asked the representatives of the Department of Administrative Services whether the Government had paid compensation to property owners for the installation of a telephone in a holiday house in Gippsland for Mr Nixon. My question was as to whether any land had been acquired to enable the telephone service to be run in. The answer given was:
The Department of Administrative Services has no record of any such acquisition of an easement for a telephone line on behalf of either the Department of Primary Industry or Telecom.

Is it the sole responsibility of the Department of Administrative Services to purchase land or property for all Government requirements, or may land be purchased, or an agreement entered into, for an easement by some other department?

The other matter that I wish to raise concerns the vote for the Commonwealth Electoral Office. At an earlier stage I asked a question about the amount of money that must be deposited by candidates seeking office in the Federal Parliament. I was very surprised at the answer I have received and believe that remedial measures should be taken in regard to the matter. The response I received was that in 1965 the deposits required of House of Representatives candidates were increased from $50 to $100, and the deposit for candidates to the Senate were increased from $50 to $200. I was told that the current House of Representatives deposit of $100 represented in 1965, when first introduced, approximately 176 per cent of average weekly earnings but now represents approximately 35 per cent of average weekly earnings. The current deposit for Senate candidates, which is $200, represented approximately 352 per cent of average weekly earnings when introduced but now represents only approximately 70 per cent of average weekly earnings.

One can quite easily understand that whenever a Federal election is conducted many bodgie candidates register their names because of the small amount of money they have to lodge as a deposit. It is high time that the Government gave earnest consideration to raising that deposit. I suggest that the deposit for contesting a House of Representatives seat-nobody should be standing for election unless he thinks he has some chance of winning it-ought to be $500 and that the deposit required from anyone who stands for the Senate ought to be at least $1,000. We know that we run into problems created by honourable senators opposite who encourage a multitude of candidates to nominate for the Senate in particular. In a Federal election some years ago we had about 75 Senate candidates in New South Wales. The informal vote was enormous. The polling booths are not big enough and they are ill lit. I have spoken about this before and there has been some improvement. I am not blaming the electoral officers; it is the Government that is to blame. It does not provide enough money to light these halls properly.

The problem as I see it-many other people have complained about this matter-is that people are unable to cast a formal vote because the ballot paper will not even fit across the platform or desk that is provided in the cubicle. People have to fold it over. People are asked to vote by numbering candidates from one to 75. I suggest that many honourable senators opposite would not be able to number candidates from one to 75 without making a mistake. I could name a few of them. That matter ought to be rectified. The deposit payable by Senate candidates ought to be at least $1,000. We know that many people take advantage of the present system. We know that a candidate is allowed certain election expenditures as taxation deductions even if that person does not spend a penny as a candidate. That person can legitimately claim under the law a certain taxation deduction.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rubbish.
—He can.
—I have never done that.

—The honourable senator ought to look at the Act. That applies up to a certain amount. If a person claims expenses exceeding that amount he has to lodge a return showing all his expenditure. People do this. They take advantage of the system. In some Federal elections people have been known to nominate in two States in order to take advantage of the system twice. That is a matter that needs to be remedied. I hope that the Government will take that matter on board and do something about it. I do not expect to receive an answer to that matter at present; I will pursue it at some time in the future before I leave this place. But I would like to receive an answer to the first question I posed-that is, whether the Department of Administrative Services has the sole responsibility for purchasing or acquiring land for use by all Government departments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coates Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer again to the matter I raised a few minutes ago. I find the response of the Minister for Finance (Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle) to my allegations about the car driven by the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr Newman) to be quite unsatisfactory. SPEECH.PARA: I suggest that having plain plates in no way adds to the protection of the Minister. If he uses plain plates following security advice, which apparently is supposed to be the case, how does the Government justify the rest of its Ministry driving in cars with 'Z' plates, if that is the means by which people are identified? All members of parliament receive threats of all sorts and, of course, people are identifiable by their personal appearance as well as by the appearance of their car. The fact that their car may have 'Z' plates is a minor factor in my view. I ask the Minister for Finance to table, if she can, the security advice about this matter to enable us to ascertain whether the matter was given the proper considerations which she suggested was the case. I also asked earlier whether Mr Newman was the only Minister with such a car or whether other Ministers were provided with cars in this way. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will deal first with Senator McLaren's questions. The first related to a water tank at offices in Murray Bridge. Some people share the view of Senator McLaren that the application fee has not risen commensurate with changes in values. Perhaps that is something that should be investigated. It is perhaps something on which there would be differing views. There would be those who would feel that a higher deposit would penalise independent candidates who may have, under our democratic system, every right to present themselves as candidates for election. SPEECH.PARA: Senator Coates again raised the question of the car that has been provided in Tasmania for the Minister for Administrative Services. I have no further information on this matter. As I said to Senator Coates, the change of registration plates was arranged for security reasons. That is the answer that has been given by the Minister. I accept that as his reason. I have no security report to table on his behalf on this matter. I think that what has been shown in the response that I have given is that what has been undertaken involves a much lower cost than otherwise would have been necessary, given that there is no service in Launceston that is of a resident nature that could supply unlimited use of a car, as is usual, for all Commonwealth Ministers, leaders of the Opposition and some other people who are office holders in the Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —The change of plates answer is an excuse, not a reason.

—The honourable senator is expressing a point of view. I cannot take the matter any further. I have given the answer fully on the information that has been provided. It is probably something that the honourable senator may wish to contest politically. We have on the one hand the contention that there is extravagance and we have on the other hand some contention that because an economical method of arranging for transport has been provided there is something that ought to be criticised. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are a couple of points I would like to raise that arise from the discussion here recently of the methods of conducting elections. A point Senator McLaren touched on that has been brought to me by many constituents is the appalling degree to which polling places are not lighted. In other words, people have to take themselves into a dark little screened area and attempt to decipher what is on a ballot paper. I would have thought that in this modern age it would have been a comparatively simple matter to provide some form of portable lighting so that people who are voting can see what they are doing when they undertake that most important duty. I put that forward as a suggestion to the Minister for Finance (Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle). We should not expect our voters to vote in almost complete darkness. In fact, I have seen polling places where that was the case on a dull day.

SPEECH.PARA: The second point I raise with the Minister has been mentioned to me by a large number of constituents also. Why does the Commonwealth Electoral Office persist in a system of finding somewhere the most ancient, the hardest, pencils-pencils which write illegibly-to provide in polling booths when these days modern ball point pens are just as cheap as pencils and could be provided with equal facility? If ball point pens were provided the voters would not have to exert extreme force to try to make a mark on the ballot papers that the people counting the votes and the scrutineers can see later.

TALK.START.PARA: —Give them souvenir Parker pens.

—These matters are quite important, I suggest, when it comes to the people's part in the exercise of the democratic process. It should be made as easy as possible for them, not as difficult as possible, as appears to be the case at the moment.

SPEECH.PARA: The third point concerns Senator McLaren's view on deposits. Through you, Mr Temporary Chairman, I suggest to Senator McLaren, the Minister and honourable senators, that to the people who want to subvert the electoral system by increasing the number of Senate votes it will not make much difference whether the deposit is $200 or $1,000. Those sorts of people can get hold of the money they want and they will go on doing so. There is another possible solution to the problem and I commend it for consideration; that is, that persons standing for the Senate should be required to have a greater number of nominees listed on their application form. In other words, there should be at least, say, six names from every electorate in the State so that a candidate can be shown to have a substantial degree of support. I would have thought that that would be a better method, if it could be adopted, than increasing the amount of the deposit.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be brief in my remarks. I raise the problems of accommodation for senators and members of the House of Representatives within the metropolitan area of Brisbane. Although the officers of the Department of Administrative Services do a very good job in allocating space and certainly do the best they can with the services they provide to members and senators, it is virtually impossible to have adequate space available in offices to house the member or senator, the secretary and the research assistant within the one area.

SPEECH.PARA: Partitions are not available and the offices are separate. We have some members of parliament in one corner of the building and their research assistants in another corner, which in some ways makes it very inconvenient for the members or senators and the staff members concerned. During the short time I have spent in the metropolitan offices it has been suggested that the Department of Administrative Services plans to increase the size and number of the offices made available to members and senators by reducing the number of offices on the twelfth floor and transferring offices to the thirteenth floor. From time to time I hear that that is right and then I hear that it is wrong. I ask the Minister for Finance (Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle) whether the Department intends to make those sorts of extensions and, if so, how long does the Minister envisage it will take to carry out extensions to create the sort of space that should be available to the members and senators in the area?

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Finance (Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle) has given information about the staffing arrangements for Senator Harradine, but in my questions of 27 October I also referred in at least two places to the Australian Democrats, although the question of the classification of staff was not there involved. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly, I wish to deal with the matters raised by Senator Mason. The matters will be referred to the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr Newman) for consideration by the Australian Electoral Office. The sheer logistics of an election in Australia are enormous. On many occasions, community halls and other places have been used for a number of years. In some cases, there may be alternatives; in other cases, there are not. I note the comments of the honourable senator with regard to adequate lighting and other facilities. We will certainly refer his comments and impressions to the Electoral Office. Equally, the other matter concerning deposits will be referred. With regard to Senator Jones and his difficulties in Queensland, I am told that it is expected that the extensions will be proceeded with within this financial year. That is all the hope that I am able to give him. I hope that work occurs as soon as possible.

SPEECH.PARA: I now turn to the matter regarding the Australian Democrats. Senator Walsh asked who made the decision to provide additional staff and, in particular, he inquired whether the Leader of the House of Representatives (Mr Sinclair) was involved. Senator Primmer asked a question on this matter also. I am informed that, on 11 July 1978, Senator Withers, as Minister for Administrative Services, wrote to Senators Chipp and Mason informing them that the Government had approved a position of assistant private secretary to be shared between them. In 1979, the Government agreed to a request that they each have a full time assistant private secretary position. This decision was conveyed to them by the then Minister for Administrative Services, Mr John McLeay, in his letter of 25 September 1979. On 4 December 1980, Senator Chipp wrote to the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) asking for additional staff with higher classifications for himself and the Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats (Senator Mason). In his letter, Senator Chipp said that he had had discussions with the Leader of the House, Mr Sinclair, about the facilities needed by the Australian Democrats. He said also that he was forwarding a copy of the letter to Mr Sinclair. The Government agreed that, as from 1 July 1981, the non-electorate staff available to the Australian Democrats would be increased from two to four positions. The two additional positions were a ministerial officer, grade one, and an assistant private secretary, grade two. The decision was conveyed to Senator Chipp by the Prime Minister in a letter dated 24 February 1981.
