SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise the matter which was the cause of the postponement of the consideration of the estimates of the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet. This occurred because the Minister for Finance (Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle) was unable to provide me with an answer as to the use of a VIP aircraft by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser). Also I had a question on the subject on the Notice Paper since 9 June. I have now been provided-not through the Estimates Committee-with an answer to my question on notice.

SPEECH.PARA: To put the matter in perspective, I will have to quote from the answer. Question upon Notice No. 896 states:
Senator McLaren asked the Minister representing the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 10 June 1981:

(1) Did the Review of Commonwealth Functions consider during its deliberations what cost savings could be achieved if Ministers were prevented from using VIP aircraft for business trips; in particular, would not great savings be made by banning such trips as were made by the Prime Minister to Armidale for the purpose of visiting relatives and to buy a bull for his property at Nareen as was reported in the Northern Daily Leader at Tamworth on Friday, 22 May 1981, and in the ABC program PM on 21 May 1981.

(2) What was the cost to the Australian taxpayer of that particular trip and can this information be made available to the Senate before the Commonwealth Functions (Statutes Review) Bill 1981 is debated in the Senate.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Carrick

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

INTERJECT.PARA: (1) and (2) Ministers use Special Purpose Aircraft, in accordance with the long-established guidelines, to enable them to carry out the duties of their office and carry out other commitments. All members of Parliament appreciate that the pressures on a Prime Minister means that he has little enough time to spend with his family. It is therefore perfectly appropriate for a Prime Minister to take the infrequent opportunities that arise during the course of official duties to pursue family obligations, and anyone with an understanding of the pressures would expect him to do so.
At Armidale I did spend some time with my son. The visit was not for the purpose of buying stock and no stock was bought.

The visit to Armidale referred to in the honourable senator's question was in fact a call at Armidale en route to Townsville on official business. It is not possible to provide meaningful information about the additional cost of a particular segment of a flight.
The Commonwealth Functions (Statutes Review) Bill 1981 passed the Senate on the same day that the honourable senator asked his question.

I am at a loss to understand why the Department of Defence, which is responsible for VIP aircraft, cannot ascertain what it cost to keep that aircraft on the ground at Armidale for the period that the Prime Minister spent visiting his son. I would like that information to be provided. If I do not get the information within a reasonable time I will keep pursuing the matter until it is provided. We were told in a previous answer that it cost a certain amount of money per hour to fly and staff these aircraft. It would not be hard for the Department of Defence to look at the log to see how long that aircraft was located at the Armidale airport and to ascertain the cost to the Australian taxpayer of the Prime Minister visiting his son. I have no reason to doubt the Prime Minister's statement that he did not buy a bull. It may be that he did not bid high enough at the sales to get the bull. I will make some inquiries from stock agents in the area about this matter. The Prime Minister did not say that he did not attend a stock sale; he said he did not buy any stock.

I am concerned with the other part of the Prime Minister's very historic answer. Many of us in this Parliament have long memories. We recall the very stringent criticism, in most cases unwarrented criticism, against the previous Prime Minister, Mr Whitlam, for his use of VIP aircraft. Now we have on record the present Prime Minister saying: 'All members of Parliament appreciate that the pressures on a Prime Minister means that he has little enough time to spend with his family'. However, he would not concede that that practice operated when Mr Whitlam was Prime Minister. He was very critical. Mr Whitlam, of course, did not use VIP aircraft to travel the long distances between Canberra and Nareen that the present Prime Minister does. As we know the cost of travel is now astronomically high. The cost of transporting the present Prime Minister between Canberra and his home is very much higher than was the cost of transporting the previous Prime Minister. I am sure that this very historic document will be used as a precedent by many members of parliament. This Prime Minister has now set a precedent in that he has said: 'It is therefore perfectly appropriate for a Prime Minister to take the infrequent opportunities that arise during the course of official duties to pursue family obligations'.

If that applies to the Prime Minister, in my view it should also apply to many back benchers who are restricted by the Remuneration Tribunal in bringing their wives and families to Canberra. We are just as much entitled as the Prime Minister to have the company of our families in Canberra. The Prime Minister has the wherewithal to transport his wife and family with him on every occasion he is away from home. He is not prevented from doing so. However, back bench members of Parliament are. I do not know whether Ministers have free travel rights for their wives and families at all times but certainly back bench members do not. Many back bench members, particularly those from Western Australia, who live a long way from Canberra, are restricted in the number of times they can bring their families here. In addition, if a member or senator from Western Australia has to travel from Perth to Kununurra or to some such place and his or her spouse uses a spouse's travel warrant, that is one less trip that that person can make to Canberra. It is all very well for the Prime Minister to plead that it is appropriate for a Prime Minister to make infrequent visits to his family. That should also apply to back bench members of parliament.

I hope that the Tribunal, when it looks at this document, will see that the Prime Minister has set a precedent and that it will not be long before all back bench members of parliament are treated on the same basis as the Prime Minister, bearing in mind, of course, that back bench members of parliament get a very much smaller remuneration for the work they do than the Prime Minister gets and have hardly any staff compared with what the Prime Minister has. I put that on the record. I hope that the Tribunal will take cognisance of the fact that the precedent has been set. What is good for the goose is good for the many ganders who sit on the back benches of this Parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I will detain the Committee for only a minute more on the same matter. I think the carping of Senator McLaren on this matter related to the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) is mean-spirited and is against the best interests of family contact and solidarity. I believe all members of parliament and all Ministers, when passing through a region where there is a member of their family, ought conveniently to be able to spend some hours with that family member. I believe there is not one member of the Senate who, in travelling from one State to another and when coming to an airport in transit, does not take the opportunity on occasion to meet with a sister, a brother, an uncle or a friend-to make personal contacts which would not have been possible but for the fact that they were travelling through the area on business. Even within the city I know of friends who, in the course of their business, take the opportunity once in two months if they are near their family home or near a brother or a sister to call in for a cup of tea or for lunch. Is such a mean-spirited and carping approach by a senator in this place to bring derision or criticism upon that kind of personal contact within families? I believe it is entirely appropriate for that kind of family contact to be encouraged by the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: The only other comment I want to make is that members of statutory bodies have the ability to travel at public expense to fulfil their duties. I refer, for example, to chairmen of statutory authorities. I believe they are denied the ability to travel with their spouses when they travel away from home, quite as often as members of parliament do, to carry out some of their quite onerous duties. I believe consideration ought to be given to allowing chairmen and some members of statutory commissions and authorities the privilege of being accompanied by their spouses during their long term absences from home. I come back to my original point. I put it to Senator McLaren that we should act fairly in the Senate and not seek to make political advantage out of the Prime Minister or any other hard-working member of the Australian community who wishes to take a short time in a very busy schedule to see a member of the family.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Townley Sen M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to ask a few questions relating to the VIP aircraft fleet. I will do so in several sections. First of all, I will deal with what I call the smaller aircraft and I will get on to the larger ones perhaps at another time.
—Order! I am advised that that matter in relation to the VIP fleet comes under the Department of Defence. We are dealing with the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet.
—I have that right in front of me. I said that I would deal with some of it later. Surely I am on the right track.
—We will be moving to the Department of Defence as the next item.
—I am not dealing with the Department of Defence. I have in front of me a document headed 'Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet'. Is that what we are dealing with?
—Yes.

—Surely the smaller VIP aircraft come under this vote. I want to ask some questions. I believe that there are two BAC111s. For the benefit of those people who do not understand what they are, they are fairly large aircraft.
—They cost a lot of money sitting on the ground at Armidale.

—Why does Senator McLaren not flap his feathers in the right order? He has had his go. He would make it a lot better for everybody concerned if he would keep quiet during a speech that is not an attack on a person but an analysis of what is happening to the finances of this country. The cost of running the BAC111s is approaching $1,700 an hour. The cost of running the Mysteres, which are smaller aircraft, is about $940 an hour. Yet those smaller aircraft, of which we have two, average only 420 hours per year. It is expected that in the coming year the BAC111s will fly 550 hours. I want to know why BAC111s are used so much rather than the less expensive Mysteres. If a Minister wants an aircraft does he decide for himself which aircraft will be used or does he use the least expensive? The speeds of them are about the same. The HS748s travel more slowly. They will average about 500 flying hours in the coming year. It has been shown over the years that the use of these expensive BAC111s has been increasing quite considerably.

SPEECH.PARA: I also ask why the estimates for the larger VIP aircraft are not under this vote. Even when we look at the other votes it is very difficult to distinguish the actual costs of running the other aircraft and what percentage of their time is spent on VIP configuration rather than defence configuration. I think that the VIP operations should, in fact, be included in the estimates that we are dealing with at the moment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am really indebted to Senator Townley for the figures that he has given because they bear out the argument I was using in my earlier remarks, which argument was the cause of a very unwarranted attack by Senator Teague upon myself. Senator Teague was not in this place for the three years that I was here during the reign of the Whitlam Government. He did not have to suffer the almost daily unwarranted attacks by the then Opposition members on Prime Minister Whitlam for what they claimed was his unwarranted and unlawful use of VIP aircraft. I am doing the same, although in a very minor way, as those senators, who now sit on the Government side of the chamber, used to when they levelled accusations at Prime Minister Whitlam. I am very pleased that I hit a raw nerve with Senator Teague. What I said really offended him. It hurt him. He has now left the chamber. What he does not realise now is that his colleague Senator Townley has put him in the soup. Senator Townley has just told us that the cost of running those BAC 111 aircraft is $1,700 per hour.

SPEECH.PARA: What I was trying to find out was how many hours a VIP aircraft sat on the tarmac at Armidale while the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser), whom Senator Teague is defending, visited his son. Senator Teague said that probably every member of this Parliament makes contact with a relative at some time while waiting for an aircraft at an airport. But of course that does not cost the taxpayer anything. In those cases Members of Parliament are in transit, unless Senator Teague makes special trips to visit relatives interstate. He did not tell us that. He might. He might have opened up a Pandora's box.

The question I posed was: How much did it cost to keep that BAC111 aircraft on the tarmac at Armidale? If I could only find out the number of hours-as I said in my earlier remarks, they would all be logged and I will be seeking this information-I would be able to ascertain the cost, using Senator Townley's figure of $1,700 an hour. I am sure that the aircraft would have been on the tarmac for at least four hours, so we will find it cost about $7,000 for the Prime Minister to visit his son in Armidale. Senator Townley posed a further question. He asked why the BAC111s are used so much. I would like to know that too. He also asked: Who decides the type of aircraft to be used? I am sure that when the Prime Minister wants a VIP aircraft he would not order one of the smaller aircraft which Senator Townley says would cost less to run and would be a lesser debt on the taxpayer.

TALK.START.PARA: —He always thinks in a big way.

—I know he does and I know Senator Townley is very critical of the expense. Of course, Senator Townley did not realise when he gave those figures that he was really putting his colleague Senator Teague in a hot spot. Now the public at large knows what it costs to run those BAC111s. As soon as we get details of the number of hours the aircraft was on the tarmac at Armidale we will know what it cost on that day. We might search for the cost on other days. Back benchers cannot do what Mr Fraser did. If we are going through Tullamarine we can telephone a relative or a friend and say: 'I will be in Tullamarine for an hour waiting for a change of aircraft. Can you hop in a car and come and see me?'. That is only peanuts. It costs nothing because we are waiting for the change of an aircraft. In this instance there was a special purpose for the Prime Minister's trip to Armidale. It was, as he said, to visit his son.

SPEECH.PARA: I think members of the public at large who are listening today will be interested to know that it was, in fact, Mr Fraser who first started this witch hunt against the use of VIP aircraft by Prime Minister Whitlam. It has rebounded very much on him. The figures that have now been revealed to us-my colleague Senator Sibraa will be seeking some further figures later when we are considering another group of votes and those figures will be very revealing if they are made available-show that we have the most expensive Prime Minister, because of the cost of his own desires, this country has ever had. The sooner we get rid of him the better.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been provoked by Senator Teague to make a couple of brief comments on the same subject. I am very touched by Senator Teague's concern for family contact, as evidenced by his agreement with the use by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser)-completely at the taxpayers' expense, of course-of a VIP aircraft to VIP-off to Armidale overnight to see his son. I would be more touched if we had not heard so much cant and humbug in 1975 from the same Prime Minister about alleged extravagance by the former Prime Minister in a personal way through the use of VIP aircraft and so on. I would be much more touched by Senator Teague's concern for the contact within the Fraser family if the head of the Fraser family had not poured out so much cant and humbug when he was trying to denigrate someone else who was doing less of that sort of thing than he has done since.

SPEECH.PARA: I would also be more touched if the Prime Minister showed more concern for the welfare of other families-for example, if he showed a bit more concern for what subsistence on unemployment benefit for long periods does to family stability. I see little evidence of the Prime Minister or Senator Teague, for that matter, showing any concern for that. On the other hand, I see a great deal of evidence of the party they both represent trying to denigrate and vilify as dole bludgers those people who are placed in that unfortunate situation. No Prime Minister, as Senator McLaren has said, has indulged himself more in a personal way at the taxpayers' expense than Mr Fraser. It does not stop with him directly. We had his wife and her relatives bludging on the taxpayers with 4 1/2 per cent loans obtained under sordid circumstances from the Victorian Government-but it was ultimately Commonwealth money-a couple of years ago. I say that far from Senator Teague having any valid reason for complaint, both the historical record and the present practice show that it is high time the taxpayers of Australia got the Fraser clan off their backs.
