SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sibraa Sen K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Temporary Chairman, I take it that we are going to deal first only with the Department of Defence?
—Senator Sibraa, we can deal with them individually.

—I am very pleased that Senator Townley raised the issue of the VIP planes and their costs. He asked: Where is the estimate for the running of the larger planes in the VIP fleet? These are included in the Department of Defence estimate. During the examination of the Estimates committees when we were dealing with Appropriation Bill (No. 1) in September 1980 I raised the question of the cost of running the VIP 707 aircraft. Thanks to previous work done by Estimates committees and honourable senators, such as Senator McLaren, the costs are now summarised under one item in the Department of Defence estimate although we were originally told, over a number of years, that it was not possible for this to be done.

SPEECH.PARA: In last year's appropriations the Department of Defence said that the cost each hour of operating the 707s for VIP use was $2,757. On my estimate, after examining the operating costs, I calculated that these aircraft were costing $4,189 an hour. An article concerning the then United States President, Jimmy Carter, pointed out that the President would not be flying the Boeing 707 during the presidential campaign because it was costing in excess of $4,600 an hour. I contacted a commercial firm called Clarkair International (Australasia) Pty Ltd. It said that the cost of hiring a 707 aircraft would be approximately $6,000 an hour. That was 12 months ago. This year the Estimates Committee was told that the agreed rate of charge for hiring the 707 for VIP purposes was $3,633 an hour. That was an increase of $900 an hour on last year. What I and the Committee members want to know is how this sum is calculated. If the calculations that I put forward in 1980 are correct-nobody said they were not correct-then this year's operating cost should at least be $5,000 an hour. As I said, if it was costing $4,600 an hour to run the United States presidential jet over 18 months ago perhaps the figure of $5,000 an hour is closer to the mark and not the figure that the Department of Defence gave of $3,633.

In this item an amount of $216,000 was given for the cost of overseas training. An amount of $66,000 was for simulator training and $150,000 for travel expenses. When we made an examination of these figures we found that crews for the 707s have to go to Hong Kong to train. The reason they go to Hong Kong is that there are no 707 simulators in Australia. When we asked why, it became fairly obvious that as Qantas Airways Ltd does not fly 707s any longer it does not need a simulator in Australia. I think that Air Nuigini is the only commercial firm that flies a 707 into Australia even though some charter operators come in. Therefore, if our crews have to do their regular training they go to Hong Kong at a cost of $216,000 per annum. When the pilots are fully trained to fly the VIPs we have a catch-22 situation because then they are entitled to fly a commercial 707 aircraft. Therefore we can lose the crews to commercial airlines around the world which still fly 707s. There are quite a number of such airlines in Africa, South America, the Middle East and on the Indian subcontinent. It is interesting to note that in fact one of the full crews of a 707 has gone already.

I think we should question the need for having these planes in the VIP fleet. Last year the cost of running the 707s alone amounted to $9,408,000. I am not querying the need to have a VIP fleet, but surely, if the Deputy Prime Minister, Mr Anthony, can go from Australia and tour the countries of the Middle East in a BAC111-a smaller plane-the larger 707s are not needed.

Another situation which ought to be looked at relates to the number of emerging smaller nations of the South Pacific which are of crucial interest to Australia at the moment. The South Pacific is one of the areas where the use of a VIP aircraft is, in my opinion, justified due to the very poor commercial air links throughout the area. We are faced with the situation where a 707 is too large to land at the majority of the airports in these countries and a smaller aeroplane would be much more suitable. Australia is pouring a lot of aid into Vanuatu but the largest aeroplane Vanuatu can take at the moment is the DC9. Vanuatu wants 727s to fly there. Air Vanuatu flights from Australia are booked out completely at the moment. The larger planes cannot land there as the runway is not long enough. Some of the smaller executive-type jets would be much more practical and economical. After all, as I pointed out, if it is too expensive for the President of the United States to use a Boeing 707 it surely should be too expensive for the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) of Australia to keep two of them operating at a cost of over $9m a year.

It will probably be said that some of the leaders attending the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting in Melbourne arrived in their own private 707s or DC8s: Nigeria and Canada are two of the countries that come to mind. However, the vast number of leaders of countries who came to CHOGM, including more populous, wealthier and important countries than Australia, arrived in chartered aircraft from their own national airlines. The Estimates over the last three or four years show that we are still spending in excess of $1m per annum in chartering aircraft from Qantas Airways Ltd. If there are occasions when the smaller aircraft, such as the BAC111 that Senator Townley referred to, are not suitable then I believe a case can be made out for charter arrangements to be made from either Trans Australia Airlines, Ansett Airlines of Australia or Qantas. After all, it was Prime Minister Fraser who in 1976 said:
On my own visits overseas, commercial aircraft will be used as far as possible; the argument that Qantas cannot provide adequate security is a specious argument and false.

These aircraft are out of date, old fashioned and gas guzzlers. They are being pensioned off by all of the commercial airlines of the world but are costing the Australian taxpayer $9.408m per annum just for the prestige purposes of this Prime Minister. Of course the Australian Labor Party, when it comes to power after the next election, will sell them.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I call any other honourable senators I make it quite clear that while Senator Sibraa debated matters relating only to defence, it is still my intention to have the three departments grouped together for honourable senators who wish to debate all three items. All of these three departments-Defence, Foreign Affairs, and Immigration and Ethnic Affairs-are being taken together.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank you, Madam Temporary Chairman. I, as Chairman of Estimates Committee D, which has reviewed the estimates for the departments of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, Foreign Affairs and Defence-which also includes the Australian Development Assistance Bureau-would briefly wish to touch upon the report of the Committee. I take the opportunity, too, of thanking the officers of the Senate who assisted the Committee. They worked most diligently and over very long hours. The work they did was very good. At the same time I would like to see that the work of committees is kept going with some continuity so that there is no lapse between the various phases of the hearings. This applies particularly to Estimates Committee D.

SPEECH.PARA: I refer to the presentation of information in the report. I would like it to be noted that often the costs associated with a particular program are spread over a number of items within one department or over a number of departments. Where this occurs, it would assist Estimates committees if the explanatory notes of the department involved, or of the major department if several departments are involved, were to include a compilation or consolidation of all the costs related to that program. As it is now, it is very costly in terms of the time it takes to gather the facts from all the departments so as to bring about a true picture of the situation. I think this has been touched on before today. I suggest this could be done with some liaison between the departments or at least the committee secretaries.

I now refer to civil defence which also is dealt with in the Committee's report on the estimates for the Department of Defence. The Committee considers that it might be timely for a Senate committee to examine Australia's civil defence preparedness in the event of a nuclear attack. Evidence presented to the Committee indicated that the planning for such an eventuality at the national level was inadequate. The Committee has not made a specific recommendation but it notes that a proposal to establish a select committee to inquire into all aspects of the civil defence program against nuclear attack is currently on the Notice Paper as General Business, Order of the Day No. 143. I do not believe it would be feasible at the moment to have a select committee look into this aspect of the work of the Natural Disasters Organisation because at the moment the Senate is very much overloaded with committee inquiries. In view of the present number of select committees I do not think it is feasible for the Senate to be able to staff any more of them. At the same time I believe that honourable senators are already almost overburdened in their duties in respect of the various committees presently operating. Nevertheless, I believe that as soon as possible consideration could be given to a reference to the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence.

I do not wish to be an alarmist on this aspect that the Committee has referred to but it is noted that on the evidence regarding the Natural Disasters Organisation it appears that not one person out of the 61 people employed in the Organisation was employed specifically to plan for defence against nuclear attack. I do not think we need to be alarmed but we should be realists. These days sufficient planning should be taking place to ensure that at some time in the future there will be a preparedness for nuclear attack. It may be that the Natural Disasters Organisation has taken some action. All I can say is that from the evidence that was presented to the Committee such action is not apparent. It would appear that in the interests of the country there should be an inquiry into this aspect to see just what is the situation in regard to the Natural Disasters Organisation. The name of the Natural Disasters Organisation implies that it is more concerned with natural disasters such as cyclone Tracy, an aeroplane crash or a train derailment which may involve a considerable loss of life. It seems rather odd that we speak of civil defence and preparedness for a nuclear attack being the responsiblity of the Natural Disasters Organisation. Nevertheless, I do not think very many other authorities would be responsible to oversee operations following the various disasters that could occur in Australia. I would not like to see any procrastination on this subject. So I suggest that in time further evidence should be taken from the Natural Disasters Organisation to ascertain whether it is up to date and is sufficiently prepared to cope with a nuclear attack or a disaster.

Another point I wish to raise relates to late answers provided to Senate Estimates Committee D. The Committee has expressed concern at a trend towards increasing reliance by departments on written answers being supplied subsequent to Estimate committee hearings, thus in practice avoiding follow up questions because of the short time left before the committees are required to report. The situation is made worse if such answers arrive late. The Committee urges that where a department undertakes to provide written answers it should do so promptly. Perhaps for some reason or other which escapes the Committee there has been time restriction on the departments after the hearings. I think it should be noted that late answers appear to be getting more common. I suggest that the departments improve their performance and liaison in this respect.

I do not want to take up too much time of the Committee but one other point to which I want to refer is that relating to the use and costs of the Boeing 707s. This matter has come up over the years, particularly at the hearings of the various Estimates committees. As Chairman of Estimates Committee D, I asked a question of the Department of Defence in regard to the use of the VIP Boeing 707s. The reply has been received by the Committee and has been incorporated in Hansard. I refer people who are interested in the number of hours that those 707s are used to that evidence. In 1978-79 the hours flown by the Boeing 707 aircraft were: VIP use, nil; national commitment, 33 hours; defence tasks, nine hours; training, 367 hours and squadron support, five hours. The hours flown in 1978-79 totalled 414 hours. Hours flown in 1979-80 were: VIP use, 429 hours; national commitment, 55 hours; defence tasks, 555 hours; training, 245 hours; squadron support, 12 hours-and total hours flown, 1,296. Hours flown in 1980-81 were: VIP purposes, 142 hours; national commitment, 34 hours; defence tasks, 844 hours; training, 544 hours; squadron support, 24 hours-total hours flown, 1,588.

Total hours flown for the specific purposes previously mentioned for the period 1978-79 to 1980-81 were: VIP purposes, 571 hours, which amounted to 17.3 per cent of the time; national commitment, 122 hours or 3.7 per cent; defence tasks, 1,408 hours or 42.7 per cent; training, 1,156 hours or 35.1 per cent; and squadron support, 41 hours or 1.2 per cent-totalling 100 per cent. It is interesting to note too that in the figures for the national commitment tasks that in the period June to December 1979 there were five refugee flights totalling 88 hours. These flights were, of course, the flights that brought refugees from South East Asia to Australia. There was one flight, Singapore to Melbourne, one flight Singapore to Sydney, one flight Singapore to Brisbane and Sydney, one flight Jakarta to Sydney and one flight Hong Kong to Melbourne and Sydney. In January 1981 there was one task of a flight of 34 hours for the purpose of taking Australian teachers to Zimbabwe.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is that document from which you are quoting?

—This is evidence that was given to Estimates Committee D as to the flying hours. This information has been incorporated. As there has been so much talk about the Boeing 707s I merely indicate that the hours used for VIP flights are a very small percentage when compared with the overall use of the aircraft.

SPEECH.PARA: Finally, I refer to evidence that has been given in regard to surveillance services in Australia. This is an indication of how questions can be spread over the broad face of Estimates committees. The responsibility for coastal surveillance is shared by the Department of Primary Industry, the Department of Business and Consumer Affairs, the Department of Defence, the Department of Health, the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, the Department of Administrative Services, the Department of Finance, the Australian Federal Police, et cetera. I believe that the matter of surveillance is now under review, and it is very difficult to get a comprehensive picture of what surveillance is all about in the northern part of Australia.

I hope that the review that is taking place in regard to surveillance will bring about a situation where one department is in charge of surveillance in Australia. There is not sufficient responsibility accepted within any one department as so many departments share the responsibility. One can well imagine, knowing the amount of surveillance that has to be undertaken on the northern coast, that perhaps the Department of Defence should have that responsibility. At the moment-perhaps for very good reasons-it is the responsibility of the Department of Transport. However, I make the point that as the surveillance area comes under Estimates Committee D, I look forward to the result of the review of northern surveillance being made public and tabled in the Senate for discussion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to pursue the matter that was raised by my colleague Senator Sibraa and to quote from the VIP manifest from the Department of Defence which is tabled periodically in this Parliament. Earlier today one of the Government senators, Senator Townley, acquainted us with the fact that it costs $1,700 an hour to operate a BAC111, and he asked why BAC111s are used so much. Of course, I concur with his view that smaller aircraft could be used. If honourable senators look at page 91 of the manifest, the Schedule of Special Flights by the Royal Australian Air Force for the period 1 January 1981 to 30 June 1981, I shall deal with the flight I mentioned when we were debating the estimates for the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet. If we look at the flight that landed at Armidale we see that the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) used a BAC111 from 20 May to 22 May to fly from Canberra to Armidale, Amberley, Townsville and Essendon, and then back to Canberra. I notice that there were only five passengers on that BAC111 flight from Canberra to Armidale. What Senator Townley had to say has a lot of substance. Why did the Prime Minister need a BAC111 aircraft for five people-himself, Constable Taplin, Miss Murray, Inspector Howard and Dr Rosalky-to go to Armidale? That fact is borne out in this document.

SPEECH.PARA: There is a long history to the tabling of this VIP manifest. Long before I became a member of this Parliament there was quite a row in the Senate in connection with this matter. A person by the name of Senator Gorton first tabled this manifest, after a lot of persuasion from the then Opposition, because people wanted to know who was using VIP aircraft. Of course, this document is a little lacking in the information which ought to be provided. Now that we know that it costs $1,700 an hour to fly a BAC111, I suggest to the Department of Defence that in future, when this document is tabled and we get a list of the VIP flights, we be told for how many hours aircraft were engaged in particular flights. Alongside the passenger manifest, we ought to be told what it cost per hour to run those flights and for what purpose the aircraft were used, whether they be BAC111s or Mysteres. I know that some VIP aircraft are used to transport Senate standing committees around the country, and perhaps Senate select committees although I am not aware of that. That should be shown in these manifests.

The other suggestion I wish to make, and I have raised this matter before on many occasions, is that it is very difficult when senators are discussing matters in Estimates committees or during the debate on the Appropriation Bills, to single out the actual cost to the taxpayer for any particular department. In the appropriations for the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, which we dealt with a short while ago, certain costs are shown. But, buried in the appropriations for the Department of Defence is another set of costs for the same purpose, that is, flying Ministers and the Prime Minister. I have suggested before-and I suggest again-that all these costs ought to be accumulated and put before the Parliament in one paper so that we can ascertain what it costs a year for the Prime Minister, his Ministers and members of standing committees of the Senate and joint parliamentary committees to fly around this country or overseas so we are not running from one Estimates committee to another trying to define the actual cost to the taxpayer for running VIP aircraft and related costs which are charged against various departments. All these costs are split up. This is a fancy way of doing it if one wants to hide these facts from the taxpayer. It is time that something was done about the practice. If I am here when there is a change of government one of the matters that I will advocate very strongly is that those figures be put before taxpayers. The figures should not be hidden. Taxpayers ought to know what the costs are.

Recently some figures were given in answer to a question on notice asked by the shadow Minister for Transport about what it cost to ferry members of parliament around Canberra. In answer to a further question by me, the dissection of that cost revealed that it was not members of parliament who were running up the enormous amount of money; it was public servants. Yet newspaper articles said: 'This is what it is costing you to transport members of parliament around the ACT'. That was a blanket answer. We had to go to the trouble as some departments had to go to the trouble to dissect the figures so that we knew the actual cost to the various departments and the categories of people who are using those facilities. I put that point to this Committee and the Minister. I hope that it is taken on board so that when the next VIP manifest is tabled in this Parliament, included will be another column showing the number of hours that an aircraft was engaged on a particular duty which is listed here and what the actual cost was to the taxpayer. I think we then might be able to get through these Appropriation Bills in this Parliament much quicker. We have to go through this exercise at least twice a year. I have seen Senator Carrick just about at his wit's end because he would not or could not provide answers. However, there is a different atmosphere in this Parliament now; the numbers are different. Fortunately we are getting some answers because the Government knows that it must deliver them. If the Government provided us with this information, it would get through its business much quicker.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to take this opportunity to thank Mr J. C. Ingram, the Director of the Australian Development Assistance Bureau, for coming before Senate Estimates Committee D. Mr Ingram's presence, as head of this important government instrumentality responsible for distributing overseas assistance, added a new and higher dimension of interest to the debate. The changes which were imposed on the Bureau were not easy for Mr Ingram to administer but he carried out his duties capably and his attitude to change generated respect from all Committee members. I thank this dignified, informed and humane servant for sharing perhaps the interest and humility of personally presenting himself before the Parliament. I hope that his example will be followed by other departmental heads.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sibraa Sen K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am indebted to Senator Kilgariff for the figures that he read into the record this afternoon. They really proved the point of the extravagance of the Boeing 707s. He pointed out the tremendous amount of time that was spent, at over $3,000 an hour, in training crews and flying these planes. I make one point very clear. If we did not have them, there would not be that cost. If aircraft are needed occasionally to fly refugees to Australia, we should hire from Qantas Airways Ltd the most efficient plane for the job. I refer to the Boeing 747s which have been used in the past.

SPEECH.PARA: I take up one other point. I support Senator Kilgariff, the Chairman of Senate Estimates D, who spoke on coastal surveillance and said that this matter should be under the control of the Department of Defence. Unfortunately, when I asked questions on this matter no officers from the Department of Defence were able to give me the answers that I wanted. They said that I should see the Department of Transport. As Senator Kilgariff pointed out, a number of departments share responsibility for coastal surveillance. It is rather ludicrous when one looks at the number of them-the Department of Primary Industry, the Department of Business and Consumer Affairs, the Department of Defence, the Department of Health, the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, the Department of Administrative Services and the Australian Federal Police.

One of the issues that concerned me in this whole matter of coastal surveillance was whether civilians who seek work with these civilian firms, the private air charter firms which operate coastal surveillance, were subject to government security checks or government screening in any way. I think the answer to that question is no. The other thing which worried me was whether it would be possible for a person with connections with drug traffickers to be employed by these private firms. I believe that the answer to that question is yes. I think it would be much better if the Department of Defence were to carry out our coastal surveillance, then all of the personnel would have to undergo some government screening or check on their past.

When the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence was in Darwin about last Easter an Indonesian fishing boat was located inside the legal limit. We had a rather ludicrous situation in that the Navy, for a number of reasons, was not able to reach the boat. The Northern Territory Police were the first people who were able to reach the fishing boat. No helicopter was available because the helicopter that is used on this work belongs to a private company and was undergoing repairs at the time. When one looks at incidents like that, it only proves that the Department of Defence or some sort of coastguard should be doing this work and not private operators.

There is one other item in the Department of Defence appropriations that I should mention and which I did raise with the Department of Defence officers. It concerns Australian servicemen who are serving in joint United States of America facilities in Australia. I was concerned, when the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence visited these joint bases, to see that the American servicemen at Woomera and, to some extent, at North West Cape received better housing than the Australian servicemen. Specifically, most, if not all, houses occupied by the United States servicemen are air-conditioned, wheras homes occupied by Australians have only evaporators. At Woomera there are approximately 100 homes which were owned by the United States and which were handed over by the United States Air Force when the National Aeronautics and Space Administration's firings were completed by the mid-1970s. Those houses are still under the control of the United States Air Force. They are better equipped than those occupied by the Australians. I think it is wrong that Australians serving in Australia with United States servicemen at joint facilities have conditions which are much worse than those of United States servicemen.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to make one observation at this moment with regard to cost benefit analyses. I find that every government department has bought some computer, but not one government department can give a cost benefit analysis relating to the purchase of that computer. I asked questions last year of each of the departments which came before the Estimates committee. I did the same this year and I find that none of those departments has looked into a cost benefit analysis of the purchase of computers. It seems to me that it would be normal for a government department to do a cost benefit analysis before it purchased such expensive equipment. I ask the Minister for Finance (Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle) whether the Government has ever made any attempt to see that the departments undertake a cost benefit analysis before they purchase expensive computers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want briefly to thank honourable senators for the comments and suggestions that they have made with regard to the Department of Defence and for the comment made by Senator Watson with regard to the officer from the Australian Development Assistance Bureau. The comments have been noted and the information that was given as supplementary information to the Senate Estimates committees, including that given by Senator Kilgariff relating to the matter raised by Senator Sibraa, a breakdown of flying hours, will now go on the record as additional information. Briefly, we can say that the flying hour rate is based on an assessment of aircraft flying costs such as fuel, oil, tyres, spares and contractor servicing. On the basis that the aircraft have a defence role, the rate excludes amortisation, interest on capital facilities, pay and allowances for crews and other squadron personnel and base squadron and other Royal Australian Air Force formation support. Perhaps the more general comment that could be made on the matter of the costing of the agreed rate for the special purpose flights of the Boeings is that it follows the established formula for the 34th squadron which stems from the statement to the Parliament in 1967 by the then Prime Minister, Mr Holt, indicating that special purpose flights would be costed on an extra cost basis. That rate excludes the charges of a capital nature-the sorts of things that I mentioned-and RAAF manpower salaries. I think the interest in this matter has been noted. The suggestions of Senator McLaren have been noted and will be drawn to the attention of the Minister concerned.

SPEECH.PARA: One matter that was raised at the beginning with regard to late answers, I think, is something which we would want to note. I make the comment that I think an improved resource has been given to the Senate Estimates committee by every department. This has stimulated a lively interest in the Appropriation Bills which are twice a year before the Parliament for discussion. As a general rule departments ensure that a wide cross-section of advisers is available at the Estimates committee hearings with a view to answering as many questions as possible. I think it is fair to say that the departments prefer to minimise the follow-up work that they have to do. They try to provide a very frank exchange of information at the time of the hearings of the Senate Estimates committees. The need of the committees for information to be provided promptly is appreciated. The Department of Finance will make special reference to this matter when making contact with departments prior to the next round of the Senate Estimates committee hearings. Emphasis will be placed on the need to provide supplementary information before the conclusion of a committee's hearings, if that is possible. The interest of the Senate has been a very salutary lesson to many departments in the preparation of their estimates, and, indeed, in the preparation of a great deal of their work and things of that kind. There is support for what has been suggested with regard to the provision of that information. I believe it has been a very helpful process.

One other matter that was mentioned by Senator Kilgariff and referred to also by Senator Sibraa related, I think, to civil defence. That matter is noted also. The comments are useful ones. I think that proper attention and consideration can be given to them. Senator McIntosh raised again the matter of a cost benefit analysis for computers. Without going through the whole procedure of the purchase of a computer I can say only that there is a very involved procedure throughout Public Service Departments before the purchase of a computer is undertaken. Consideration could be given at the time of the hearings of Estimates committees to whether any further cost benefit analysis could be given. In many instances, of course, computers have become the essence of public administration. I can say only that their purchase, the contractual arrangements for them and the tendering procedures applied to them are under very close surveillance throughout the Public Service. If we can provide any further information of interest I will see that that is given. With those comments I commend the estimates for this group of departments. I understand that Senator Mulvihill wishes to raise a matter on immigration.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mulvihill Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want any misconceptions to arise. I deliberately refrained from speaking because this is a topic I did not want to gate-crash. I will be dealing with defence. First of all, I want to supplement Senator Kilgariff's remarks as to the functions of Estimates committees and the effect of the backup staff that we had during the committees hearings. I give advance warning also that a motion has been circulated in my name. I will be seeking leave to move it at the end of our consideration of this group of departments. Of course it means only that we will give warning to the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs that when we deal with the Supplementary Estimates we will certainly want to scrutinise much closer than usual the effect of new changes in our migrant selection scheme. We will want also to look at our refugee policy.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn to defence. When Estimates Committee D met I used as a parallel recent disclosures by the British Admiralty on whether one or two of the decisions of World War II were right or wrong. Let me say at the outset that I am not one of those who on Sunday afternoon after a football club's performance assume the role of an expert in the light of hindsight. However, anyone who read the book by Michael Montgomery will agree that it raised a number of questions about the fate of HMAS Sydney which do not appear to have been satisfactorily answered. Following my two questions, the rather limited answers that I received, and certain statements made by the author in some Sydney newspapers, I sent him a copy of the relevant Hansard record. He replied on 3 November from his home in Middlesex, in the United Kingdom, and I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard his three-page letter, of which the Minister for Finance (Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle) has a copy.
Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-
SUNRIDGESOUTH HILL AVENUEHARROW-ON-THE-HILLMIDDLESEX
01-422 62953 November 1981 Dear Senator Mulvihill,
Many thanks for your kind letter of October 20th and enclosure.

I note that the Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence's reply to you covered only questions relating to the Sydney's actual conduct of the action itself, whereas the more serious and pertinent questions arising from my examination of the evidence all concern the Navy's handling of the episode as a whole. These may be summarised as follows:

(1) It would have been impossible for the Kormoran to have surprised the Sydney as she did unless she had opened fire (with an under-water torpedo) while still flying a neutral flag. This would have been in direct contravention of International Law; were War Crimes charges on this count ever considered against Captain Detmers, and if so, why were they not pursued?

(2) The condition of the life-jackets and Carley floats recovered from the Sydney point very strongly to survivors from her having been shot in the water; why were no charges brought on this count, granted also the evidence that the Kormoran had twice previously fired on lifeboats in actions with the merchant ships British Union and Eurylochus?

(3) The Carley float recovered off Christmas Island was clearly stamped MADE IN AUSTRALIA and contained a body dressed in a RAN-issue boiler suit and shoes. No other RAN ship had lost a life in action in that area up to that time; why therefore did the Director of Naval Intelligence in 1948 issue a report denying that it had come from the Sydney?

(4) The Sydney had given her Expected Time of Arrival at Fremantle as 'PM November 20th'; why was no signal made to her to report until she was three days overdue, and that in spite of a Q ('Suspicious Ship') signal having been received at 5 p.m. on the 19th? (Vice-Admiral Sir Alan MacNicoll raised the same question in the Bulletin of August 25th).

(5) Why did the Naval Board not inform the Aquitania, which was following the same course three days behind, of the Sydney's absence? (The First Naval Member at the time, Vice-Admiral Sir Guy Royle, wrote that he considered that 'the Naval Board were grossly at fault' in this).

(6) At 10 a.m. on November 20th a party of civilians on Dirk Hartog Island reported seeing thick smoke burning out to sea; no ship was in that particular area at the time, and I conclude that it must have been caused by oil and wreckage from the Sydney and Kormoran still burning on the surface. Naval Intelligence, however, attributed it to the tug Uco, although her Deck Logbook shows that she was then 180 miles to the south; why? N.I. also gave a position for the Uco when she picked the signal on the 19th which was at least 80 miles west of any position shown in her Logbook; why?

(7) It is very surprising that no signals were apparently received from the Sydney either before or during the action. On examining the Master's Logbook of the lighthouse service ship Cape Otway, I found that the Official Log had been very obviously rewritten to end on November 18th-the day before the action-the next one not resuming until March 30th, 1942; did the original contain a record of signals recieived from the Sydney which were then suppressed? (There is also evidence that the Uco's Master Logbook was similarly doctored.)

(8) Why were the different boatloads of Kormoran survivors not kept segregated in view of a report from the Intelligence Officer concerned that the first of them to be interrogated were refusing to answer due to the influence of officers and others from another boat? (This was another question also raised by Vice-Admiral MacNicol.)

(9) Why did Naval Intelligence choose to adopt the account of the action eventually put together by the officers and to ignore the different evidence volunteered while the boats were still separated-in particular, the shorthand cryptograms drawn by Dr. List, the Kormoran's official war correspondent, which when deciphered made unambiguous reference to the involvement of the Japanese in the Sydney's sinking? (I produce evidence in the book that certain Naval Intelligence officers privately admitted the truth of the latter.)

As a non-Australian myself, I don't feel that I'm in a position to say whether these constitute sufficient grounds for opening an official enquiry. I would like to think, however, that they will lead to consideration being given to amending the account of the action in the official RAN History by which, as it stands at present, the lives of 645 of Australia's finest sons are made to seem to have been needlessly and ingloriously squandered. I would also like to suggest that the Navy exhume the body buried on Christmas Island and return it to an honoured place of burial in Australia; this would, I feel, be a particularly appropriate gesture in the fortieth anniversary year of the Sydney's loss.
I am deeply grateful for your interest in the matter, as I'm sure are all those others who lost relatives and friends in her.
Yours sincerely, Michael Montgomery

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Committee. I am motivated to seek further information from the Navy because the letter makes a number of assertions. One is that if Sydney was tricked, if I may put it in that way, by the German vessel concerned flying a neutral flag and firing a torpedo at the same time it would have rendered the master of that vessel liable to prosecution later for a war crime. The author refers also to the condition of certain life jackets, to a float bearing a body dressed in a Royal Australian Navy boiler suit and to evidence which raises the question whether personnel were machine gunned in the water. There is also the question of whether a log was tampered with, and other such matters. Hansard will contain the full text of the letter. I believe that, in view of the British precedent, the Navy could come up with more detailed answers to these questions. I hope that it will.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish also to refer to other matters which relate to the Department of Foreign Affairs and to the issuance of passports. As members of the Committee will know, I probed for answers from the officers of the Department concerning why we could not achieve better co-operation with the State Registrar General's officers so that one could block the loophole that now exists. Anyone who has read Day of the Jackal by Frederick Forsyth will recall the account of how one may check up on records of death and masquerade as one who is deceased, thus obtaining a passport under false pretences. In view of the manifestations that have become apparent about the extent of white collar crime I believe that we could do more to block that loophole. I raise the matter again because, although the response I received was rather negative, and doubts were expressed as to whether corrective action would be possible, individuals as far apart as David McNicoll, writing in the Bulletin and the authors of one or two of Canberra's newsletters, have hinted that something is happening in this field. Common politeness demands that if the Department is contemplating a reform which I have advocated I should be advised of it. My recollection of these matters went back to the occasion when a member of my own union, the Australian Railways Union, was blandly told, when he wanted to go abroad and sought a passport: 'Look, David Flynn, someone has already got a passport in your name'. It is not as though I have suddenly jumped on the bandwagon. I raised the matter several years ago. True, the real Mr Flynn got an apology from the then Minister for Foreign Affairs, Mr Peacock, but the matter has been crying out for reform. If reform is around the corner I would like to believe that a member of Estimates Committee D should have the same knowledge of it as perhaps columnist David McNicoll and some of the authors of Canberra newsletters. I will leave the matter there.

My other comment concerns immigration policy. I wonder whether decisions have yet been made in certain matters which have been raised. One is of a very delicate nature and involves a deportation order which was issued against a certain person who had gone to New Zealand from Britain, had grown up there as a teenager, had been convicted in Australia of an offence and had received a fairly lengthy sentence. A deportation order having been issued, the question was whether New Zealand would take him back. We continue to reciprocate action by New Zealand on these matters. Although we have imposed passport control across the Tasman, the size of the migrant component that crosses the Tasman from New Zealand does not cause us to tailor our total annual migrant intake from other countries. New Zealanders are still a privileged group. I am not suggesting that we should not maintain excellent trans-Tasman relations but I am curious as to whether New Zealand has decided to take back the person to whom I refer. Occasionally we read in the New Zealand newspapers of Australians having transgressed and magistrates having lectured them, saying: 'You will have to go back across the Tasman or you will be in trouble'. The situation should be even-handed. I hope that I will be able to get answers relating to those matters. Madam Temporary Chairman, I am in the hands of you and the Minister as to when I should seek to move the motion I have foreshadowed. Should I do so now or at a later stage?

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that Senator Evans and Senator Sibraa wish to make contributions. Perhaps, with the agreement of the Committee, they could raise their questions, which could then be answered by the Minister prior to your moving your motion.
—I yield to both of my illustrious colleagues.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As always I am indebted to my colleague Senator Mulvihill for his forbearance. I wish briefly to raise a matter to do with security in the issuing and dispatch of passports by mail, which is something of an old chestnut which, I think quite properly, rears its head on occasions such as this. Some further and better answers need to be provided. As I understand it, the Department of Foreign Affairs ceased sending passports by registered or certified mail during 1978 as part of what was described as an economy measure. The results of that economy measure do not seem always to have been entirely happy as is instanced by an example of the way in which passports now appear to be travelling through the mail which was drawn to my attention by Dr T. G. Corbett, a Melbourne patent attorney. He told me of the circumstances in which his wife had received a passport. Indeed, to prove the point he was making, he sent a photocopy-an extraordinarily evocative photocopy-of the condition of the envelope in which that passport arrived.

SPEECH.PARA: The passport was in an envelope which was not the subject of a certified or a registered mail procedure. It was a particularly flimsy looking envelope which arrived in a particularly crumpled condition. It was not gummed down at the back but had only a couple of rather wan pieces of sticky tape stuck to it which had long ago lost whatever adhesive capacity they might once have had. The envelope was open when it arrived in the mail and the fact that the passport arrived at all was clearly much greater testimony to the skills of Australia Post than to the sense of the Department of Foreign Affairs in sending the extraordinarily valuable document that a passport represents through the mail in that way. There is no doubt that with drug trafficking, immigration problems and other circumstances of which we are aware, that passports have a significant blackmarket value. One would have thought that the Department would introduce more intensive security measures to ensure that they do not go astray in this way and cannot simply be plucked from the post by any hand that happens to pass them by.

Dr Corbett wrote to the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Street) about this matter and was kind enough to send a copy of his letter to me. The Minister in his reply simply confesses the error and promises to do better by way of improving the quality of sticky tape in the future but makes no concessions at all on the question of certification or registration. He simply states that there have been very few instances of delay or loss due to the use of normal postal services. One would have thought that any instances would be too many instances in this area. I for one remain unsatisfied, I am afraid, by the Minister's answer. I am not suggesting that this is a breathtaking issue-very few of the issues with which we deal in these Estimates debates are of breathtaking or earth-shattering national significance-but it is a small matter which seems to be capable of remedy by, one would have thought, a not especially spectacular financial outlay. I would welcome from the Minister-not necessarily right now but at some later stage-some indication of just what dollar and cents cost savings to the Department are involved in no longer posting passports by certified or registered mail. Also, will the Minister be prepared to reconsider what seems to be a rather silly piece of cheapness on the part of the Department?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sibraa Sen K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make some remarks about the Department of Foreign Affairs. I was interested to find out that in the Department of Foreign Affairs estimates there was a grant to the Australia-Britain Society for $150,000. I have never heard of this organisation and this grant was to support its secretariat. I was told that the Society sees itself, as the report states 'as a rallying point for people wishing to preserve our family relationship with the people of Britain and the essential features of our British heritage'.

SPEECH.PARA: While the aims of the Society are quite commendable, I personally feel that such a society may be somewhat redundant and irrelevant these days especially when one looks at the priorities of the grants from the Department of Foreign Affairs. For example, the United Nations Association of Australia and the Australian Institute of International Affairs had their grants considerably reduced from last year. I think that would be wrong, but grants to the Australia-China Council, the Australia-Japan Foundation, and the Australia-New Zealand Foundation were the same or were slightly greater than those of the year before. I would not oppose that. When one sees $150,000 going to an Australia-Britain Society, I wonder whether we should have an Australia-Italian society or an Australia-Greece society. As I have said, I have never heard of the organisation, but in the Mercury from Tasmania yesterday there was an article entitled: 'Australia-Britain links live on'. It states:
The Australia-Britain Society is alive and well, according to the national director-general, Air Vice-Marshal W. E. Townsend.
Mr Townsend, based in Sydney, was in Hobart yesterday in an attempt to reactivate the Tasmanian branch of the society.
Mr Townsend, who spent 40 years with the Royal Australian Air Force, has been director-general of the society since June, 1981.
He said the society was set up in 1971, with the help of Sir Robert Menzies, to 'maintain the ties Australia has had with Britain for the past 200 years.'
Mr Townsend said the society had about 1,500 members in Australia, and a sister-society had been formed in England.

That is a grant of approximately $100 per head for every member in the Society. I reiterate the fact that I think perhaps it is something that we ought to look at in our priorities in the future. During the Estimates I asked one of the officers from the Department of Foreign Affairs whether his Department's travel section looks after the overseas bookings for the Australian Development Assistance Bureau staff. I was told that the Department of Foreign Affairs travel section would only handle the bookings if the travel was financed by the Department. Instead, travel arrangements are made by the management and foreign service division travel section of the Department of Foreign Affairs. I have long believed that it is ridiculous that each government department should have its own travel section rather than one central booking office operated by specially trained staff, yet I think it is even more ludicrous in this situation that we have within a department two sections handling travel arrangements. There was a very good article in the Traveltrade back in July which dealt with this matter. It spoke about Canberra being a fast growing tourist attraction. It mentioned the Australian War Memorial being second only to the Sydney Opera House as a drawcard for tourists and went on to talk about the Australian Capital Territory Tourist Bureau. The article stated:
If the Government were to divert its massive travel budget-domestic and international-through the Bureau it would probably make a profit on the operation with the commissions it would get.
Instead it prefers to allow every department to have its own travel section in which travel expertise is not necessarily the hallmark.
Later on it stated:
Meanwhile in Canberra, not only are individual departments doing their own thing but it is also costing the taxpayer dearly.
Concessionary fares often available are just not being utilised for Public Service travel.
Instead the Public Service Board and the Public Service unions engage in continuing wrangles including a 3-year epic on when first-class, business-class or economy should be made available.

I think that the idea of a central booking section for a number of departments ought to be looked at. Another matter that concerned me in the Department of Foreign Affairs estimates was I believe that the staff ceilings have detrimentally affected the security standards at our overseas posts. It is quite obvious that security is playing a much more important part in our missions abroad than it was 10 years ago. I was informed that the Department of Foreign Affairs is adequately coping with the security that is required overseas. However, it was admitted that staff ceilings were causing inconvenience. I hope the Government continues to bear that in mind. I do not think we can afford to cut costs when it means cutting back on the security of our staff or the people who work overseas on security.

A further issue that concerned me was the outcome of the razor gang's decision to remove the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation advisers to the London High Commission and the Washington Embassy. It seems to me to be a ridiculous situation that the Australian Government cannot afford to support those advisers when, apparently, it can afford to spend at least $3,633 an hour for the use of VIP aircraft by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser). The Committee noted in its report that the Government should take into account the potential benefits to Australian science and industrial research and development by posting those officers abroad rather than bearing the costs involved in flying in advisers. I urge the Government to reconsider its decision on that matter.

Another issue that came up in considering the estimates of the Department of Foreign Affairs-it has been raised by Senator Robertson and me in the past-was that of our having a consulate in Bali. I believe that the Government has at last decided to go ahead with the appointment of a permanent consul in Bali. In my opinion the decision has come years too late, but I am glad that at last it has been made. The situation in Bali is that officials of Qantas Airways Ltd have borne the brunt of the problems posed by any Australians who have had travel problems in Bali. Regardless of whether we like it-I know a number of Government senators do not like to see Qantas Airways being subsidised in any way-in the instance to which I refer our airline and our airline officers are seen, in fact, to be arms of the Department of Foreign Affairs and the Government. I believe a very good case can be made for a subsidy to be paid to Qantas Airways in those circumstances.

I turn now to the other department whose estimates were considered by Estimates Committee D-the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. Again, it was quite worrying to see the result of the razor gang cuts which placed severe pressure on staff in passport offices around Australia. Pressures were also placed on the processing of citizenship applications in our overseas missions, particularly in London and Washington. At the Estimates Committee hearings officers readily admitted that the processing of passport applications was way behind schedule. Many of the calls for assistance that I receive at my office directly relate to the inadequate staffing levels determined by the Government.

Constituents are contacting me because their citizenship applications are taking months and months to come through. Because of the long delay they sincerely believe that their applications must have been lost. The total process is now taking between six and nine months. I have heard that in New South Wales now 17,000 applications are waiting to be processed and that 5,000 applications in Sydney alone are waiting for a security clearance. If those figures are wrong I hope the Minister for Finance (Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle), through her advisers, will correct them for me. Consequently, prospective citizens are being given no encouragement to become Australian citizens. They are justifiably beginning to believe that perhaps the Government does not care whether they become citizens.

I have also received a number of calls from constituents whose relatives have applied to migrate to Australia and who have been waiting for many months to learn the outcome of their applications. This applies, in particular, to London. In a number of cases, even when there is no doubt that the relative will be permitted to migrate to Australia, the processing takes many months, mainly because of the staff shortages. As I said, this is particularly the case in England. It is quite wrong, I believe, that prospective migrants to Australia have to wait up to three or four months just to be granted their first interview with immigration officials in London.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise briefly a matter concerning immigration; in particular, the Telephone Interpreter Service. The service in Hobart is now switched to Melbourne, so that anybody who rings the Hobart number ends up speaking to somebody in Melbourne. That is a very unsatisfactory way of providing a telephone interpreter service because for a start, local knowledge is often very important. As I understand it, since that changeover occurred the number of people making contact with the Telephone Interpreter Service has been reduced, not just by 10 per cent, a quarter or anything like that, but by something like 85 per cent. There has been a reduction of 85 per cent in the number of people making contact with the Telephone Interpreter Service from Hobart. I would like to ascertain whether those figures are correct or are anywhere near correct. I ask in particular whether the calls which are received in Melbourne from Hobart can be identified as such and whether they are recorded as being Tasmanian calls and not calls from Victoria. I condemn the Government for the change which has occurred in that service. It was very useful to the ethnic communities in Hobart. The service was obviously valued. A reduction of that amount-even if it is not 85 per cent or anything like that-is an indication of the lack of service which is now being provided by the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —A number of matters have been raised. Some of them will need to be referred to the departments for information. Senator Sibraa made a suggestion with regard to a central booking section for travel. I will refer that to the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Street). A comment was made with regard to staffing. I have some information about the Department of Foreign Affairs. The Public Service Board has advised the following developments in relation to the matter raised by the Senate Estimates Committee in regard to staffing in the Department of Foreign Affairs. I advise that the Government has approved variations to the provisional ceilings in the light of Budget and other Government decisions. These variations included an increase of 25 in the staff ceiling of the Department of Foreign Affairs as at 30 June 1982 to handle the work load arising from the Government's decision to introduce passport control on trans-Tasman travel. The Department was advised on 28 September of that increase. A temporary allocation of an additional six staff has also been approved recently to assist the Department to establish a temporary passport processing unit in its central office. Over the next three months this unit will process applications which are redirected from the passport offices in the States. I have noted the comments and concern with regard to delays and security through the post of passports. I will draw those matters to the attention of the Minister.

SPEECH.PARA: A further question was raised-I think by Senator Sibraa-regarding scientific advisers. The Review of Commonwealth Functions recommendation on this matter provided that there be reduced staff levels at those posts but the reductions were not strictly related to scientific adviser positions in London and Washington. Several Ministers appealed against the Government's decision to reduce staff insofar as it affected their responsibilities. A case for the retention of the scientific adviser positions was made but, after ministerial consultation, it was decided not to change the original decision on this matter. Arrangements are being made within existing resources and through established channels to maintain a flow of science and technology information. This will build on the already extensive interchange between Australian and overseas scientists that is a feature of scientific relationships. Much of this interchange is Budget supported. I believe Senator Mulvihill raised a question with regard to deportation-if that is the correct word-to New Zealand. I advise that negotiations are being conducted with New Zealand concerning the person mentioned by Senator Mulvihill.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it was Glen Stone.

—That is the name which I have here. We do not yet know what the outcome of those discussions is. The Minister will inform Senator Mulvihill directly as soon as that outcome has been established. I have noted the incorporation of the letter that Senator Mulvihill received from Michael Montgomery. I am sure it will be of great interest to the Department of Defence. As soon as that has been studied I am sure that whatever further information can be provided will be forthcoming. I have further information with regard to staffing in the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. The Department agrees that there are delays in migrant processing in the United Kingdom. But it is a case of looking at the priorities and the resources that are under the Department's control. Reference was made to delays in citizenship processing. Some further information will need to be given as a result of what has been said today.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Coates referred to the Telephone Interpreter Service, which is basically a communication channel between information sources. I think we are all aware of the benefit that has resulted from that service. I have noted the honourable senator's particular query with regard to Hobart. I am not sure that I have information with me that I can give him but I will certainly see that he is advised of the magnitude of the calls that are made, and the analysis that he requested will be forthcoming as soon as I am able to make arrangements in that regard. Any further information that is required will be forwarded in due course.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to raise briefly one matter which concerns the vote for the Department of Foreign Affairs. I want to take this opportunity to place on record not only my appreciation but also the appreciation of many other members of parliament for the service that is rendered to us by the staff of Foreign Affairs, particularly when we make a request for some arrangements to assist us in respect of overseas visits. The Department will bend over backwards to help and make arrangements for members of parliament, particularly when we wish to visit certain places in the course of our official duties. I think this is the appropriate time to place our thanks on record.
—Hear, hear!

—I am pleased that Senator Missen agrees with me. I hope that when the staff of Foreign Affairs read what I have said, with the concurrence of Senator Missen, they will see that we appreciate the service that is rendered to us.

SPEECH.PARA: Quite often we rise in this Parliament to criticise the staff of departments for not doing the job we think they ought to do. However, every time I have sought the assistance of the staff of Foreign Affairs that assistance has been forthcoming at any hour of the day, and sometimes at any hour of the night.

TALK.START.PARA: —Both here and overseas.

—I think I have spoken about that before. I well remember that some years ago when I paid a visit to East Germany I could have been in some serious trouble had it not been for our post over there. Mr Morris, who I think was the High Commissioner, really helped me and other people as well. I take this opportunity to place on record the appreciation of members of parliament of the wonderful service that the staff of Foreign Affairs give to us.

SPEECH.PARA: Motion (by Senator Mulvihill)-by leave-agreed to:

That the Committee is of the opinion that the impact of the new Migrant Selection Scheme on Australia's migration intake, with particular reference to the country of origin of any refugee intake, should be monitored by the appropriate Estimates committee during its consideration of particulars of proposed expenditure for the remainder of the financial year 1981-82 and for the financial year 1982-83.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Robertson Sen E.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to deal with the shortage of staff in the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs both in Australia and overseas. To illustrate the point I want to make, I will take the case of an Australian national, a girl, who married an Irishman in New Zealand in February 1980. She then came to Australia. Later that year and certainly more than 12 months ago she made an application to the Department in Sydney for a change of status so that her spouse could become an Australian citizen. I have raised in this place before the fact that I believe this is totally unnecessary. I believe that if an Australian national marries overseas his or her spouse should become an Australian citizen automatically. If we did this we would overcome the problems we are having at present where an Australian national has to seek a change of status for the spouse. I will not press that point again.

SPEECH.PARA: I will not go into the full details of this case because the Department has them both in Sydney and in Darwin. Let me give a little of the background. I indicated that the couple made an application in Sydney over 12 months ago for a change of status. They then moved to Melbourne and some months ago moved to Darwin. As soon as they arrived in Darwin they contacted the local departmental office to seek some details about the change of status. Despite constant calls to that office, they got no action. So, six to eight weeks ago they came to me and I started to make contact with the Department in Darwin. The same story came back: 'It will be about two weeks'. I was in contact with the couple this afternoon. We are still waiting, 12 months after the application was made, for the job to be done. This is because either the Department is inefficient or it is short of staff. I think it is the latter, because I have had good contact with the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and the officers seem to me to be very efficient people.

Let me reinforce why I say that I think the reason for this delay is a shortage of staff. I rang the office in Darwin four or five weeks ago to see what was happening and an officer said to me: 'I have been in touch with Israel and with Ireland'-they are both involved in the application-'and I wrote to them some months ago'. I said: 'Will you contact them again because we need some information before this job can be done?' He said: 'I would not bother them again because they are so busy'. Then he went into some detail about how he personally had experience of working 14 hours a day and more and how the officers in the missions overseas did this sort of thing-worked 14 hours a day-quite often. He said that he would not want to bother them. I have visited a number of missions, particularly in the Asian area, and the same comment comes back to me-that the enthusiastic officer who is trying to keep up with the job, trying to get the job done, has to work far longer than his normal office hours in the day. I will not go into detail about why I think the offices in Darwin and the rest of Australia are understaffed. I have made that point before. It is as a result of the razor gang and other cuts.

In the evidence given to the Estimates Committee there was an indication that there is no shortage of staff and that everything is flowing along. I ask the Minister for Finance (Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle) why there would possibly be this sort of delay. When I told an officer that it was over 12 months since the application had been made, he said: 'That is all right. It is usually six to eight months before this sort of application can be processed'. What a load of nonsense! The comment was made that they needed information from Israel and that this would take a lot of time. The person concerned wrote to Israel as a private citizen-not as an officer of the mission or the embassy, but with no contacts there-and in less than three months received back from the Israeli police force a clearance of character, which was apparently the information that was needed.

Obviously there are holdups and I can attribute these holdups only to a shortage of staff. If this process takes six to eight months, that is a short time. It is taking 12 months to process a fairly straightforward case of an Irishman who spent some time in Israel, married in New Zealand, and spent the last 15 to 18 months in Australia. Surely that is not a difficult case to sort out. I ask the Minister whether she would comment on this shortage of staff both in Australia and overseas.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mulvihill Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable senators will know that I have frequently put forward my quest to reach a more equitable employment society. There is a need to have a much tighter liaison between the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, to which we have just referred, the Department of Employment and Youth Affairs and the Department of Industrial Relations. With the rationalisation, restructuring, or whatever one likes to call it, of industry I sometimes wonder whether there is enough co-ordination. I preface my remarks with the tocsin I have sounded on many occasions; that until we have computerisation of our work force, as has been brought about by the Scandinavian governments, we will find a lot of looseness and that people simply miss out on adequate employment because there is not enough awareness of specific demands.

SPEECH.PARA: I will illustrate that by referring to an extract from Workers News. It deals with the fact that in Five Dock in the electorate of Lowe, for which I am the resident senator, near Christmas the Nestle Australia Ltd chocolate factory is to be taken over by Life Saver (Australasia) Ltd. To be quite fair about it I say that I have a copy of a letter sent by Nestles to the Labor Council of New South Wales in which was put forward a reasonable, or even favourable, severance pay system. In a lot of industries in Australia today the unions are able to negotiate an effective severance pay system which is all right for the man over 50 years of age. It may mean that he just manages to make the final payment on a home which he has been struggling to pay for a long while and matters like that. It is quite attractive for him. But nobody seems to know what happens to the people under 50 years of age, say, between 25 years and 50 years, who receive less severance pay and who still have a role to play in the Australian work force. I seek leave to have this article from Workers News dated 7 November 1981 incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The article read as follows-
TAKEOVER MOVE TO SHUT FACTORY
Three hundred families in the Five Dock area of Sydney's inner-western suburbs have been dealt a blow by the planned closure of the Nestles chocolate factory at Christmas.
The plant is being shut down following a takeover of Nestles' Australian operations by the Lifesaver company.
Three hundred and sixty jobs will be destroyed in the process adding to the growing list of sackings in the confectionery industry.
Over 200 jobs were axed at Rowntree-Hoadley when the Sydney operations were transferred to Melbourne and 60 jobs went when the same thing happened at Scanlen's.
At the Small's factory the workforce has been reduced from 80 to 26 following a takeover of the company, but output has been trebled with the introduction of new machinery.

Nestle's factory workers have accepted a redundancy agreement which gives them a lump sum of four weeks pay plus an additional three weeks pay for each year of service and loadings of up to 25 per cent on the gross amount depending on age.
Bob Biddle, the New South Wales secretary of the Confectioners Union, said it was one of the best agreements he had seen yet.
But he added: 'No matter how much money you get you still haven't got a job.'
Many of the workers are close to retiring age and some have worked at the factory for as long as 40 years.
They are disappointed about the decision.
'We're not happy because we're out of a job and it's hard to find a job when you get older,' said Vince Dileo.
'Perhaps I can find a casual job but no one wants to employ you.
'There are about 300 families in this area of Five Dock who will have to find another job.'
Nick Rexhap has worked in the adjoining Maggi factory for the last five years. It too is marked for closure within the next two years.
'It's bad I suppose, but you can't do anything about it,' he said.
'A lot of people here are in their sixties.
'People have worked here for 20 to 25 years or more.
'I think the company made plenty of money but now they don't want to work. They don't care about the people whether they work or not.
'It's bad for the people. The government shouldn't allow them to close down our jobs.'

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the article epitomises the matter I am raising. I am asking the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs (Mr N. A. Brown) to inquire into a situation in the central western suburbs of Sydney. When people become aware that one firm in an industry is to be taken over by another, what effective liaison and what function is performed by the Commonwealth Employment Service in the fitting in of the redundant workers? In the case in point the article states that 300 people are faced with dismissal. I spoke to Mr Biddle, the secretary of the confectioners union. It is true that some of the people will be retained by the new company and others will probably be slotted in to what I call the confectionery sector of the manufacturing industry.

SPEECH.PARA: We had a similar situation in the rubber industry. When Firestone Australia Pty Ltd vacated the area of tyre manufacture, I, along with Barney French, the secretary of the Federated Rubber and Allied Workers Union of Australia, paid tribute to the then Minister for Productivity, the Honourable Ian Macphee, for the role he played in helping many of those workers get alternative employment. In the case of the rubber workers it was all very nice to say to them: 'There is alternative work in Dunlop Australia Ltd across the border'. Even if a man of 42 years of age with a family of two, say from eight to about 14 years of age, living at Bankstown is offered free travel and the cost of the removal of his furniture to another State, he has to pull up roots from a suburb where he has been happy and contented and where his children have been happy in their school. This is the point I am making. In the era of Ian Macphee there was consultation with other ministries to see that these workers received adequate or, as far as possible, alternative employment. I say to the Minister for Finance (Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle) simply that I would be curious to know what role Neil Brown, the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs, is playing in these sorts of operations since Ian Macphee left the Department of Productivity. I am not taking a Luddite attitude. I know that there will be mergers and restructuring in industry. If that comes about and some sections receive good severance pay I want to know what happens to the people who have another 25 years to work. I am trying to find out just what effective liaison there is.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will ask the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs (Mr N. A. Brown) to communicate directly with Senator Mulvihill on this matter. I am sure that an active role is played in finding employment for those who are displaced through redundancy or mergers or takeovers of companies. If I were to allow Senator Mulvihill to have the same sort of communication with the Minister, as he obviously had with Mr Macphee when he was Minister, that may be a better way of dealing with the many questions that I think Senator Mulvihill has in mind.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mulvihill Sen J.A.
