SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-
15 October 1981
Mr T. North,
Organiser,
Labor Council of NSW,
10th Floor,
Labor Council Building,
377 Sussex Street,
Sydney 2000
Dear Sir,
This confirms our recent discussions regarding severance payments to employees affected by this Company's announcements on 21 August 1981.
1. Severance Payments
(a) The Company agrees to make a severance payment based on the following calculation:

(i) An employee who has been made redundant and remains with the Company until the scheduled closure date, or leaves at the specific direction of the Company, will receive a payment of four weeks pay.
(ii) An employee who has been made redundant and who has voluntarily left the Company's employment, or who leaves before the scheduled closure date, will receive a payment of two weeks pay.
(b) All such redundant employees will receive an additional payment at the rate of three weeks pay for each completed year of service, plus 3 weeks payment for part year of service.
2. Age Allowance-In addition to all payments, an 'age allowance' will be provided also, as follows:
(a) 45 years of age, to 49 years of age-an additional 10 per cent of gross payments under this scheme.
(b) 50 years of age, to 54 years of age-an additional 15 per cent of gross payments under this scheme.
(c) 55 years of age, to 59 years of age-an additional 20 per cent of gross payments under this scheme.
(d) 60 years of age, to 65 years of age-an additional 25 per cent of gross payments under this scheme.
3. Sick Leave-Payment of all unused sick leave entitlement.
4. Annual Leave Loading-Annual leave loading (17.5 per cent) to be paid on all accrued annual leave including pro rata leave.
5. Voluntary Leaving During Period of Notice-An employee may leave at any time during the period of notice and receive full benefits of this agreement.
6. Time Off for Interviews-The Company will provide the necessary time off, with pay, to allow employees to attend interviews for alternative employment.

7. Seniority-The Company agrees to the general principle of seniority and consultation, however, as explained during our discussions, we do not want to be tied down to the literal application of this principle in all cases.
8. Itemised Statement of All Wages Due-Redundant employees shall be given an itemised statement of all termination payments as early as possible prior to the actual date of termination.
9. Certificate of Service-The Company will supply a Certificate of Service to all retrenched employees.
10. Superannuation-Separate payments of Superannuation Scheme/Pension Fund entitlements will be provided under the rules.
11. Preference of Employment-All retrenched employees shall have preference of re-employment with the Company should positions become available.

12. Alternate Employment within Company-Where the Company offers a retrenched employee alternate employment in other units and this employment is accepted, the employee shall be entitled to all redundancy payments if that employee leaves within three months from the date of transfer. Employees have the option of accepting the alternate employment or the redundancy payments.

13. Transfer to Other Company Units-Where a redundant employee is offered, and accepts, alternate employment within the Company, the employee will receive compensation for expenses as provided by Company policy.

14. Long Service Leave-The Company will make Long Service Leave payments in accordance with the Long Service Leave Act, except that the Company will make pro rata payments to retrenched employees with three or more years of completed service.
15. Payments-All payments referred to will be based on the weekly 'shop rate' applying at the date of retrenchment.
16. Death of Employees-Should an employee die before the final date of termination, all benefits relating to this scheme shall be paid directly to his or her estate.
17. Gross Payments-The gross severance scheme payments must not amount to more than the sum the employee could have earned up to his/her normal retirement.
18. Operative Date-Severance payments detailed in this letter will be operative from 21 August 1981.
Yours faithfully,
NESTLE AUSTRALIA LTD
Personnel Department
Manager
P.S. We acknowledge your agreement that acceptance of this offer will result in the lifting of all present bans or limitations at Abbotsford, Sydney, and St Albans, Melbourne.

Addendum to our letter of 15 October 1981-Point 19: It is agreed that where we offer work through to 22 December 1981 the provisions of the Confectionery Award will apply to those leaving and that they will therefore receive three days statutory holiday.

There will be other jobs for them to do, so we will want these committee hearings to continue.

SPEECH.PARA: I mention one area that we referred to in paragraph (b) on page 2 of the report. That paragraph refers to the heading 'Incidental and Other Expenditure'. The background in this area of the Minister for Finance (Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle) is greater than mine. Perhaps she can elaborate on this matter. It certainly seems to me to be undesirable to have large amounts of money in this vote. In some departments it is a sort of grab bag for the items that they cannot slot in elsewhere. I take as one example freight and cartage. Some departments have a separate heading for freight and cartage; others have this collected in a grab bag of incidental and other expenditure. While I am not suggesting that we want to see uniformity in every set of explanatory notes that come before us I think that most of us sitting on the Committee would want the point made that it is inappropriate to have a large amount of money under one heading and for the department to say: 'Well, we have $150,000 or $200,000 which is just incidental or other expenditure'. One hesitates to use the expression 'slush fund' but certainly it is a grab bag sort of vote. I wonder whether the Minister might care to comment on whether it might be more appropriate for some of the large 'Incidental or Other Expenditure' votes to be broken down and included in other areas or to have set up separate votes, such as 'Freight and Cartage', which involve fairly large expenditures.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —As was observed by the Committee and pointed out by Senator Robertson, a separate item of appropriation is already provided for freight and cartage under the estimates for some departments. In most cases the amounts provided are significantly in excess of the amount that was highlighted by the Committee. Following the Government's decision on a Review of Commonwealth Functions recommendation, the Government currently is reviewing the appropriations with a view to reducing the number of items where this would result in no significant loss of control. Pending completion of that review it would not perhaps be appropriate to embrace a procedure that would result in an increased number of items.

SPEECH.PARA: The underlying rationale for this review is to provide departmental managers with a greater degree of flexibility to allocate funds to services having the highest priority. It is not envisaged that explanatory notes for Estimates committees, for instance, will be presented in any less detail. In fact, I think what has occurred with the Estimates committees is that a great deal of information is given and a lot of segregation of items occurs even within particular votes. However, in the meantime, recognising the needs of committees for adequate information on which to examine departmental appropriations, departments will be instructed to provide full details in explanatory notes of any continuing and substantial amounts, provision for which is included in the appropriation 'Incidental and Other Expenditure'. In other words, where that item appears there will be a breakdown of it and the Estimates Committee will have that information in the detail that I think it would require. As I said, my department is looking at perhaps providing fewer headings, not less control, so there is greater flexibility within departments. Perhaps the outcome of the review we are undertaking will be of interest at some future time to an Estimates committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

It is always of assistance for the committee members to compare items or to be informed of progress in matters that may have been reported on previously. The timing of the tabling of the Auditor-General's report is very much dependent upon the availability of the financial statements prepared by the Minister for Finance pursuant to section 50 of the Audit Act. The preparation of these statements is a lengthy and exacting task which receives the highest priority in the Department of Finance. That preparation is undertaken in close collaboration with the Auditor-General's staff and is subject to detailed checking throughout the preparation.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not think anything I am saying is underestimating the understanding that we have that the Auditor-General's report ought to be available. TALK.START.PARA: —I want to raise a couple of matters relating to the Department of Employment and Youth Affairs. Firstly, I give a very small illustration of the result of the Government's policy on the employment situation. The Government's sales tax measures have, of course, been widely criticised on all sorts of grounds. I just want to quote from a letter that a Tasmanian constituent received to show a further effect of that policy and how it can affect employment. I have deleted the name of the constituent concerned. The letter is signed by the Personnel Services Manager of a pet food manufacturing company. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: We would like to apologise for the time it has taken us to get back to you regarding your application for the position of Engineer.

One point I would like to make is that it is an amazing fact that the committee in Tasmania, for instance, has no women on it. It is purporting to be a committee on discrimination in employment but the committee there has not one woman on it. It is a totally male committee. I want to register a complaint in relation to a question I asked of Senator Messner on 29 October in his capacity as the Minister representing the Minister for Housing and Construction. I referred the Minister to the desperate situation of the building industry in Tasmania and the urgent need for whatever Commonwealth construction work there is there to get under way, particularly the new Federal law courts building in Hobart. I asked:

Is it a fact that the letting of tenders for the project is held up because the Government's conditions will not allow any site allowance which may be granted by the Arbitration and Conciliation Commission to be part of the rise and fall conditions of the contracts? Is it also a fact that none of the tenders is in accordance with that condition?

I urged the Government to change its mind about that condition and not to try to usurp any decisions of the Arbitration Commission which may grant site allowances in accordance with the law. I pointed out to the Minister that it is crazy economics to hold up for that sort of reason projects that were so urgently needed to be commenced, especially when costs are rising every day. The honourable member for Denison (Mr Hodgman) has been praising the Government long and loud for having gone ahead with this project, although it was initiated by the Labor Government. This Government is being very loud about this project in praise of itself, but because of its own policies it is holding it up. I was promised a reply by the night of the day I asked the question, 29 October. I got a note from Senator Messner's Private Secretary late that night which stated:

Senator Messner has asked me to let you know that, although we were not able to get a reply to your question without notice tonight, we are expecting an answer from the Department of Housing and Construction early tomorrow and we will phone your office in Tasmania as soon as it is available.

The Government should be making every effort to give it a boost by making a start on this project rather than holding it up. I would like an answer to the problem. I would like a start made on the letting of the contract and an explanation given as to why the promised answer was not provided.

Answer: There are two current Members of Parliament purchasing Government allocated houses in the ACT.
On the third page of the document there is a further question and answer. They state:
Question: Senator McLaren asked whether the interest rate has increased on houses that were sold by the Government--
The Department omitted in that part of the question to mention the two members of parliament. The question continued:
in the past and whether that interest has escalated in the same way as rent has escalated for people on low incomes.

Answer: There are still some current mortgages at 4.5 per cent, 4.75 per cent and at 6.25 per cent. These rates have not escalated because the mortgage documents in respect of these loans do not provide for the interest rate to be varied.

The list that I have in my filing system states that there are four persons paying these rates of interest of which three are still Ministers in this Government. In view of the fact that you, Mr Temporary Chairman, received the answer to your question that two current members of parliament are still purchasing government allocated houses, then almost certainly two of the three must be Ministers. One of the other persons who had a loan at 6 1/4 per cent is no longer in the Parliament. He got one of those jobs for the boys. I have the names of these people, but at this stage I will not reveal them. I ask the Minister: Do those two members of parliament have houses at this very low interest rate? My information is-I do not doubt it-that in the first case the purchase price of the house was $31,950 and there was a government loan for the mortgage of $30,352 at 6 1/4 per cent; in the second case the purchase price was $18,910 and there was a government loan for the mortgage of $17,964 at 4 3/4 per cent; and, in the final case, the purchase price was $17,500 and there was a government loan for the mortgage of $16,625 at 4 3/4 per cent. Each of those loans was over 45 years. Before I go any further, I want to know from the Minister whether, in any of those three cases, the two Ministers are referred to in the answer as the persons who have government loans at that low rate of interest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —This morning I referred to the adversative attitude of the Industries Assistance Commission whereby it is attempting to cut the heart out of manufacturing industry in Australia without having regard to the social or dislocative effects of its recommendations. It does this with blinkered vision towards lowering tariffs and eliminating quotas. This is all done without regard to what other countries use as measures to protect their industries. On the other hand, the Commission conveniently ignores a whole host of monopolistic positions which apply in the tertiary sector or even the public sector. According to the criteria which are used against manufacturing, some of these industries would be categorised as inefficient.

SPEECH.PARA: The recent interim report into the motor vehicle industry, I believe, is a typical example of what I refer to as cutting the very heart out of the manufacturing sector. If the Australian Government wishes us to have in Australia high technology capable of utilising a wide range of skilled people, a stable manufacturing sector is essential. I believe this objective will not come to fruition through assembling or importing completed units produced overseas. Too many Australians currently have the mistaken notion that we will have cheaper vehicles in Australia if we rely almost exclusively on imports. What a fallacy and how naive and disruptive that is for the Australian workforce! What these transnational companies, which operate from overseas, will do is send a sufficient number of vehicles at a price that the market will bear. The only possibility is that we will get cheaper cars in the very short term until the market is fully secured and the market share is fully secured.

How many honourable senators are aware of the effective upward revaluation of the Australian dollar in the last 12 months compared with currencies in many Western European countries? Anyone exporting, for example, sheepskins or apples to those countries would know of the losses and consequences of that effective revaluation. For example, there has been an effective 26 per cent revaluation against the United Kingdom currency, a 33 per cent revaluation in the case of France and a 36 per cent revaluation in respect of Germany. Have honourable senators noticed the prices of vehicles such as Peugeots and Mercedes-Benz which are imported from those countries come down by anywhere near those percentages? Of course not, and what a fallacy that argument is! Australia needs a capability to produce a complete motor vehicle-not necessarily a whole range of vehicles from a Mini right up to a Statesman Caprice. We must have this capacity for strategic and defence reasons if nothing else, apart from the important employment implications.

I will look at some of the strategic problems. Our sea lanes could be vulnerable in time of war and our maritime industry is punctured with disruption and dispute. I believe that the component manufacturers are very much at risk. It is important that there is no increase in export facilitation. I am aware of certain abuses that are currently employed and which extend far beyond the techniques of transfer pricing. I believe that lower prices will come about only by some constructive rationalisation which will result in the motor vehicle industry in Australia having the capability of producing reasonable batch sizes so that industries can produce with reasonable economies of scale. I believe that the Australian car manufacturing industry must be capably supported by an up-to-date component industry which is employing modern technology. I am concerned about the unremitting attitude from the Industries Assistance Commission. I ask that we have a bipartisan debate with a view to getting the charter of the IAC changed.
Debate interrupted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Siddons Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the comments that were made earlier in the day by Senator Gietzelt when he recommended that the terms of reference of the Industries Assistance Commission should be changed. I support that concept absolutely. I believe the time has come to change from a confrontationist approach, which the terms of reference of the IAC necessarily engender, to an approach of co-operation between government and industry. This can happen only if the terms of reference of the IAC are changed. At present industry has to face IAC references on the basis of justifying its existence. It is asked to present evidence to the IAC as to why it should be allowed to exist with the rates of protection which it enjoys. I contrast this with the approach in Japan, where there is co-operation between government and industry-not confrontation, but co-operation. Industry is a part of the economy of the Japanese Government and that Government looks to ways of co-operating with industry.

SPEECH.PARA: This could be done in Australia with a different approach. It starts, of course, with understanding clearly what our long term objectives are and understanding clearly what the markets are for various industries around the world. I suggest this could be done through the Department of Trade and Resources. It could very easily be asked to quantify the potential markets in various countries and then, in co-operation and discussion with industry and with other sectors of the community, work out a long term plan for the development of Australian industry.

To illustrate my point I draw the Senate's attention to the situation that occurred some years ago with an IAC report in relation to the steel industry in this country. Whatever the merits or demerits of various industries in this country, from brick making to steel making and textiles, one can hardly argue that we should not have a steel industry and we should not encourage a steel industry. We have some of the largest deposits of iron ore in this country. We have the best deposits of coal in this country. We should, in all circumstances, develop our steel industry. This concept appealed to the IAC. There was an inquiry into the steel industry. The IAC received evidence from the steel manufacturers and from other areas of the community and it then came out with a report. It said, in essence, that Australia should develop its export markets and that a very large percentage of the future investment of the steel industry in this country should be related to export industries. That is a concept which would appeal, I am sure, to many honourable senators on both sides of the chamber. But what happened? As soon as that report was brought down it was challenged by the management of Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd, the major producer in this country. In isolation, a government body advising the Government of this country had come up with a projection of the future possibilities for the export of Australian steel, which was in complete contradiction to the projections of the executives of BHP.

I contrast this to what happens in Japan, where the Government and industry get together to look at the long term projections. They discuss them; they work them out. Finally, they agree as to what the future of that particular industry could be. That is co-operation between industry and government. It is co-operation with the best expert advice available. They come up with a long term plan and, having agreed on it in a bipartisan way, they then say: 'All right, we will now co-operate. Government and industry will work together in the interests of this long term plan, which is in the interests of this country'. That approach has to win every time. It is winning in Japan. Let us look at the situation in Japan. It is a country with no resources. It imports its raw materials. It imports a large percentage of its food. Right now Japan is the major competitor with the United States of America in the automotive industry. It is the major competitor with the United States in the steel industry. Why? The Japanese Government, in co-operation with the steel and automotive industries, said: 'These are the areas we will encourage. These are the areas that are in the interests of our industry and in the interests of our Government'.

I conclude by saying that I agree absolutely with the proposition that was put forward earlier today by Senator Gietzelt: The terms of reference of the Industries Assistance Commission have to be changed in line with the principle of co-operation between government and industry rather than the principle of confrontation, which is the essential approach today in this area.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I call Senator Martyr, I point out that, the time being now 8.13 p.m., there is one minute precisely left for the debate on the presentation of papers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martyr Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Madam Acting Deputy President. What has been said so far is a demand for the continuation of the high levels of protection in this country. What is wrong with protection? A huge industry develops behind a high tariff wall. When such an industry does its costings the first calculation it makes concerns what the traffic will bear, and that is what it charges. It does not care what it produces. It does not care whether its goods are of poor quality. It has no real competition. It does not have to worry about price and quality because it believes the Government will protect it by stopping good quality, cheap goods coming into Australia. Essentially, that is an answer to what has been said by Senator Watson, Senator Siddons and others. I make the point that I am glad that the Industries Assistance Commission report has given a very clear indication that this sort of thing should not go on and that the Government should take very great cognisance of what is said in the report about the levels of protection being far too high.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a brief statement on the procedures of this place in relation to the consideration of reports.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it needs to be put on the record for urgent consideration, presumably by the Standing Orders Committee but I hope also by the managers of business in this place, that we have reached a bizarre situation when the Standing Orders are now to be applied in such a way as to deny the possibility of even the most cursory consideration of the other 10 reports that were introduced today and which are listed for debate, including the annual report of the Law Reform Commission, the documents on the Australian Dairy Corporation matter, the report on poverty measurement, the massive 500-page report on child welfare from the Law Reform Commission, as well as a number of other matters of lesser significance. It seems an absurd situation that not even the most cursory statement can be made, be it by the Opposition spokesman on a particular matter, or anyone else, on subjects of such significance. It seems absurd that reports of such importance will now go on the Notice Paper and not be capable of being debated in any way in this chamber for a considerable period of months-if at all-unless some special arrangement is made. It seems that the new Standing Orders that were introduced to deal with these reports--
—Why do you say that? Procedural matters are no longer in the Government's hands.
—Maybe so, Senator Chipp, but there is a sessional order--
—Any number of these matters can be revived, even tomorrow.
—May I point out that there is a sessional order which sets out the precise time allowed for debate on papers that are presented. That is the matter to which Senator Evans is addressing himself.

—Because I know that other arrangements have been made tonight, I do not seek to take advantage of the numerical power available to us as senators to move the suspension of that sessional order to permit further debate on these papers. I merely take the occasion to comment on what I think is the absurd situation with which we are confronted-of some 19 significant reports having been introduced today and an hour and a half having been allowed in which to debate them, with the procedures operating in such a way that it has not been possible for some very important items even to be reached. The order in which the reports are listed appears somewhat random. Presumably it represents the chronological order in which they appeared in the tabling office. It has nothing to do with their intrinsic significance or the desire of honourable senators to speak to them.

SPEECH.PARA: I will wind up my remarks by making just a couple of additional comments on this matter. It seems to me that the only way in which it would have been possible for this new sessional order to have made any sense was for there to be an assumption that there would be an average of only one speaker on each paper and that that speaker would address himself directly to it, saying what it was possible to say given the short notice that we have of these papers-stating what it was in effect urgently necessary to point out in relation to it-rather than using the occasion as a springboard for general chatter about matters raised incidentally or consequentially by the subject with which a particular report dealt. Perhaps the problem we have experienced today, more than the overall time limit, is the fact that honourable senators, for reasons that I can well understand, have taken the opportunity of the presentation of papers to speak-a number of them successively-on particular matters rather than observe the spirit of the new arrangement.

TALK.START.PARA: —The remedy is in the hands of honourable senators because they have changed the nature of the debate, haven't they?
—That may well be so and it is in that spirit that I am contributing to the debate tonight what I hope is in most of our minds, in such a way that it can be taken account of in the future.

SPEECH.PARA: Also, it seems fairly bizarre for this kind of sessional order to apply at this stage of the year when, as we all know, a very large number of reports do tend to be tabled by statutory authorities, departments and other bodies, simply because of the time of the year. A period of an hour and a half, which might be perfectly reasonable during most of the year to deal with the reports brought down in a given week, becomes manifestly unreasonable in the context of this stage of the calendar year.

I make those points not in order to seek to bring on a major procedural debate now-certainly not to move to change the order of business-but so that the matters which I have raised may be brought to the attention of the Standing Orders Committee. I do not know whether it is necessary to move to that effect. I certainly ask the Standing Orders Committee to take it on board. I also ask the managers of business in the various parts of this chamber to take account of the fact that at least three or four of the items which remain are of significance, and to see what might be done about adjusting the procedures of the Senate in order to provide some brief opportunity for a contribution to be made on them before the Parliament adjourns until next year.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The matter that has been raised by Senator Evans can, of course, be considered by the Standing Orders Committee which, as I understand it, unanimously proposed the procedure under which we are operating tonight. I wanted simply to put on the record the fact that the defects in that procedure, as it applies when a large number of reports are presented at a late stage of the session-when there is a great deal of other business before the Senate-impact on the Government as well as the Opposition, the Australian Democrats and the Independent senator. Several statements that I was to have put down I cannot now put on the record at the time when the relevant reports are being tabled. It is a matter of concern for the Government as well as for private members and Opposition spokesmen. I think that it is a difficult matter part of the solution to which, as Senator Baume interjected in the debate, involves self-control by honourable senators and some selection as to the items which are seen to have priority. That is always a difficult matter because nothing is more important to an individual than the issue that is burning in his bosom at the time. I am sure that the matter will now be drawn to the attention of the Standing Orders Committee and that the Committee will give us a further report on the procedures.

DEBATE.TITLE: QUEENSLAND ABORIGINALS AND TORRES STRAIT ISLANDERS (SELF-MANAGEMENT AND LAND RIGHTS) BILL 1981

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 24 September, on motion by Senator Ryan:
That the Bill be now read a second time.
Upon which Senator Missen had moved by way of amendment:
Leave out all words 'That', insert-
'(a) the Bill be deferred to enable the Queensland Government to advise the Senate and the Australian people of the specific proposals of that Government on-
(i) its announced intention to repeal the Aboriginal and Torres Islander Acts and to amend the Queensland Lands Act in order to abolish Aboriginal reserves in Queensland;

(ii) what consultative processes it has undertaken and completed to ascertain the desires of the Queensland Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders, who presently reside on reserve lands, for land rights and self-management of their own communities;

(iii) the alternative legislative and/or administrative steps it now proposes to take, in accordance with the expressed wishes of the local communities, to provide Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders with land rights or other effective security of tenure of lands now constituting the reserves and of other traditional lands to which they have proper claims;
(iv) what legislative and/or administrative steps it proposes to take to provide effective self-management for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities in Queensland; and
(v) the date or dates on which such legislative and/or administrative action will be completed, and

(b) if no such advice has been received by the Senate by 29 October 1981, the Bill be restored to the Notice Paper, and the second reading be an Order of the Day for the first sitting day after 29 October 1981, and that such Order of the Day take precedence of all other business on the Notice Paper for that day'

TALK.START.PARA: —When this Bill was last before the Senate on 16 September I spoke at some length about the Australian Democrats' attitude to it. I said that it had our wholehearted support. Since that time developments have taken place in relation to Queensland Aboriginal lands which I believe are heartening and have the support of honourable senators on both sides of this chamber. I believe that those moves are in part a response to previous debate in this chamber and to the work of the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Peter Baume) in this regard. I believe that the atmosphere in which the debate has taken place so far and the attempts by honourable senattors from all parties to see it successfully concluded must give heart to everybody in this country. We have shown that we may on these very contentious yet extremely important issues come to a resolution and a consensus without brawling in public. I believe that this is one area in which that situation is rapidly approaching. I hope that we will reach it in the very near future so that this matter can be resolved to the satisfaction not only of this Parliament and of the Queensland Parliament but also, and in particular, of the Aboriginal people in Queensland so that at last they may again be owners of their own land in their own country. I believe that this is what is desired and hoped for by all right-thinking Australians. We certainly commend this Bill to the Senate and give it our wholehearted support. We will vote for it at the second reading stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I have had two opportunities to contribute to the debate on the private members Bill that I introduced to give self-management and land rights to Queensland Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders. I do not propose to traverse the same ground again this evening. I have been able on a previous occasion to remind the Senate of the history of the violent usurpation of land from Queensland Aboriginals by the colonial invaders and of the sorry history since that time of Aboriginal Queenslanders, both those living on reserves and those living outside of reserves. I have set out in my Bill machinery which will allow Aboriginals and Islanders living on reserves to become properly self-managing and a way in which the Commonwealth can secure freehold title to reserve lands for the Aboriginal and Islander residents of those reserves.

SPEECH.PARA: In the course of the debate some Government senators raised some objections to some minor aspects of the legislation. In response to those objections I have pointed out that in consultation with the Australian Democrats who, as Senator Macklin has said, have been supporting us wholeheartedly on this issue, we have drafted a number of amendments which I believe meet any of the serious criticisms that have been made of some of the machinery aspects of the Bill. I understand that Senator Missen and Senator Bonner would also like to contribute amendments at the Committee stage. I look forward to studying their amendments in the spirit of co-operation which I am very happy to say has pervaded the Senate during the debate on this Bill. I think it is a matter of gratification that nobody in this Senate has actually opposed the concept of land rights for Queensland Aborigines. There has been opposition to some of the methods I have proposed, but, speaking certainly for my own party, for the Australian Democrats and I believe for Senator Bonner and Senator Missen, there has been no objection to the objective of land rights for Queensland Aborigines.

I will comment briefly on some developments which have been given coverage in the media in recent days. There have been references to new proposals which are about to be put forward by the Queensland Government to deal with the situation of Aboriginal reserves. Both the National Party in Queensland and the Queensland Liberal Party have announced new policies with regard to Aboriginal land in Queensland. I believe it is appropriate that I comment briefly on the proposals insofar as we have any details of them. As far as the National Party's new policy is concerned, there is really little to be said at this stage. All we have been told is that a new policy will be announced this weekend. However, we do note that the National Party is using the term 'perpetual title to land'. This is something which it is prepared to consider, which it has not yet defined and which, as far as we understand, will not meet our case for freehold title to Aboriginal land by Aboriginal owners.

As far as the Liberal Party of Queensland is concerned, a more detailed release has been made public in which the concept of a limited freehold is discussed. I am gratified to see the Liberal Party in Queensland using the concept of freehold at all. However, we do not know what form of limitation the Liberal Party intends by 'limited freehold'. Again we can greet this new announcement only very cautiously. There are some interesting aspects to the statement by the Liberal Party in Queensland, not least of which is the announcement that when arrangements for self-management and limited freehold are made the Department of Aboriginal and Islanders Advancement in Queensland, the Department which has become quite notorious amongst Aboriginals and Islanders in Queensland, will no longer need to exist.

I endorse the view of the Queensland Liberal Party in that respect, although not generally at this stage because, as I said, we do not know what arrangements in detail are contemplated by the Queensland Liberal Party. Suffice it to say at this stage then that we are pleased to see that there is a more active discussion of Queensland land rights among members of the National Party and the Queensland Liberal Party. As everybody in this chamber knows, there is a great difference between what political parties may announce as their policies and what governments are prepared to do. What we in the Labor Party are interested in at this stage is what governments are prepared to do. We have no reason to believe at this stage that the Government of Queensland is prepared to grant freehold title to Queensland Islander and Aboriginal inhabitants of reserves. Therefore, in our view, we must proceed with this Bill.

The purpose of this Bill is to state the principle of freehold title and of self-management and to lay down machinery whereby those principles may be implemented. So nothing that has been said on previous days makes it any less urgent that we proceed with this Bill this evening. No suggestions of proposals that have come forth negate the need for a statement from the Senate of Australia that freehold title must be granted to Queensland Aboriginals. Therefore, we will proceed with this Bill as it has been my intention to proceed since I first introduced it.

In conclusion, I remind the Senate that some 43 amendments to be moved at the Committee stage have been prepared by the Australian Labor Party and are available. More amendments may be brought forward and we will examine them in a spirit of co-operation. The important thing at this stage is to press on with this Bill, to press on with enacting the legislative principle, which we are entitled to do, which it is our Federal responsibility to do. Should it happen that the Queensland Government wants to provide for freehold title in the next few days we will re-examine our position and see whether it is necessary to proceed to the Committee stage. However, as I said at this stage it is clear that our commitment to freehold title is unqualified and unaffected by anything that has happened. I commend this Bill to the Senate.
