SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am grateful that the Minister for Finance (Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle) has agreed to table the document. Unfortunately, her doing so at this time may not give me an opportunity to look at it before we take a vote on this group. Earlier this evening I posed a question because of an answer that I received from the Department of the Capital Territory that two current members of parliament are purchasing government allocated houses in the Australian Capital Territory. The Minister asked me to put the question on notice. I was only interested in current members of parliament. I notice that the document is the same as the one I was provided with quite a number of years ago. I notice that the names of at least three of the people I mentioned tonight are shown on this document. As the answer I received in writing stated that there are only two current members of parliament involved, I sought to ascertain which members are still in receipt of these very low interest loans.

SPEECH.PARA: I am in a little difficulty in trying to peruse this document quickly, but I notice that the three members I named-Mr Anthony, Mr Nixon and Mr Sinclair-are shown on the document. The figures shown are exactly the same as the ones I quoted. The interest rates are the same. The document shows the dates that the loans were granted. That intrigues me because I was told during a meeting of the relevant Estimates committee that this low interest rate came about because of some fault with the mortgage documents. When I looked at my own document again during the suspension of the sitting I noticed that a mortgage was entered into on 17 December 1964 by Mr Anthony and that Mr Sinclair entered into one on 14 August 1966. There is a time span there of nearly two years. Four years later, Mr Nixon entered into a mortgage. That does not bear out the officer's statement that this occurred through a fault with the mortgage documents. If that is correct, that fault existed for some four years, although the Minister did say that some special provision applied to Ministers.

I want to know now which Ministers of that three mentioned are still recipients of those low interest rate mortgages. Is it Mr Sinclair, Mr Anthony or Mr Nixon? Apparently two of those three are recipients. Mr Gorton is no longer a member of parliament and Mr Bryant is no longer a member of parliament. Mr Morrison would have obtained his loan when he was with the Department of Foreign Affairs and not when he was a member of parliament. He obtained his loan in 1974. He might have been a member then, but that is not applicable. Mr Grassby had a loan, as did Mr Whan, Mr Negus and Mr Fry. Mr Fry, according to my earlier perusal, would have received his loan when he was working for the Government and not as a member of parliament. However, on looking at those documents again I find that only three of the people listed on the manifest to which I have referred are in fact Ministers and still members of parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about Morrison and Fry?

—The date of discharge of Mr Morrison's mortgage was 12 December 1974. I do not think he was a Minister then, although he might have been. However, he had the good grace to discharge his mortgage. As far as I can see there is no date of discharge in relation to Mr Anthony. The document I have here states that as at 1 October 1981 Mr Anthony still owes the Government $15,005.51 and he is getting that money at an interest rate of 4.75 per cent. As at 1 October this year Mr Nixon still had a mortgage of $28,404.14 and he receives that at an interest rate of 6.25 per cent. Mr Sinclair's mortgage was discharged on 6 August 1974. So the two people in question are Mr Anthony and Mr Nixon. Yet we find that young couples in this country today are having great difficulty in getting housing loans. They have to pay anything up to 15 or 20 per cent in interest rates. If they want bridging finance they have to pay a lot more to get a roof over their heads. We have a government which is prepared to let two Ministers on top salaries have money at the cost of the taxpayer. In one instance Mr Anthony still owes the Government $15,000 which he is getting at 4.75 per cent. Mr Nixon, who is in the news quite a lot lately, owes the Government $28,404 which he is getting at a rate of 6.25 per cent.
—Was that Mr Morrison, the ex-Labor Minister?

—I pointed out that Mr Morrison's mortgage which was being repaid at a rate of 4.75 per cent, was discharged seven years ago. For Senator Baume's information, he discharged his loan, which was taken out over 45 years, as soon as he became a Minister in the Whitlam Government. Mr Anthony and Mr Nixon have not seen fit to discharge their mortgages. No, they are hanging on to them at cheap rates of interest at the expense of young couples in this country and at a time when this Government is making less and less money available to the young people of Australia for home loans.

SPEECH.PARA: I think that the least I can say is that it is a damn disgrace. It is time the Government did something to stop paying out these perks to Ministers of the Government. This afternoon we had an exercise which involved the waste and misuse of taxpayers' money by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) who used a BAC 111 aircraft to go to Armidale to visit his son at a cost of $1,700 an hour. These are the types of people who are governing this country today. It is time something was done about it. I am very pleased to say that through continual agitation we have been able to expose these practices. I hope that young people who are listening to this debate tonight, some of whom have to sell their homes because they cannot keep up with mortgage repayments because of high interest rates on their loans, take cognisance of what has been said. I will be only too happy to let them have a copy of the document with which I have been provided tonight on an official basis. As I said, I had a copy of this document quite some time ago. However, this matter was swept under the carpet when I raised it in the Parliament some years ago. That is not now the case. The matter is out in the public arena and I think the people at large ought to take some action to do something about it.

I plead again with the Ministers who sit in the chamber tonight-there are three of them-to ask Cabinet or their ministerial colleagues at least to show some consideration for the young people of this country and pay off those mortgages. I think it is a disgrace that a man like Mr Nixon, who has all the perks of office at his fingertips, still owes the Government $28,404 which he is getting at the very low interest rate of 6.25 per cent. Why, we have returned soldiers in this country living on blocks of land for which they have to pay much higher interest rates for loans. They have to make a living off that land. I am not aware that Mr Nixon served his country in the armed forces. The Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner) who is in the chamber would know of the problems being faced by many ex-servicemen today because they cannot make enough on their farms to keep up the payment on high interest loans. As a result, a lot of them have had to leave their properties. I do not know whether Mr Anthony ever served in the armed forces. But these are people of privilege who are able to take advantage of low interest loans, made available to them by their colleagues. It is time that the three Ministers in the chamber tonight said something to them. It is time they asked them to repay those loans which they have had for such a long time.

I think I have said enough. The public is aware of what Ministers of this Government are doing. My colleague Senator Walsh and I have repeatedly sought to establish in this Parliament how many members of the Cabinet have money invested in income equalisation deposits. Senator Walsh has spoken at length on that matter. We cannot get an answer. Members of the Government will not deny that this is the case so what are we to assume-that in fact they have these investments and are ripping off the general public. It is time a change was brought about. Of course, it is time we had an election so that we can get a government which is honest to run this country. We do not want people who do everything possible to line their own pockets, people who do not need the money but who are ripping it off the poorer people of this country-the workers. I say again that it is a damn disgrace.

TALK.START.PARA: —On this matter I want to ask the Minister for Finance (Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle) and those who are advising her how it is that such mortgages were issued with no interest rate escalation clause. When one takes out a loan with the Commonwealth Bank there is a clause in the mortgage document which allows the interest rate either to rise or to fall according to the conditions that prevail in the market place. It is extraordinary that two Government Ministers have mortgages with fixed interest rates for a term of forty five years. It is fairly obvious that both those Ministers are taking advantage of those low interest rates. If they have a need for funds, why should they have to use a bank overdraft which would cost them nearly 16.5 per cent when they can comfortably use $28,000 of the Government's money at an interest rate as low as 4.25 per cent? That is a ridiculous rate of interest. One would understand if that rate of interest were made available to returned servicemen.
—It is 4.75 per cent and the other is 6.25 per cent.

—Well, 4.75 per cent and 6.25 per cent are very low rates of interest at present. It appears that the Senate now needs to express an opinion that these Ministers should divest themselves of these loans immediately. They cannot possibly continue ethically to be in this position. The first question then which the Minister may be able to answer for us is why two Government Ministers should have mortgages at such low fixed rates of interest over a period of 45 years. That is not sound lending practice at all. That is rather ridiculous. Was it done in error? Someone mentioned that there was an error in the mortgages. If it was done in error, there must be some way in which that error can be corrected. But something the Ministers can do immediately is to take steps to divest themselves of those mortgages and to borrow money, at normal interest rates, to pay back the Government these loans which are greatly to their advantage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Georges raised the question of the fixed interest rate clause. I just state again that the mortgages granted up to 20 September 1974 did contain a fixed interest rate clause. All people who had a Commonwealth of Australia mortgage at that time had it under those terms. That was the arrangement that existed. In 1974 this was changed and all mortgages that were issued after that date contained a variable interest clause. Persons who took out mortgages after that date in 1974, of course, have a variable interest rate clause. But many thousands of people in the Australian Capital Territory-I would hesitate to speculate on the number, but it would be countless-who had mortgages in the early years of the settlement of the Australian Capital Territory would have a fixed interest rate clause in their Commonwealth of Australia mortgage instruments.

SPEECH.PARA: Another change was that prior to 1974 mortgagees were permitted to transfer their interest in a Commonwealth of Australia mortgage when they sold the property. I can only say that this historically was the basis on which these mortgages were granted. The changes that I have mentioned have taken effect. Those who took out mortgages prior to the date of change, regardless of who they are or what level of position they may have in the community of Canberra, still hold them at that fixed rate of interest. It is not something about which I can give any other information, except to say that that was the practice at that time and that is the way in which the mortgages were written.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Georges Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can we get an assurance from the Minister that this matter and the opinion of honourable senators who have spoken will be brought to the notice of the two Ministers concerned? I do not think it is necessary for us to move a motion stating that it is the opinion of the chamber that those two Ministers should divest themselves of the two mortgages promptly. One is tempted to move such a motion and to enter into a wider debate but surely the Minister, especially as she is the Minister for Finance, would be prepared to give us an assurance that she will bring the matter to the notice of the two Ministers to indicate that there is an unfair advantage to them that they ought not to be prepared to accept. They ought to show, as I think Senator McLaren said, some example to the rest of the community even though they are tecnically entitled to continue with such mortgages. It is fairly obvious that to this point they have had no intention of reducing the principal amount because a very cheap interest rate is payable.

SPEECH.PARA: These Ministers would have gained other advantages in the normal run of economic change through buying their properties. The value of those properties must have increased substantially but that is another matter. Everyone gains under this system from an increase in property value. They have had an advantage in that direction which, possibly, one would not criticise. One would allow one's criticism to flow to the lack of a capital gains tax. There has been some difficulty in governments coming to a decision to tax capital gain. Both Ministers have managed to advance themselves financially in that direction. But this is another matter which is of considerable concern. I ask the Minister to transfer that concern to the two Ministers involved.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have noted with interest the comments of the honourable senators who have spoken tonight. I have noted the request of Senator Georges that I draw the comments of the Committee to the attention of the Ministers concerned. I undertake to do that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —A couple of matters need to be cleared up because of the interjections from the other side. Firstly, Mr Morrison's name was mentioned. Now that I have had time to have another look at the document I find that the amount of the loan which Mr Morrison took out was $7,000. He discharged that mortgage on 12 December 1974. Mr Grassby took out a loan of $7,958. He discharged that mortgage on 18 March 1976. Two other honourable members took out loans. One is an ex-Labor member of Parliament, Mr Bob Whan, and the other, Mr Ken Fry still is a member of Parliament. When we look at the notes on the bottom of the document we find that both of these persons obtained the loans as private citizens prior to becoming members of Parliament. Mr Whan borrowed only $9,000 as a private citizen. No doubt many other private citizens in Canberra availed themselves of such loans at that time and would have been paying the same rate of interest. Mr Fry borrowed $11,970. Let us compare those figures with the amounts of money borrowed by these Ministers. The purchase price of Mr Anthony's house in 1964 was $18,910. The amount of the loan he received was $17,964. He paid less than $1,000 as a deposit, yet he received most of the purchase price of the house at an interest rate of 4.75 per cent. He still owes $15,005 and some odd cents. He bought the house in 1964, which is 17 years ago.
—How much?

—That is the amount of money that Mr Anthony still owes. When Mr Nixon purchased his house on 27 August 1970 the selling price was $31,950. He borrowed $30,352 from the Government. He still owes $28,404.14. Honourable senators can see that whilst there have been a few interjections from the other side, two of the people about whom there have been interjections borrowed their money as private citizens and have long since paid the money back, although they took out the loans for 45 years. But they were honest people and they paid back the loans. From looking at the document we find that the allocations for Mr Anthony and Mr Nixon, who borrowed nearly the full amount of the purchase price of those homes are shown under the heading 'remarks' as 'a ministerial allocation'.

SPEECH.PARA: I am concernned only about the sitting members of parliament and, particularly, the Ministers of this Government. I concur with what was said by my colleague, Senator Georges, that something ought to be done. The Senate ought to be in the position to take some action to see that these two Ministers divest themselves of the loans that they are now carrying on these two houses. As I said before, it is a disgrace that two Ministers-two Cabinet Ministers at that-are able to carry on like this and rort the system while we have other people, particularly young couples who want to buy a home and rear a family, who are unable to get money because of the penny-pinching methods of this Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Georges Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —We need to consider another couple of departments which were considered by Estimates Committee F. We have been somewhat diverted by the revelations made by Senator McLaren which are matters of concern. When looking at the document concerning the Department of Science and Technology the first word that strikes my eye appears under 'Telegrams'. It is the word 'conscience'. That brings to mind that conscience should prevail in matters such as those exposed by Senator McLaren.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to raise a matter concerning the Department of Science and Technology section of the report. I asked a question on notice in which I sought information from the Department of Home Affairs and Environment concerning amounts spent on Great Barrier Reef research. I have received an answer through the secretary of the Committee from the Department of Science and Technology giving a list of the various research projects being undertaken on the Great Barrier Reef. It is an impressive list but I must express some concern about one area. In this document there does not seem to be any evidence that substantial moneys are being spent on research on the crown of thorns starfish infestation of the Great Barrier Reef. I may be incorrect in my scrutiny of this document but it is a substantial document which was sent to the Estimates Committee by the Department of Science and Technology. The question I raise is: Where in this document is expenditure on the crown of thorns infestation shown? I think one or two amounts are shown but they amount to a few hundred dollars. Yet last time I raised the question I think an allocation of $100,000 had been made for crown of thorns research. It is pleasing to note that today the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) took a definite step in the confrontation with the Queensland Government and has decided that the marine park in the Cairns area will be declared.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are commending the Prime Minister? It is a very good decision.

—I have not said otherwise. It has taken almost two years of argument with the State Government for the Australian Government to come to the point where it has made a decision based on its powers. If I recall correctly, we have been arguing for quite a number of years that on this matter there is very little chance of co-operation with the Queensland Government. That has been proven today. The Prime Minister has finally decided that after two years of discussions the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park will be declared and the Australian Government will accept its responsibilities. That is pleasing. What is not pleasing is that, although the large sum of money provided for research on the Great Barrier Reef is not being dissipated, because every item of research that is mentioned is worth while, it seems to have been spread over research which covers a great area of investigation that does not attach itself to the reef complex. In particular, it does not cover the main problem which the reef faces at present, that is, the starfish infestation, which recent reports say is increasing. The infestation appeared to have fallen away but is now starting to reappear, and previously devastated reefs are being devastated a second time. Simply, the question is: How much money is being spent on research in the area I have mentioned?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Townley Sen M.

TALK.START.PARA: —First of all, as Chairman of Estimates Committee F I wish to say how grateful I am to the people from the different departments who came before us for the way they gave evidence. In a couple of cases they needed a bit of prodding to obtain a full answer, but that is what I expect from them anyway. I have had a lot of experience with some of the people from the Department of Transport, or who used to be with the Department of Transport, and I know that unless one asks the right question they will not give the answer one really wants. That is their privilege. That is what I would expect of them. Some of the matters I have listened to tonight have worried me a little. I will go back briefly to the Department of the Capital Territory, and I do not want any interjections at this stage from honourable senators who sit on my right.
—When would you like them?

—Senator Martyr can do so whenever he wishes because he is on my left. Those honourable senators on my right should be quiet for a moment because too often they interject when a Government senator is about to say something that I think is important.
—We have not said a word. Senators on your side are interjecting.

—I said I would take interjections from my left. I think the situation with regard to Ministers of the Crown receiving loans at low rates of interest-if what was said is correct-is scandalous and should be fixed forthwith. Those people should pay off the loans, as I certainly would if I had a loan on the kind of salary they are getting. Having finished with that matter, I move to the Department of Transport. First of all I refer to the Department of Transport's F28 aircraft, of which it has three. I used to be that when I went to a meeting with the people from the Department of Transport they would come along with a list of aircraft they had and the hours flown during the previous year. Unfortunately, this year I omitted to ask that question, and that is my fault. Perhaps it is time that the Department included that information in its Estimates. It has a considerable number of aircraft and the number of hours that those aircraft fly each year is not very considerable. I would like to have had from the Department a list of the aircraft on its register and the hours that they had flown. I hope that it is not too late to get that list.

SPEECH.PARA: During the interrogation-that is a word I use knowingly of the Department of Transport-I asked what hours were spent in training the people who are examiners of airmen. I think this is one area which the Department of Transport needs to examine. I believe the amount of money spent on training people to check the pilots of this country is pretty exorbitant. It will be seen that the amount allocated for staff training in the Department of Transport Estimates has increased by 25 per cent this year compared with last year and that, out of a total of about $1.5m, over $0.5m is being spent for overseas travel and training.

I find it very difficult to understand the situation where people who fly a particular type of aircraft for only 12 hours a year are then able to sit behind a pilot who flies 40 times 10 hours a year-400 hours a year-and criticise the way that he flies that aircraft. I am not yet convinced-I interpose that I have been offered to be shown around by the Department of Transport in Melbourne but I have not yet had time to see the situation there-that the amount of time which has been spent on training on one type of aircraft, particularly in relation to the Jumbos and some of the other bigger aircraft that are flying around this country, is of any real benefit. I think the Department may well be able to save money in that regard.

I see that a certain amount of the flying time-some 66 hours-of the F28s in this coming year is being spent performing VIP aircraft travel at over $2,000 an hour, which is a cost in excess of those of the other aircraft that I mentioned earlier today. I think I said that the BAC111 costs nearly $1,700 an hour. For the benefit of those who do not understand anything about flying-like Senator McLaren from South Australia-the hours apply to when the aircraft is flying and not when it is sitting on the ground, be it in any other place than the capital cities.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the 707s at over $4,000 an hour?
—Yes. I have not had a chance to read what Senator Sibraa said about those earlier on.
—Nearly $10m a year without wages.

—I will get back to those matters. There is plenty of time yet. We have another week of sitting. The point is that Department of Transport aircraft are put down to fly 66.05 hours of VIP flights at $2,290 an hour. The only time I have flown anything like the 0.05 hours is when I flew at Geelong. I flew there once. The aircraft got into the air, fell down towards the ground and hit a fence. The Department of Transport put that down as 0.03 flying hours and charged me for it. Thank goodness I was not charged at nearly $2,300 an hour because I could not have afforded it.

SPEECH.PARA: The point is that I was told that the Department of Transport had bought the F28s for some tremendous amount-they are the same kind of aircraft that are flown in Western Australia by what used to be called MacRobertson Miller Airlines-to check facilities at different airports. At the time I criticised the purchase of those aircraft. I really do not think the Department needs three of these aircraft. Let me put it in perspective. If a company wants to make a profit out of running an aircraft it expects to get something like 3,000 hours a year from that aircraft. Here we have the Department of Transport running aircraft that I imagine are doing 400 hours to 500 hours a year. These aircraft are costing this country a lot of money. I think the Department should look at whether it really needs these F28s.

Another subject I would like to talk about is the light aircraft situation at the Hobart Airport. The restrictions on light aircraft at the airport are becoming increasingly severe. The position used to be that when a pilot took off in a light aircraft he could fly at his own discretion in a certain direction and at a certain height provided he did not go into the primary area where the larger aircraft were flying. But recently the position has changed. It seems that unless a pilot can guarantee to separate his aircraft by at least 1,000 feet vertically from any other aircraft that happens to be in the area he is not allowed to take off. This restriction is costing a lot of people who are learning to fly and who are taking joy flights around the area a considerable amount of money. It is over-restriction. It is not required. Perhaps I can illustrate the situation by saying that if I were to take off from Cambridge Airport to fly to Moorabbin I would require virtually none of the facilities of the Department of Transport although the facilities are costed against general aviation. When a pilot is going across Bass Strait he likes to be in contact with Melbourne radio or Launceston radio in case he falls in the water; but if he falls in the water in Bass Strait he will not have much chance of being found anyway, as we have found out on many occasions. Many Department of Transport charges are being costed against general aviation that should not be because the facilities are not required. The example I gave is perhaps a difficult one because anyone who flies across Bass Strait is obliged by regulation to report. But if a pilot is going from Moorabbin to South Australia, on no occasion would he need to contact the civil aviation authorities.

I have limited time in which to speak but there are two other matters I would like to mention. It has been announced that an international terminal is to be built in Hobart within the next year or so. I am not convinced that the proposed site for the building will be to the total benefit of the State. It is unusual for somebody from a particular area not to encourage the Government to go ahead with a new building because people think it will be great, extra building will be going on and it will benefit the whole community. Hobart has four international flights each week, two departures and two arrivals. It is anticipated that the building will cost over $1m. I believe both Ansett Airlines of Australia and Trans Australia Airlines are against the proposal to place the terminal on the site that has been chosen. It is to be built in an area that has just had a display put in it. There is a parking area there. The proposed building will limit parking facilities. The airlines that are operating in Hobart at present want the terminal incorporated in the present one and I think that is the sensible thing to do at this stage. I hope that is something that the Department of Housing and Construction will look at seriously in the coming months.

I would like to ask what happened in regard to the recent search in which the F111s were brought in to look for an aircraft that disappeared somewhere between Sydney and Melbourne. Are the costs attributed to the Department of Transport or to the Department of Defence? While everybody here would want to find anybody who happened to be alive after an air crash-I know what it feels like-the introduction of the F111 is an expense that I believe should be borne by the Department of Defence as a defence training item, just as I am told that many of the VIP aircraft come under the vote for the Department of Defence.

Those are some of the matters that came to my notice when we went through the estimates. I would like to comment on the amount of money that is spent in sending pilots overseas for training so that they can then judge the ability of people who do many more hours than they do in Australia. Finally, I thank once again for their help the people from the various departments who came became me as chairman. If at any time I appeared a little aggressive I assure them that that is the way I am.

TALK.START.PARA: —Come on, give it a break.
—No, come on; they all knew what I was about. They knew I would expect the kind of tolerance I got at the committee hearings. Senator Grimes knows what I mean.
—Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mulvihill Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise two short matters. In the first instance I refer to the Department of Science and Technology. In this I follow the remarks of my Queensland colleague Senator Georges on the extent of research in that State. I wonder whether the Department could ascertain for me the truth or otherwise of the assertion made by a naturalist in Sydney that, notwithstanding the fair acquisition of natural parks and wildlife refuges in Australia, not enough attention has been given to the retention of the correct eucalypt species which is the staple diet of the koala. I wonder whether we have any up to date research which would refute or endorse that assertion.

SPEECH.PARA: The second matter is directed at the Department of Transport. I wonder whether we could get a tally sheet for the last 12 months indicating the extent of off-shore spillages around Australia. I know that they fall into two categories: Those which are refinery mishaps and those which occur in the open sea. The latest figures that I received indicate, in the first instance, that there appeared to be a tendency for flagships under Liberian and Panamanian flags to be the worst offenders. Secondly, in a number of cases we did not detect the offence. With the emergence of our responsibility for a 200-mile fishing zone there is a greater need to weed out these vessels. The last point I wish to raise has been raised by Senator Sibraa and relates to coastal surveillance. I think that a table for the last 12 months will indicate whether we have improved our batting average on detection.

TALK.START.PARA: —I enter this debate to add my words to the matter raised by Senator Townley concerning the spending of over $1m on an international air terminal in Hobart. We have a situation in which there are two flights a week in and out of Hobart to Christchurch, both of which are Boeing 727s and both of which have an average loading of less than 60 per cent. Bearing in mind that neither Ansett Airlines of Australia nor Trans Australia Airlines agrees with the building or the siting of the terminal, on what set of priorities was this decision made? The upgrading of both Hobart Airport and Launceston Airport is needed. The upgrading of the tarmacs at both Devonport and Wynyard airports in Tasmania is needed. Yet it seems to me that suddenly bobbing up at the top of the priorities is this extraordinary building to be built in Hobart which it has been predicted will cost just over $1m. By the time it is built the figure will probably be near $2m. There is no suggestion that the number of flights to and from Christchurch will increase or that any other international flights will be commenced. One just cannot understand the priorities that were set. I wonder whether we could have some answer as to why this is a top priority. Apart from the fact that Mr Hodgman and Mr Goodluck make a lot of noise, I can see no reason for having this as the top priority.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coates Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to raise a couple of issues concerning the Department of Transport. Before I do so I wish to remark on Senator Grimes's comments concerning the Hobart Airport terminal. He may be surprised to know that I agree with his general comments on the matter. It strikes me as being silly to set up a separate terminal when presumably normal airport services, such as milk bars and newsagencies, would have to be duplicated in that separate terminal.

SPEECH.PARA: The main matter that I want to raise concerns the air bridge subsidy to Tasmania. As far as I am aware, this matter is still unresolved as far as the north-west coast is concerned. I have not heard anything in recent days as to whether it has been decided. Some honourable senators may be aware that Trans Australia Airlines and Ansett Airlines of Australia have been flying from Melbourne into the north-west coast ports of Wynyard and Devonport. But TAA is withdrawing as from next February and is being replaced by East-West Airlines Ltd. TAA has been receiving the air bridge subsidy which applies to all flights into Tasmania. But, as I understand it, the Government has still not decided whether East-West, as the replacement provider of that service, will receive the subsidy. I am seeking an assurance from the Government that it will not be applying a discriminatory policy on the north-west coast.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Temporary Chairman--
—Tell us about Queensland.

—As a matter of fact I will tell the Committee something about Queensland. I wish to speak about the estimates of the Department of Transport. Recently a light aircraft crashed in Brisbane because the radar system in Brisbane was out of operation. The plane had to be directed to a new flight pattern and had to fly across a mountainous area. It developed engine trouble and had to land. On landing, it overturned and a number of people were hurt. However that matter is secondary to another matter I want to raise tonight but it is not unimportant.

SPEECH.PARA: Some time ago in this chamber I asked the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner), who represents the Minister for Transport (Mr Hunt), a question concerning radar facilities at the Brisbane Airport. I asked how many radar systems were operational at the various airports and whether there were backup facilities at the airport in Brisbane. Part of my question was:
Is it considered fundamental to air transport safety to have a secondary back-up radar system in operation at major terminals.
The Minister's answer to that part of the question was:
All of the electronic equipment in each of the departmental radar facilities is fully duplicated.

I imagine that the Minister would have been advised then by some of the same transport advisers who are advising him tonight. They said that the radar facilities are fully duplicated. Following the crash in Brisbane I had a discussion with some of the air traffic controllers and was informed quite clearly that the radar service was out from 10.15 a.m. until 1.45 p.m. Water got into one of the radar systems. Whilst it is said that the system is duplicated, it is not actually duplicated. It is physically joined. If one part of the system is being repaired, the other part of the system is out of order. The answer to the question is very misleading when it claims that all electronic equipment in each departmental radar facility is fully duplicated. It is not fully duplicated; in actual fact the two radar systems are physically joined. As I have said, the air traffic controllers have advised me that if one area of that radar system has to be repaired the whole radar system has to be stopped.

People can claim that the crash of the light aircraft was not caused by the radar system, but I was advised that if the air traffic controllers had been able to bring the aircraft in on the flight path on which it attempted to land and radar facilities had been available the aircraft could have been brought in on that flight path. It was only because those facilities were not available that its position had to be altered and it was decided to divert the aircraft to a flight path which light aircraft normally do not take in that area.

I cannot understand why the Department of Transport is saying that one of the safety precautions is duplication of facilities. The metropolitan area of Brisbane does not have duplicated facilities; the two facilities are physically joined. They are not duplicated and if there is a breakdown in one there is a breakdown in the other as both facilities have to be stopped for repairs. This happened a day ago and the repairs took about three and a half hours. In other words, a major airport in Australia was without radar facilities for three and a half hours. I would like the Department of Transport to answer some questions in relation to this matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will speak very briefly on the provision of funds for the upgrading of airports in various parts of Australia. Reference has been made to some of the problems in Tasmania, but I believe that people need to be reminded that Tasmania does not enjoy the advantage which the other States enjoy of Commonwealth expenditure on an interlinking highway. There is a very substantial saving for Commonwealth revenue in that a highway does not have to be maintained, as is the case with highways between every other State, between Tasmania and its nearest State, Victoria. Therefore there are considerations and compensations to which Tasmania is entitled and which do not apply to the other States. Substantial funds are being made available for upgrading airports-I do not object to that-and all that is required so far as Tasmania is concerned, further than has been announced to date, is that the Commonwealth stop the nonsense of talking about Launceston Airport requiring local ownership before it can be upgraded to take unlimited Boeing 727 aircraft landings. The amount of money involved is a tiny fraction of what is proposed to be spent on most of the other upgradings that are taking place around Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: Launceston Airport is the gateway to Tasmania. Launceston Airport is the closest major airport to the nearest State-Victoria. Launceston traditionally has been the tourism gateway through which package tours, fly-drive tours and all the rest take place. I supported Senator Townley, or alternatively he supported me, about getting Hobart to be the site for an international terminal. Between us and with the support of others-I am not suggesting it was not a concerted effort-the development of the international route between New Zealand and Tasmania ought to, and properly did, go to Hobart. But because Launceston Airport, as the major domestic gateway, did not receive that international status as it would have liked, that does not mean that we then abandon what is the major travel link between Victoria and Tasmania.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is Senator Harradine playing a role in this?

—Senator Mulvihill should not introduce irrelevancies. Let us get back to the realities of the problem. The problem is that for a sum of money which is probably only a little over $1m, Launceston Airport can be upgraded-all it requires is a reinforcement of the main landing strip and the tarmac area-to take unlimited 727 aircraft. That means that it will be available to continue to be used as the main domestic tourism gateway into the State. Already we have the situation in which all of the hire and drive, and bus tour operators use that airport. The tourist industry, which is an extremely important industry to Tasmania-the figures vary, but the assessment is that it is probably the third most important industry to that State-goes through that airport. I point out to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner) that at the moment the Government is talking about deferring the promised upgrading until and unless it eventually gets some priority over the capital cities-work there will never finish-or until a local ownership proposal is put forward.

SPEECH.PARA: The Senate Select Committee on Passenger Fares and Services to and from Tasmania received evidence from the Department of Transport. I have not had a chance to check, but I think the final letter was received on 18 June this year which was very shortly before the report was presented. Repeatedly throughout the evidence given to the Committee the indication was that there was a proposal for a relatively minor program of upgrading for Launceston and Hobart airports-it was relatively minor in comparison with that which is required for other States, particularly Queensland and for Sydney, for that matter-and that the upgrading of both airports would proceed. Never at any stage was there a suggestion that such upgrading would be subject to local ownership. Never at any stage was there a suggestion that there was any question that it would happen. The only question was in which order it would happen.

Therefore, the point which I am making is that I would like to receive an assurance from the Minister tonight-if he is not in a position to give it tonight, then as soon as possible-that we will stop the nonsense of talking about local ownership of the Launceston Airport and get on with doing what the Government has indicated over the past couple of years and certainly over the past 12 months was going to happen; that is, that in accordance with the development of the airline industry in Australia, in accordance with the type of aircraft which are likely to be used, Launceston will maintain its opportunity to be able to continue to serve its role as the domestic tourism gateway to Tasmania. Whilst we also encourage Hobart Airport to develop as the international gateway, the fact is that it is very much cheaper for the average tourist to be able to use Launceston as the ingress point for a circuit trip around Tasmania.

In fact, I will start talking about breach of faith; I will start talking about people who welsh on deals; I will start talking about a number of things and I will get more and more strident unless I receive an assurance that we will not hear any more about the upgrading of Launceston Airport being dependent upon some local ownership plan being accepted. I do not mind if the announcement is that that upgrading will follow in the next financial year what is being done in relation to Hobart Airport, but if somebody starts to say that the plan is at risk as to whether it will happen within the next couple of years, then I am afraid that the Government is likely to hear a very great deal more about this from Tasmanian senators on both sides of the chamber. I would regard as a total breach of faith any stepping back to a situation in which Launceston, as the main gateway to Tasmania, is disadvantaged in being able to fulfil that role.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Georges, I think, started us off with the matter of the crown of thorns starfish. He made the point that not a great deal of expenditure was being made on this form of research. I should point out to him that a very significant study was done, as I know he understands some years ago with regard to the crown of thorns starfish. Indeed, the amount of money that is being expended by the three bodies that are involved in this study at the present-the Australian Institute of Marine Science, the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority and the Australian Marine Sciences and Technologies Advisory Committee-totals some $5,000.
—Five thousand?

—An amount of $5,000 is allocated in this Budget. I think that at this time it is important to bring to the attention of those various authorities the concern of Senator Georges and also Senator Mulvihill who, I think, commented on this matter, and to have regard to the fact there may be changes in the environmental situation in the Great Barrier Reef with regard to the crown of thorns starfish. It is important that surveillance is undertaken at a high rate and that these matters are given a great deal of attention.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Townley spoke firstly about the situation with the F28 aircraft that are owned by the Department of Transport. He asked for a list of the aircraft and the hours which they fly. I am unable at this moment to provide that information. We undertake to provide it for the honourable senator.

TALK.START.PARA: —Could we have a full list of all departmental aircraft and their hours of flying during the last year?

—I believe that that can be obtained. We will endeavour to get that information for the honourable senator as quickly as possible. With regard to the training of examiners, I take the point that Senator Townley was making; rather than seeking information he was making a comment about that matter. I recall his seeking information on that matter during the Estimates Committee hearing. Again, I suggest to Senator Townley that he take up the Department's invitation to visit Melbourne as soon as practicable and have a look at the facilities. In regard to Senator Townley's broader concern as to the operation of F28s, I think we should point out that F28s are not purely available for running around Australia for the purposes of delivering passengers; rather they are available for specific purposes on non-scheduled routes. In fact, the aircraft contain up to four tonnes of electronic equipment for the surveillance of various activities in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Townley mentioned VIP travel. I understand that the full costs of VIP travel where the F28s are involved are recovered from other departments. I understand that the aircraft have been used on occasions for royal visits, for use at events such as the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting and so on.

TALK.START.PARA: —Which F28s?
—Those owned by the Department of Transport.
—They have been used for CHOGM?

—I am advised that they have. There were questions with regard to general aviation at Hobart Airport. Again, I think Senator Townley was making a comment as to the increasing costs of regulations. We know that he is well experienced in that matter. Those points have been noted. I come now to the matter concerning the international airport at Hobart. This became an intra-Tasmanian dispute of some note. We noted the comments on all sides. There seems to be considerable support from, I think, Senator Coates for the proposition of an international airport. Senator Townley's particular remarks in connnection--
—Wait a minute, you have taken him out of context, surely.
—With the location of the terminal--
—I said that there should not be a separate building.
—It is a waste of money. It is a terrible waste of money.
—I am sure those points will be clearly stated in Hansard. They will be drawn to the attention of the Minister for Transport (Mr Hunt) on a later occasion. It is a very complex argument.

SPEECH.PARA: In regard to the matter which Senator Peter Rae raised, relating to whether or not there will be any delay in the Launceston development compared with that at Hobart, certainly I believe all Tasmanians would agree that it would only enhance the tourist potential of Tasmania to have access through Hobart to international facilities. The point raised by Senator Peter Rae is a matter of real concern especially to those who live in Launceston--

TALK.START.PARA: —The Tasmanian tourist industry is concerned about it.

—I thank the honourable senator for his further observation. I will draw the matter to the attention of the Minister. Although I cannot give the immediate assurance that the honourable senator has requested I will make certain to obtain an assurance from the Minister as to progress.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Jones mentioned a recent air crash in Brisbane and I have noted his particular concern in that regard. I believe that he also has a question on the Notice Paper in regard to it. I have some information which may be of immediate interest to him but certainly will not answer all of the points raised by him. That must await the outcome of a departmental investigation. I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard such information as is now available.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
DRAFT-DAILY NOTE
ACCIDENT INVOLVING CESSNA 185 VH-BVY

The accident to Cessna 185 VH-BVY which occurred near North Pine Reservoir on Wednesday 11 November 1981 is currently under investigation by the Air Safety Investigation Branch. As the investigation is in its early stages the information which I am able to make available at this time needs to be recognised as provisional and some cannot yet be confirmed.

The aircraft was en-route from Rockhampton to Archerfield on a private flight with three persons on board. It was identified on radar and cleared initially to enter Brisbane controlled airspace at 5,000 feet. When identified the aircraft was about 10 miles east of its planned track.

In view of pending radar outage for planned maintenance, this clearance was then amended to proceed outside controlled airspace to Archerfield via the light aircraft lane of entry reporting to Brisbane Flight Service. This clearance had no effect on the required track the aircraft would follow. He would be required to descend from 5,000 feet to below 3,000 feet and then, prior to 16 miles DME Brisbane, below 2,000 feet.

In the vicinity of North Pine Reservoir, at the northern extremity of the lane of entry, the pilot advised Flight Service of a rough running engine and shortly afterwards that he was unable to maintain height.

It is perhaps worthy of mention that the prescribed lane passes to the west of the built up area of Brisbane, thus the possibility of the accident occurring within the built up area did not arise. This lane has been designed to be outside controlled airspace to provide ready access to light aircraft proceeding to and from Archerfield and locations to the north.

There are two air traffic control radar facilities at Brisbane, a primary radar and a Secondary Surveillance Radar. The two radar facilities share a common mechanical rotating mechanism, which because of its high reliability, adequate performance is obtained without duplication.

A scheduled inspection of the radar antennae was carried out at 5 a.m. on the morning of Wednesday 11 November. As a result of this inspection it was decided that some maintenance of the primary radar feed system would be required and would be done at a time convenient to operations. Because of the excellent weather, it was decided that the maintenance would be done later that morning.

The airlines were advised by Notam at 8.35 a.m. that the radar would be off for maintenance between 10.15 a.m. and 2.15 p.m. on Wednesday 11 November. The maintenance actions were completed within the notified time and the primary radar restored to service at 1.40 p.m.
The emergency location beacon carried on the aircraft was activated about the time of the crash.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Committee. No doubt the Minister, upon the conclusion of investigations that may take place later, will be in a position to answer additional questions on this matter.
—What about the subsidies on the north-west coast?

—That matter has been raised on one or two occasions by Senator Coates but no final decision has yet been made regarding it. The honourable senator would have noted-I believe he referred to it during his speech-the fact that the current arrangements continue until 1 February. I will bring his concern to the attention of the Minister and seek an early reply for him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coleman Sen R.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not delay the Committee for very long. I wish to refer to a subject on which I made a speech some time ago, on 22 October to be precise. If the Department of Transport officers have not read it, I commend it to their attention, as well as a number of complaints that I have had about the provision of air services in Western Australia through the Department. A moment ago Senator Peter Rae said 'we must stop the nonsense we are talking.' I would like to adopt some of his words and suggest that we stop the nonsense that we are engaging in at the Perth Airport. I do not know how many honourable senators have entered Perth Airport in the last month or so--
—No more than could possibly help it.

—Senator Haines says 'No more than could possibly help it'. To get into and out of the airport involves a tortuous journey. Perhaps I might relate a recent experience in that regard. On the occasion in question seats on an Airbus were being allocated. It was impossible for people who wanted to use the other airlines to get through. There were four queues. They had to go out of the airport and come back in to get their seat allocation through the other airlines. We now have some distance from the departure lounge, what is laughingly referred to as 'the pen' but I believe is officially entitled the arrival lounge. It is some hundreds of metres from where the aircraft normally pull up. There are no toilets, nor is there provision for them in this new section; nor are there any telephones. I realise that the development is in its very early stages but I point out that it is distinct and apart from the building that is already in existence.

SPEECH.PARA: I ask honourable senators to imagine a situation in which, some hundreds of metres from the actual departure terminal we have this little arrival terminal. In front of the departure terminal some boxes are now being created. I understand that they will be departure lounges which will take the traffic away from the present departure lounge but will not make it any easier for people arriving in Perth actually to get into the arrival centre. I was informed that in fact the idea of having the arrival terminal was for the aircraft to pull up, passengers to disembark, and luggage to be unloaded. Passengers would be taken through the arrival terminal and then the aircraft would proceed to the departure lounge area and park. It may have been intended that this should happen, but it is not happening. I assure the Committee that the operation is extremely dangerous at the moment because there is a lot of unmade ground between where the aircraft pull up and where passengers have to go to collect their luggage.

I strongly suspect that this problem has developed because there is no overall plan for the Perth Airport-which, as a matter of interest, is supposed to be an international airport already-and we already have international arrival and departure lounges which are not always in use and which to the best of my knowledge have been used for domestic aircraft on only two separate occasions. We are now reaching a situation where we have to have messages broadcast over the public address system in the departure terminal to say that an aircraft has arrived and passengers may be met in the arrival terminal. Then people go out into the open and trot over this hazardous little walkway to meet the people who have come from the eastern States. I would have thought that it would be a fairly simple operation for the international arrival terminal to be used for all incoming domestic flights. I would be rather interested to know whether there is any reason why this cannot be done. On the two occasions on which I have been on a domestic flight which has arrived there the operation has been very quick and very convenient, the luggage has arrived very quickly and we have been able to quit the building with a minimum of fuss. With the present situation we find that people are coming in the wrong doors and going out the wrong doors, do not listen to announcements and do not know when the flights have arrived. There is a great deal of chaos and confusion.

What concerns me most perhaps is what will be the order for the future. I am sure that those representatives of the Department of Transport who bother to read my speech of 22 October, which is recorded at page 1590 of Hansard will be interested in what I had to say. I raised the comments that had been made by Mr H. B. O'Keefe, Transport Australia's First Assistant Secretary, about the key equipment, some of which he said was almost 20 years old and being kept going with cannibalised spare parts. In that speech I made the very valid point that this was an extremely dangerous situation. The people of Western Australia and those who use the Perth Airport are entitled to know that the equipment that takes them up and brings them down is in good working order. I sincerely trust that the Minister for Veterans' Affairs can give me some comprehensive reply tonight-or if not tonight, at least in the very near future- as to the future of Perth Airport; whether there is a master plan and when I can see it and discuss it with his officers; and when in fact an appropriation is to be made for the upgrading of the equipment that appears to be so necessary to keep the airways in operation. Mr O'Keefe said:
If the Standing Committee on Public Works . . . gives the go ahead the new tower should be in operation by late 1984.
I would like to think that we will have an overall plan and a new tower long before that time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I call Senator Haines.
—You have called from the same side.
—But from a different party.
—Ladies first.
—That has nothing to do with it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It seems to me that tonight the chamber is doing its best to fulfil Mungo MacCallum's prediction that after last night's debacle the Senate's next trick would be to levitate, and the closest we are going to get to it is talking about airports. I really would hate not to be part of that. While we are discussing the Department of Transport and the airways in particular, I wish to raise two matters. One of them concerns the terminal building at Mount Gambier Airport. I imagine that that airport is in much the same situation as Perth Airport in that it is hardly an appropriate entry for tourists into what is for South Australia a prime tourist area. Although it is not exactly a Nissen hut, the terminal building in Mount Gambier is tin. I understand that it is in that state because there has been some bickering for some time between the Federal Government and the local government over whose responsibility it is to pay for, provide, build or whatever, a new terminal building. The debate was not enhanced in any way at all when a week or so ago the South Australian Minister for Tourism, Mrs Adamson, was down in the south-east to crown the festival queen and was chided by one of the local residents over the situation. Her solution was to suggest somewhat flippantly that since the south-east is a prime area for the timber industry perhaps a little self-help would not hurt and they could build it themselves. That hardly seemed, to any of the 500 people who listened to her comment, an appropriate way of solving the problem.

SPEECH.PARA: The matter of the airport at Hamilton was raised by a member of the Mount Gambier community who was there that night. He made the point that it seemed somewhat inappropriate that a town such as Hamilton, which has a population half that of Mount Gambier, should have a terminal building so much better than the one in the south-east. I understand that Hamilton is in the electorate of Wannon. The name of the honourable member for Wannon escapes me at the moment, but he obviously has considerably more pull than the honourable member for Barker (Mr Porter), in whose electorate Mount Gambier is situated.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think his name is Fraser.

—The honourable senator may be right. As I have said, my memory fails me at the moment. I would like to know now what will be done, and when, about the upgrading of the airport terminal. It is the gateway for tourism in the south-east, and that is an important industry for South Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: The second matter I want to raise is in elaboration of a matter I raised in Question Time this morning. It concerns what seemed to me rather odd priorities within the Department of Transport in relation to an internatioanl airport in South Australia sited somewhere near Adelaide. Senator Townley was complaining bitterly earlier about the waste of $1m in upgrading a terminal--

TALK.START.PARA: —I wasn't bitter.

—Whatever it was, it certainly sounded bitter from this side of the House, but since interjections were not being taken from this side we really could not be quite certain of the tone of the honourable senator's attack. However Senator Townley was complaining, he nevertheless was complaining about the fact that $1m was being wasted on that upgrading. If he thinks that is bad, we are spending or are about to spend somewhere between $5m and $7m upgrading Adelaide's airport so that it can take, according to the South Australian Minister for Transport, something like three or four international flights per week. While I do not disagree with Mr Wilson that South Australia is disadvantaged with international flights since for us to get anywhere overseas other than to Kangaroo Island we have to go via another capital city and add that domestic air fare to our international air fare, I would disagree with the short term solution which is being proposed, presumably by the Department of Transport.

SPEECH.PARA: For those honourable senators who do not come to Adelaide with any frequency I point out that Adelaide's airport is in the centre of a residential area. It is some 10 kilometres from the city centre of Adelaide. It is on a large slab of prime residential land in a city which is bounded on its eastern side by the hills and on its western side by the sea and, therefore, is forced to spread north and south for any residential development and expansion. It seems to us rather absurd that the Government is planning to spend $5m to $7m to put in a temporary international terminal on the present Adelaide Airport site simply to accommodate three or four flights a week, unless the Government is planning on progressively increasing these flights over the years, as it does with taxes. It would seem much more appropriate to bring forward the projected time of building a proper international airport for South Australia.

At the moment we are assured by the Premier of South Australia that that will occur somewhere around the turn of the century, although I would not hold my breath waiting bearing in mind the state in which South Australia now finds itself. We are also assured that it will be built well on the outskirts of Adelaide in a non-residential area. I therefore question seriously the priorities of the Department of Transport in spending this amount of money at this time when it is clearly planning to spend an even larger amount of money in the very near future to do the job properly. I ask the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner) not only when the terminal facilities at the Mount Gambier Airport will be upgraded but also when South Australia will get its much-needed and deserved international airport terminal outside a major residential area.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Townley Sen M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be brief, but I would like to comment upon just a couple of points which were brought up by honourable senators who spoke before me in this debate. The first point is that I do not wish it to be understood that I feel that Hobart Airport should have no money spent on it. Its present terminal should be upgraded rather than a new terminal built. I failed, I think, to make that clear. But I agree with Senator Coates-maybe this will be the one and only time that we agree-that the way in which money should be spent at Hobart Airport is by upgrading the present terminal rather than building a separate terminal. As I said earlier, I think both Ansett Airlines of Australia and Trans-Australia Airlines would agree with that.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like another question answered. The Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner) talked about the F28s owned by the Department of Transport which will spend 66.05 hours on VIP travel in the coming year. I want to know: If they have four tonnes of electronic equipment on board, how will they be suitable for VIP travel? Does that mean that the Department has quick change F28s; that it can rip out all those tonnes of equipment and put in VIP facilities? I would like, if possible, either now or in the near future, a list of just how those F28s will be used in VIP travel.

TALK.START.PARA: —Whilst the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner), in his interim responses to honourable senators who have spoken on these Estimates, did bracket my name with that of Senator Georges when he spoke generally on scientific research, he did not indicate specifically whether anything was being done to refute or to endorse the need to retain an adequate eucalypt habitat for koalas. Also, he did not respond to my question concerning a tally sheet on oil spillages.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly, in answer to Senator Townley's question regarding the electronic equipment on board the F28s, yes, that equipment is removable. The configuration of the aircraft is changed from time to time for VIP travel purposes. I will endeavour to obtain further information for the honourable senator on the other matter that he raised. I will need to take on notice Senator Mulvihill's question on koalas. I will get back to Senator Mulvihill as soon as possible on that. The oil pollution statistics can be obtained for Senator Mulvihill at relatively short notice. Again, I will undertake to do that as quickly as possible. I now turn to the matters raised by Senator Coleman. She would know best of all the situation which exists at Perth Airport. Having travelled there I know that from time to time the airport does present considerable problems. Indeed, certain works are in hand for the introduction-
—That is what bothers me-that they are in hand.

—Yes, I understand that. I am sure that the honourable senator's concerns have been noted tonight by the Department of Transport. Opportunities will be provided for further discussions in that regard also. Two airports in South Australia were mentioned. Senator Haines referred to Mount Gambier Airport. Most of us know Mount Gambier Airport well. I believe this is an area of concern. As the honourable senator indicated, it is an important tourist area of South Australia and does represent a gateway to that State. I will bring the matter to the attention of the Minister for Transport (Mr Hunt) and I will indicate Senator Haines's very real concern. She made the point, when referring to the Adelaide Airport, that perhaps there ought to be a movement towards the establishment of another airport further outside of the metropolitan area rather than a redevelopment of the present airport. Perhaps I should just make one or two points on this because she was referring to priorities and that does include the question of finance.

SPEECH.PARA: An amount of $7m, which is currently in mind with regard to the extension of terminal facilities at Adelaide Airport so as to provide an international type facility, compares very favourably, in terms of priorities, considering a possible 15 years use that would be obtained from that facility, with the estimated cost of some $200m-$300m which might be involved in the development of another airport outside of Adelaide. Of course, we have to bear in mind the very considerable time it would take-maybe between eight and ten years-before such an airport could be constructed and got under way. The present facility which is in mind for Adelaide would be in operation, I think, within the next couple of years. Therefore, I believe the Government's priorities are correct in this regard. Indeed, this does give us breathing space as we look ahead to the increased services and usages as South Australia develops, particularly in the minerals area.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Georges Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to comment on the information that was given that only $5,000 out of some $1,250,000 has been spent on starfish research. I have received an assurance that the matter will be brought to the attention of various authorities. It seems to me to be extraordinary that research on starfish infestation should be allotted such a small amount. One would now have to ask: Where are the reports that resulted from the expenditure of some $110,000 over past years? I know that research has been undertaken in the past. I know that a report has been brought down. My opinion was that the report was not conclusive and suggested that instead of reducing the amount spent on research into the infestation problem there should have been an increase. I wonder whether competition and the arguments that exist between scientists have led us to fall in between their varying opinions as to whether there is cyclic infestation of starfish, whether it is of short proportions, or whether it is a cyclic infestation of great magnitude which could lead to the destruction of the Great Barrier Reef at a time when there are other pressures upon the Reef. I hope that is not the case.

SPEECH.PARA: I know that there has been some conflict between the scientists at the James Cook University and the scientists at the University of Queensland. I am interested to know how much research money is going to the James Cook University and how much is going to the University of Queensland. I would not like to put any money on it, but I would say that a substantial amount of the research money is going to the James Cook University. If that is the case and the James Cook University has some say in decisions as to where the money is to be spent, of course we would find that the priority given to the crown of thorns starfish problem has been downgraded. I will from time to time raise in the Senate the question of this infestation as I have done in the past. The fact that only $5,000 is being spent at a time when all indications are that infestation is increasing substantially is a disgrace.

I am surprised that we have not come back to the matters raised by Senator Jones which concerned the safety of airports and of people. Senator Jones was not concerned with further extensions or upgradings; he was concerned with safety. A very real problem exists at the Brisbane Airport. The Estimates Committee was able to ascertain through questioning that a shortage of air traffic controllers at Brisbane Airport has presented a problem. This matter has been the subject of questions in the Senate and especially in the Committee. The Minister for Transport (Mr Hunt) made a statement that a training program is now underway to make up for the shortfall of air traffic controllers. Questioning by the Committee revealed that for some reason or other a failure to anticipate the wastage by retirement at Brisbane Airport has led to a shortfall and that that shortfall has aggravated the problem. Because of their increased work load the air traffic controllers who were available have been affected. The point was reached where they began to fail.

We now have the ridiculous situation of a 9 o'clock curfew at Brisbane Airport. I travel from Sydney to Brisbane regularly. It is not a very comfortable feeling to know that on some occasions the last flight on which one is travelling has to come in much more rapidly in order to beat the curfew. That means that there is still a safety problem as far as Brisbane Airport is concerned because of a shortage of controllers. The Department of Transport does not seem to have taken emergency action to transfer air traffic controllers to Brisbane Airport. Surely there are controllers elsewhere who are not so much surplus but available to work at Brisbane Airport if they were paid the necessary working away from home allowance. I hope that the Department of Transport does not take economies into account when it considers the problem at Brisbane Airport.

Senator Jones also raised the question of radar equipment. What he has revealed is a matter of consequence. He was given the incorrect answer. In fact there is no backup system at all. In fact the systems are connected. When one fails the other must be shut down in order to repair it. In this case it led to an accident with a small aircraft, but it could have led to an accident with one of the larger aircraft. One could argue that the backup should not have been repaired until such time as it was convenient to close both down. But in an airport of the size and status of Brisbane Airport such an arrangement surely is not acceptable.

I suggest that the matter Senator Jones has raised should be answered now. The Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner) said that he had further information. What does he do? He incorporates it in Hansard, as if it is a matter of concern between himself and Senator Jones. It is a matter of concern for all once it is raised. I would have thought the Minister would have read the document and given us that information. Its incorporation in Hansard means that the Hansard reporter has taken the document with him. What was in that document? What can the Minister tell us here which may have some spread of interest and which could allay the fears of people who land at Brisbane Airport?

Surely the Minister and the Department of Transport must by now accept that the position at Brisbane Airport is unacceptable by any standards. At present we have daylight saving, which enables aircraft easily to beat the curfew. We want an assurance tonight from the Minister that at the end of this six-month period, when the normal hours between the two States are restored, there will be sufficent air traffic controllers to enable the curfew to be lifted. Again I say that this is a matter of safety. It is not a matter of just increasing the length of a runway or doing any other thing. It is a matter of making safe those existing facilities which are not safe at the moment. There will arise a situation in which aircraft landing in Brisbane will not be under proper control. Really that is not acceptable.
