LETTER FROM MRS SCHELLING
Shaaltarah Kennels Kangaroo Ground 3097 8 May 1981 The Hon. M. J. MacKellar,
Parliament Offices,
Canberra, ACT
Dear Sir,

I enclose photograph of my recently imported Greyhound, 'Harestreak Triple Crown (imp. UK)'-house name 'Rugby'. It will attest even more to my plight than the also enclosed report by my Veterinary Surgeon, Dr Hugh Wirth, who is, incidentally, Victorian President for the RSPCA. The photograph was taken shortly after the dog's release from the new, 'luxury' quarantine station at Wallgrove on 24 April. He weighed 65 lbs in mid November, at 5 1/2 months.
Dr Wirth has just informed me that Rugby died this morning-weight 32 lbs.

Let me point out that this Greyhound was not a racing Greyhound. He was in fact one of the only two living male exhibition Greyhounds from the British Kennel Club Stud Book to come to Australia. The other served his quarantine confinement as a kennel mate of Rugby and was in similar condition at release. His constitution was able to stand the necessary changes to diet and environment and he has gained 15 lbs to date. Poor Rugby was not so lucky and was first hospitalised on 27 April for intensive care.

It should not be necessary to point out that this dog represents the outlay of many thousands of dollars. Shipping costs alone amount to four figures and Rugby's value to the ancient breed of Greyhound in Australia was inestimable. He was acquired after extremely difficult negotiations, years of waiting and personal travel worldwide, study of the breed and pedigrees etc. etc. Since his breeder was reluctant to submit the dog to quarantine in any case, it is highly unlikely that she will ever send a replacement, if indeed a suitable one can be found. Rugby was a son of Englands top male-all breeds and was imported specifically as a mate for Australasia's No. 1 Sighthound, my Champion Solstrand Diamond Lil (Imp. UK), who won the 'Contest of Champions' last October, defeating the absolute top winning stars of all other breeds of canine from all over Australia. Needless to say she is world famous in the dog scene and her puppies by Rugby were eagerly awaited and in great demand.

I am not new to the business of importation of livestock into Australia. I have in my twenty years as a successful breeder, exhibitor and international judge of dogs, imported some 15 dogs from Great Britain, New Zealand and from USA. I have owned and, or bred some 100 Australian Champion Afghan Hounds, Greyhounds and Italian Greyhounds. I have also exported many dogs. My previous imports have been quarantined in Melbourne and in Perth. Never have I had the problems which I experienced in this instance. I am not alone in my disenchantment with the new NSW complex and can furnish names of others whose dogs were released in far from unsatisfactory condition. In addition, complaints about the attitude of one Miss Syder, Collector of Public Moneys, were universal.

I visited my dogs at Wallgrove on 17 March, some six weeks after arrival and found them both to be in extremely poor condition. I complained to the young attendant, known to me as Roy, and asked that the dogs' food be increased. In addition the dogs' feet were badly splayed and growing joints swollen due to their trying to maintain footing on the entirely unsuitable, shiny, slippery and seemingly constantly wet surface of the kennel. I had understood from publicity regarding the new kennels that 'vet bedding' was used. My dogs had no bedding, not even a raised wood platform, and had been forced to sleep on the same concrete floor. As a result they developed pressure sores on their already swollen and painful joints. Since both dogs were puppies going through what should have been their greatest growth period, their alarming weight drop had me concerned. I am of the understanding that dogs are weighed weekly whilst quarantined. Surely the dogs' weight charts should also have caused concern to the persons responsible. In the light of previous experience with Melbourne quarantine, I was naive enough to think that this would be rectified.

On my second visit, one month later, I was horrified to find that the situation had worsened. The dogs were even thinner, their feet and joints worse, and Rugby definitely lethargic and losing hair in handsful. This time they had some form of bedding-a bag of wood chunks, which was wet. At this time I had three breeder friends of wide experience with me, including one from USA. Let me say that we were all horrified and I was ashamed of our government, to say the very least. As there was only three days until the dogs would be released I felt that they would survive until I was able to instigate a reversal at home. It was always my understanding that all dogs were routinely dosed for worms on admittance and prior to release. I will direct your attention to the vet report in this regard.

I do not know the qualifications demanded of attendants working in Wallgrove, nor do I believe that the blame can be entirely laid at the boy's feet. I was charged a fee of $30 for veterinary inspections and a 'Form QA12', declaring that the dogs were in good health was signed after final veterinary inspection immediately before release. Since wasting is a symptom of Leptospirosis, one of the diseases which quarantine is supposed to guard against, it could have been possible that a diseased dog was being released to spread that horror far and wide.

Whilst I am informed that Animal Quarantine will be transferred to the jurisdiction of Primary Industry, the case in question is entirely the responsibility of your department of government and there are many areas of Animal Quarantine which warrant questions being asked and satisfactory answers given. In spite of the fact that previous complaints along these lines have been totally disregarded in the past I intend to pursue this matter to the limit of my resources.

A copy of this letter is being forwarded, along with the photograph and veterinary report, to the Australian National Dog Press, the British Canine Press, the Greyhound press and to all commercial dog shipping agents in the UK. The breeder of the dog will take the matter as far as she can in Britain, and will personally visit Australia House. My own further actions will, of course, depend upon your actions.
I sincerely hope that you will find the time to give this matter immediate attention.
Yours faithfully, Lynette O. Schelling (Mrs)
EXTRACT FROM 'NATIONAL DOG'
Canberra Refutes 'Gross Neglect' at Wallgrove
The following letter has been received from the Commonwealth Department of Health, Canberra.

Whilst it is not our normal practice to enter into controversy concerning the use of government facilities, I feel compelled to comment on the letters which have appeared in your newspaper on the last 2-3 months dealing with the death of Mrs Schelling's greyhound dog 'Rugby'.

I must stay at the outset, that I have chosen not to comment earlier as the circumstances surrounding the death of the animal were unclear and, as is normal in these types of cases, a full investigation was being undertaken by this Department.

However I take strong exception to Mrs Schelling's continued attempts to discredit the staff at the Wallgrove facility, to question the integrity of the veterinary supervision, and to downgrade the facilities and their design.
1. The dog entered quarantine on 24 January at age 7 months and weighing 26kgs.
2. During its stay in quarantine the animal suffered diarrhoea on 3 occasions. On each occasion the diarrhoea was not persistent and was cleared up in a couple of days with routine treatment.

3. Mrs Schelling visited the animals twice during the quarantine period. During these visits the animal's general condition was discussed as was the ainmal's diet. At no stage did she register any complaint about the animal's condition or its level of care.
4. The dog was released from quarantine on 24 April to its owner. At that time the animal weighed 28kg, a gain of 2kg during the quarantine period.
5. The animal was in a fit condition and Mrs Schelling signed the release to that effect without any comment to station staff, other than to thank them for their efforts.

This Department has sought and obtained a report from the private veterinarian who treated the dog after its release from quarantine. We have also sought advice from a veterinary parasitologist at Sydney University concerning the claim that the dog was suffering from a ''horrendously high parasite infection''.

The veterinary report and a pathology profile of the animal prior to its death both indicate that the animal was dehydrated and that its symptoms were ''not inconsistent with the clinical pattern of canine parvovirus disease''.
The opinion of the veterinary parasitologist, was that any effect of the number of roundworms found on a dog of that size would be absolutely minimal.
No Gross Neglect

On the basis of the above facts, I am quite unable to accept Mrs Schelling's accusations of 'gross neglect, severe undernourishment and a horrendously high internal parasite infestation', as the reason for the dogs death. Veterinary experts who have studied the history of the animal are almost unanimously of the opinion that the animal was infected with canine parvovirus.
On the broader aspects of the complaints, I would wish to point out the following facts:

1. Rugby was accommodated in a block of kennels under the control of an employee who has worked at animal quarantine stations for 11 years and is respected for his abilities and attitude by many importers.
2. The officer who had direct responsibility for Mrs Schelling's dog was a recent employee at the station. He has however been involved in dog breeding for over eight years.

3. Staff at the station are recruited on the basis of quality and affinity with animals and all staff have undergone or are currently undertaking, the animal care courses offered by technical colleges.
4. Staff involved in animal care are not involved in day-to-day ground maintenance.

The staff of the Wallgrove Station are extremely dedicated and justifiably proud of their record of animal care. Since its opening in June 1980, the station has accepted 744 cats and dogs and to date there have only been two deaths in the station. Both of these cases were diagnosed as being caused by stress induced infection. Stress of travel is unfortunately commonly seen in animals coming such great distances by air and this demands, careful handling at the time of entry into quarantine. Since its opening, the staff of the station have received in excess of 100 letters of thanks and commendation as opposed to the one letter of complaint from Mrs Schelling.
Mrs Schelling's statement concerning the provision of bedding and the hosing out of kennels are incorrect.

All animals are provided with bedding. The bedding comprises two chaff bags partly filled with wood shavings. This type of bedding has found to be eminently suitable and sensible. It provides the animals with a warm soft sleeping surface which can easily be aired and is cheap to replace when soiled or damaged by the animal. The bedding is destroyed following the release of the animal.

Kennels are hosed out on an as required basis, dependant on the habits of the animals. Some boisterous animals (including Rugby) tend to spread excreta over themselves and their bedding. On average, kennels are hosed twice per day and remain wet for 10-15 minutes. During hosing down, the bedding is hung on the wall of the kennel.

With regard to diet, animals are fed on a diet determined by the kennelman in conjunction with the veterinary officer. Animals are fed dry dog biscuits in the mornings and fresh meat of a night. The meat is either cooked or raw depending on the animals individual requirements at the time. Dietary supplements are added to the prepared food as required. Rugby was fed 3lb of meat per day plus biscuits, calcium and dietary additives to assist weight gain and was released weighing 61.6lbs (28kg) not 39lbs as claimed by Mrs Schelling. His diet was specifically raised with her.
All food is prepared in a central preparation area prior to distribution to individual kennel blocks. It is held in the grooming room prior to placement in each kennel.

Grooming and bathing of animals is performed on an as required basis. All animals are bathed as soon as possible following arrival and again within 48 hours of release. They are also bathed as required at other times. Records of baths and grooming are kept. Similarly, animals are brushed at least once per week, with long haired animals being groomed as often as three times per week.
Full Vet Inspection

All animals undergo a full veterinary inspection on arrival and are visited twice per week by a veterinarian during the course of their stay. Prior to release they again undergo a full veterinary inspection with particular reference to their history during their stay.

Criticism of the facilities at Wallgrove is particularly ill-founded. The station is the most modern in Australia and incorporates a number of design features intended to ensure quarantine security and also to assist in the welfare of animals.

The kennel compound is designed on a block concept with each kennel being of rabies proof design. This ensures that any spread of disease would be minimal and that in the event of exotic disease outbreaks, each block can be treated as a discrete unit. This is in contrast to other stations in Australia which for exotic disease purposes must be treated on a full station basis. Each kennel includes a sheltered sleeping area and an open exercise area. The roofs of all sleeping areas are fully insulated and portable heating and cooling equipment is available. All walls are completely impervious to maintain hygienic conditions and allow full disinfection when required.

The cattery is similarly designed on a block concept, with individual cat accommodation designed to ensure minimal disease transmission. They are specifically designed to avoid cross air circulation and prevent the spread of viral respiratory disease and other problem diseases associated with the caging of cats. Each cat cage includes a basking area where the animal can enjoy maximum sunlight without exposure to adverse weather.
Since its inception, there has not been a single case of upper respiratory infection transferred from one cat to another in the station.
Future Emergencies

The size of the Wallgrove facility has been determined taking into account the foreseeable demand, any future emergency and to provide buffer accommodation against future changes in quarantine importation policy. I would point out that the station is already accepting animals from the Pacific region which are required to undergo nine months quarantine periods and again staff have had nothing but praise from importers of these animals. To date 25 dogs have performed the nine months at the station, one winning a show within two days of release. The large size of the facility has already produced tangible benefits for importers through its ability to accept large shipments of animals on charter flights, which has considerably reduced importing costs. It is worth noting that stud dogs represent only 5-10 per cent of the imports, the remainder being pets.

The record of the Wallgrove station speaks for itself, and I would suggest to any of your readers who may have doubts about the ability or attitude of the staff or the suitability of the facilities that they should contact the station and either discuss the matter with the Officer-in-Charge or arrange with him to undertake an inspection of the facilities. I believe that you will find that the Officer-in-Charge is justifiably proud of his staff and the facilities and that he can produce documented evidence to support the excellent record of the station.
I would also thank those who have written in support of our staff and facilities. This support is most important to the morale of the staff at theses facilities.
K. A. Doyle Assistant Director-General (Animal Quarantine)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coates Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a matter that concerns both the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) and the Minister for Health (Mr MacKellar). I refer to health cards for overseas students. It is a matter I have been working on for some time in trying to put together a cohesive picture, which is very difficult. Senator Coleman asked a question about this matter only a couple of days ago and, if I recall correctly, received a totally unsatisfactory reply from the Minister. In fact, on 15 September as is recorded at page 730 of Hansard I asked the Minister for Social Security, Senator Chaney, a question about the matter of health cover for overseas students. In the response he gave to that question after Question Time he outlined for me health care guidelines for temporary visitors, including overseas students studying in Australia. At that time he said:

SPEECH.PARA: Overseas students who are sponsored by governments or other bodies are not eligible for health cards.
But a circular memo dated 10 August-more than a month before the Minister answered by question-to private students from the Australian Development Assistance Bureau states:
A private student who is financed by his home government or an international agency, or by an employer or other organisations in the home country will be eligible for a health card . . .

That is, provided certain conditions are met under the residence test. Despite the fact that these students have to meet some conditions the Minister's answer appears to be in direct contradiction to the ADAB memo. What I would like to know is who was right. Does the Minister really know the rules of eligibility as they relate to overseas students studying in Australia? How well informed are his departmental officers as to the rights of those students? It seems that this, like most other aspects of the health card system, is in a state of chaos. No one is able to give a straight answer as to who is and who is not eligible. In fact, depending on to whom one speaks one can get a whole range of conflicting answers in relation to one set of circumstances.

During the past week an overseas student doing post-graduate study at the University of Tasmania came to me to try to untangle the health card mess for him. His wife was ill and he could not afford the cost of health care on his scholarship. His wife had not been in Australia for the statutory six months. The student had been given the runaround and my staff was given the runaround, not because of any bureaucratic red tape but simply because departmental officers have not been properly informed about overseas students' rights or eligibility. They are still as confused about the new health card system as the rest of the population. One of the problems is the multiplicity of departments involved. The Department of Health decides one aspect of it. The Department of Social Security decides another aspect. If the students are from overseas the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs may be involved. The Department of Foreign Affairs through ADAB, in particular, is involved and the system is a total shambles.

A series of changes to the guidelines since 1 September has only added to the confusion of the departmental officers and the students are having enough trouble coming to terms with a new culture anyhow. I understand that eligibility guidelines have been changed at least twice since 1 September. If that is the case, why has not the Minister informed the Parliament that he has updated his previous answer to me, particularly in view of the fact that questions on this subject have already been asked? Surely he had a duty to update his previous answer when it proved to be wrong. A Department of Social Security memo dated, I believe, 21 October sets out the rights of these students under various headings such as New Zealand students in Australia, students sponsored by ADAB, students on university scholarships and so on. I ask the Minister whether he will table a copy of this memo so we will all know what is going on and when overseas students come into our offices seeking some accurate answers we can pass on the information. Does the Minister expect that the confusion will continue for some further time while his Department attempts to sort out the health care mess created by his Government? I would like to know when the Government will get its act together on this matter.

A more recent memo dated, I believe, 2 November-only a few days ago-changes the eligibility of dependants of ADAB sponsored students. On 1 September dependants were not eligible for health cards. They had either to face the high cost of health care in this country from their own resourses or to take out health insurance with a private fund. Two months later the Government changed its mind and decided that dependants could have health cards after all. The 2 November memo said that section 19 (2) of the Health Insurance Act now ceases to apply to dependants of ADAB-sponsored students. I doubt that the students have been properly informed of this new access to health care in Australia. I doubt that Senator Chaney's departmental officers are aware of the change as they should be. I suspect that if last week these people decided to get a health card from the Department of Social Security in Hobart they would have been turned away.

When was the decision made to change this aspect of overseas students' rights? When were officers of the Department of Social Security, the Department of Health and the ADAB part of the Department of Foreign Affairs informed of the changes? I would like to know who first made the decision. Has an interdepartmental committee actually come to some final decision about the matter? Will there be any retrospectivity in relation to medical fees incurred during the two months that the students' dependants were not covered by health cards? That brings me to the point of the unrealistic demands on students who qualify for health cards. As I understand it-I have to put that qualification in the current unsatisfactory situation-ministerial approval was given for ADAB to meet the medical and hospital costs of families of sponsored students so long as prior approval was obtained for all treatment and the treatment is essential. Does that mean that the hospital or doctor involved has to check with ADAB before treatment is prescribed? If that is the case, who in ADAB gives the okay? Who decides whether the treatment is essential?

I note also that ADAB would not meet the cost of prescribing or purchasing contraceptives yet, by inference, any medical consultation or treatment for pregnancy-if conception occurred in Australia-would be covered by ADAB. To clarify that, ADAB would not pay the costs of a spouse who arrived in Australia more than three months pregnant but presumably would have met the cost of pregnancy which occurred in Australia, or if the pregnant woman arrived in Australia less than three months into her pregnancy. I understand that none of that applies from 1 November. The example serves only to highlight the lunacy of the whole system.

From 1 November ADAB ceased to meet the medical expenses of dependants. I understand that during the six month waiting period the Bureau will not cover costs either because of some misguided belief that this would render the dependants ineligible for a health card once the six month period had expired. Perhaps the Minister could explain whether this is in fact so. I seek assurance that all of these points I have raised will be investigated and tidied up, at least until a Labor government can get in and offer universal health care to all people in Australia. I am pleased to see that both the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Peter Baume), who is the Minister representing the Minister for Health, and the Minister for Social Security are in the chamber. I hope they will caucus sufficiently to get their act together to provide some answers.

He said:

SPEECH.PARA: Such an agreement, if known about, would have been totally unacceptable to the Government.
In the House of Representatives on 17 September this year-at page 1484 of Hansard for those who want the reference-he said:

I strongly support the contention that action should be taken by a government with a chairman of a statutory corporation or a subsidiary of a statutory corporation if it finds there is a breach of an international arrangement. Such action was undertaken by me immediately evidence came forward to that effect.

I repeat that he said 'immediately evidence came forward to that effect'. Tonight on the radio program PM both those claims were contradicted by Mr Jack McGuire, the managing director of Murray-Goulburn Co-operative Ltd, a man of impeccable reputation and unassailable integrity. In May 1976 Mr McGuire approached Minister Sinclair to see whether an Australian Dairy Corporation decision to refuse an export certificate at a price below the GATT minimum could be reversed. Did Mr Sinclair tell Mr McGuire that any breach of GATT would have been totally unacceptable to the Government, as he had claimed to the Senate Committee? No, he rang the Corporation chairman at midnight. As Mr McGuire put it:
He raised the matter on my behalf--
He means the matter of obtaining an export certificate for a contract at below the GATT price. As Mr McGuire said-I quote from the transcript:
I think he understood my problems.
That is the Minister. He continued:
He wouldn't have bothered I don't think to have rung the chairman if he wasn't sympathetic towards what I was saying,--
Mr President, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the transcript of the PM interview which comes from the Press Office of the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser).

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not seen it.
—Continue your remarks, Senator Walsh, while Senator Chaney looks at the document.

—Thank you, Mr President. Mr McGuire said that Minister Sinclair stopped short of actually ordering the chairman to issue a certificate. But he certainly leaned on him. This discussion took place in the context of a pre-existing breach of GATT by the Corporation itself on a sale to Mexico. Again the question arises: Did Mr Sinclair, as he claimed in Parliament on 17 September this year, take action against that breach-I use his words-'immediately evidence came forward'? No, he did nothing about the pre-existing breach and he encouraged the chairman, Webster, to condone, to authorise another breach.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Walsh, could I interrupt you for a moment? The Minister for Social Security has agreed to the incorporation of the document.

INTERJECT.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
New revelations in the hands of 'P.M.' in the Asia Dairy Industries affair could involve the former Minister for Primary Industry, Mr Ian Sinclair, in further controversy.

Simon Nasht: The major criticism surrounding Mr Sinclair in the Asia Dairy affair is that while Minister for Primary Industry, he failed to ensure that many doubtful practices within the Dairy Corporation at the time were firstly not identified and secondly, once discovered, weren't corrected. Mr Sinclair denied these claims, saying that in many cases, the Dairy Corporation and particularly its former chairman, Tony Webster, were keeping the problems from him. Mr Sinclair says that when he did become aware of the problem areas, he acted quickly to put a stop to them. One of the main areas of controversy surrounds contracts made by the Dairy Corporation which breached Australia's international trading obligations under the GATT-the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. In one particular instance in which the corporation was selling skimmed milk powder to the Philippines, the Senate enquiry which investigated these sales came to the damaging conclusion that it preferred the evidence of Mr Webster in these events rather than that of the Minister, Mr Sinclair. Mr Sinclair has attacked that finding strongly, and repeatedly defended himself by saying at no time would he consider contracts that meant GATT would have been breached. In evidence to the Senate enquiry, and I quote, ''Such an agreement, if known about, would have been totally unacceptable to the Government.'' And again, two weeks ago, he told Parliament in a carefully worded statement which centred on his responsibilities as the Minister, he said, ''it was not for me to do other than to direct that sales should not be made under the GATT arranged price. At no stage did I in any way accept that there should be international sales by the Dairy Corporation, its subsidiaries or any other private organisatoin that might have breached that direction.'' At the time in question, in the mid seventies, the world price for milk powder, was tumbling, leaving Australian producers with a huge excess of products which seriously threatened the industry. The price fell so quickly that contracts that we had overseas with buyers were taking our Government and private industry suppliers perilously close to the agreed GATT minimum price of $350 US a ton. In fact, the world price slumped below GATT in April 1976. Despite the fact that the price slumped below GATT in April and the Dairy Corporation was aware of this, Mr Sinclair has said the first time he was made aware of the possible treaty breaches was at the earliest, September that year, vital months later. However, ''P.M.'' has now information that Mr Sinclair was approached well before that date by a private company to approve a contract worth well over $5 million which was clearly in breach of the GATT minimum price, and despite his often repeated policy that the Government totally opposed such arrangements, he was prepared to take the approach to the Corporation chairman, Mr Webster. The context surrounding these events is important. In April 1976, Australia jointly negotiated with New Zealand to sell $5.25m worth of milk powder at a price perilously close and possibly under the GATT minimum because of deductions being made for freight charges. In any event, the money returned to the Dairy Corporation was nearly $10 under the agreed world minimum price, but in the desperate circumstances, it was approved. A report handed to the present Minister for Primary Industry, Mr Nixon, last month, reveals that recent attempts by the Corporation to investigate this sale had been frustrated because crucial files are now missing and those left behind, have, in the words of the Corporation's General Manager, Brian Norwood, been deliberately falsified to demonstrate that the GATT minimum pricing arrangement had not been breached. At that time, one of the Corporation's board members was the managing director of one of Australia's largest dairy companies, Murray Goulburn Co-operative, Mr Jack Macquire. As Mr Macquire recalls it, on the very same day the Corporation approved the Mexico deal, his company applied for approval to export another huge pile of skim milk powder at least as big as the Government contract. The price offered to Murray Goulburn was $340US, in breach of GATT, but returning to Australia almost exactly the same as the corporation contract at a time when the industry was facing a crisis situation. Despite this, the corporation refused to give export approval because of the GATT breach, leaving Mr Macquire furious. He told the board of management he was left with no option but to raise the sale with the Minister. Soon after, a meeting with Mr Sinclair was arranged for Macquire by Canberra lobbyist, Mr Peter Cullen. It took place late at night at approximately 11.30 after the Minister had finished in Parliament. Reports of what took place at that meeting varied, but what is clear is that Mr Macquire pushed strongly to have Murray Goulburn's offer approved, using the Corporation's Mexico contract to support his case. Despite the fact that Murray Goulburn's offer breached GATT, Mr Sinclair was sympathetic. So much so, that despite the late hour, he agreed to reach Mr Webster and discuss it with him while the meeting continued. Mr Webster was woken up at a Canberra motel, and on a conference phone so everyone present could hear, Mr Sinclair enquired from his chairman as to why approval had not been granted. At least twice during a substantial conversation, Mr Macquire recalls Webster telling the Minister that the contract could not be approved because it would infringe the Government's GATT policy. Mr Macquire does not believe that Mr Sinclair was directing the Corporation's chairman to breach GATT, but it raises serious questions as to why, in the light of the Government policy, Mr Sinclair pursued the matter. Also, in the light of the Minister's evidence to the Senate enquiry that he was not aware of GATT breaches by the Corporation until late in 1976 the matter of the Corporation's Mexico deal being raised also becomes significant as this meeting took place months earlier. Mr Macquire has agreed to talk to ''P.M.'' about what happened that night in Mr Sinclair's office.

Mr Macquire: We had an enquiry and a firm offer for powder that was less than the GATT price, and as is normal, the general manager of our company, I think it was, that submitted this to the Corporation, . . . inaudible . . ., it came up. I am not sure, exactly sure, if it was the same day or around about that time, for discussion and it got agreed to. The Corporation did not agree to make that sale on the basis that it was under GATT.
Question: But on the face of it, it was on terms that would have been very similar to the Mexican deal.

Mr Macquire: Well, that's true. It would have returned 50c a ton more to the pool than the Mexican deal, and I was a bit concerned about it because I had watched a lot of powder from Australia because of prices that I felt were set higher than world prices come down from, say, $600, right down, and I was concerned that this was a sale that as it returned to the pool this amount, and I could see in the next few months it was going to go low, and it finally did go lower . . . inaudible . . . powder was finally sold, disposed as stock food. I think for around about $180. Yes. I was concerned about it.

Question: You must have been pretty worried. The industry itself was going through a whole lot of turmoil at the time. Here was a deal-even if it was 15,000 tons at the GATT minimum, it was worth $5.25m, to you. It was a big deal. You were going to get a price, in fact, that returned more, than the Mexican contract.
Mr Macquire: That's true.
Question: It must have worried you . . .

Mr Macquire: It did worry me. It worried me to no end. It didn't really affect our company as a company because whatever these prices came, and that view included some sales made at 6.5, some 6.75, not much, but some, but it was an equalised thing, and we I think were aware the Government had agreed to underwrite at 300, but it seemed to me it was a shame to miss this sale.
Question: Do you think it was a bit unfair?

Mr Macquire: Well, I was concerned, and I felt it was. I made reference to that at the Corporation meeting, and I did say, well, I have got no alternative now but to go and discuss it with the Minister, which I came back either that night or the next morning to arrange an interview with the Minister to discuss it with him.
Question: So, you went to Canberra after that.
Mr Macquire: Yes, I did.
Question: And you hoped to see the Minister.
Mr Macquire: Yes.

Question: Now, I believe that meeting took place quite late that night because you had to wait for Mr Sinclair to finish his duties in the Parliament. Do you think he was sympathetic towards your problem? I mean, there was a mountain of skim milk powder in Australia at that time, and this was a deal worth perhaps more than $5 million, it was a way of at least starting to clear some of the backlog. Do you think he was sympathetic?

Mr Macquire: I think he was concerned of the whole skim milk powder position of which I would imagine he would be aware about and I think he was concerned, but I had seen fit from my position in our company to go up and discuss it with him. Sure, I think he was concerned, as we all were. We would have liked to have seen the skim milk powder flowing out and being disposed of at sensible prices and I expressed to him my concern that it had been sliding continually down. The stock on hand in the EEC-government stocks, trader stocks-all pointed up to that the price would ultimately go down lower.
Question: Yet the Corporation was able to make a deal, but your company wasn't.

Mr Macquire: Yes, but when we look at this in its true perspective-the Corporation-I was part of that decision, don't forget. We made what we believe to be a price that was not under GATT but it only came under GATT by a commission to the trader who organised a sale at this end. Now, that is the difference, really.
(Line from Canberra drops out)

Laurie Carmichael, the National Assistant Secretary of the AMWSU claimed today that a Federal Court judgment which stripped him of his position was part of an attempt to get rid of left wing leaders of Australian trade unions. Mr Carmichael's comments follow Mr Justice Shepherd's decision to declare last year's AMWSU null and void after he upheld allegations by Victorian branch officials of irregularities in the calling of the nominations. Mr Carmichael interviewed.

The Deputy Prime Minister said today that Australia should now think of putting behind them the deaths of five Australian journalists in east Timor in 1975. Mr Anthony told a meeting of the Australian/Indonesian Business Co-operation Committee that the tragic deaths of the journalists was still an obstacle to relations between the two countries. Mr Anthony interviewed.
Question: The obstacle seems to be, most particularly, with the Indonesians. Why are they so troubled by the fact that we continue to discuss this issue?

Mr Anthony: Well, it obviously is a sensitive matter with them, and I wouldn't have mentioned it other than I realised it is an impediment to our relationships and it was an occasion at the Australian/Indonesian business Co-operation Committee today to mention this and also I hope to get a message, in as tactful a way as I could to the Australian media who do play very heavily on the issue, and no doubt feel very strongly about it. But, I think one must realise that the incident did happen six years ago and today it is still causing trouble between our two countries. I think it is fair enough to say that these expressions that some of our journalists use-and I can understand their feeling-is provocative and doesn't help towards good relationships.

Question: So, really, isn't it. It is a toss between the importance we attach to economic and diplomatic relations with Indonesia and what journalists and the families of those journalists who died regard as an unsatisfactory explanation of what happened in East Timor.

Mr Anthony: Well, I don't want to use the word toss up. I think that is making trivia of it. It is a serious, but look. If you can't get resolution of it, and a lot of people have tried over the period of time, then is it to our advangage to keep on harping about it, knowing that it is impairing important relations with one of our closest and most significant neighbours.

Question: Can I make the point again though. I mean, even if there are sections of the media that do harp on this issue, it is for them a discussion that takes place within the context of Australia. One wonders why we allow ourselves to be so concerned about the importance attached to a domestic discussion by the Indonesians.
Mr Anthony: You are saying it really doesn't matter if we do make these noises.
Question: No, not at all.
Mr Anthony: Yes you are.
Question: I'm not. I didn't say that at all.

Mr Anthony: Well, we do know they are reacting to it. And we do know it is an obstacle to good relations between our two countries, and recognising that and understanding that, then we ought to act appropriately.
(Back to the previous Asia Dairy interview)

Simon Nasht: Before we lost the line, you will recall that the managing director of the Murray Goulburn Co-operative Mr Jack Macquire was discussing the events of a meeting he had in Mr Sinclair's office in 1976. He was seeking approval at that meeting for a bid contract of skim milk powder which had been refused by the Australian Dairy Corporation despite the fact that the Dairy Corporation had approved its own contract for a sale of a similar amount of powder to Mexico.
Question: You didn't think it was strange at all that the Minister should discuss a contract that was possibly in breach of GATT with the chairman of his corporation?
Mr Macquire: No, I don't think so.
Question: But you went there to try and get the contract pushed through, didn't you?

Mr Macquire: I went there to take up our case. What the hell was going to happen to this damn powder. Here was a chance of selling-yeah, sure. I was aware that the 340 was under GATT, but I knew every other bugger, countries were doing the same thing and what the hell . . .
Question: You thought it was sound business?

Mr Macquire: I thought it was just commonsense that we should otherwise we would be left on the damn, left behind by other countries doing these deals and they were doing it by no interest rate and 180 day interest rate at 1% and some countries-they were doing it by putting it on palettes and shrink wrapping it and all those damn things which to me added up to what's cost, lands in the warehouse of a buyer overseas. And I felt that this was-the hell with convention. Those were desperate days.
Question: Do you think Mr Sinclair understood your problems?

Mr Macquire: I think he understood my problems. He wouldn't have bothered I don't think to have rung the chairman if he wasn't sympathetic towards what I was saying, but-and I think that is why he went to the trouble to ring Webster-I can only summise that.
Question: He did discuss . . . .

Mr Macquire: I wouldn't say he overly pursued it. He raised the matter on my behalf, and a general discussion took place on powder and the likely possibility of sales of powder . . inaudible of Australia and what likely prices they could be sold at. Derivations were mentioned as a possible outlet for Japan, for school lunch programmes, stock feed possibilities in Japan were discussed, I think, with Webster and the Minister. And it sort of-the conversation finally sorted of drifted out. I said before when the Minister closed the phone down, he said, ''Look Jack, you heard what I said. You heard what Webster said. Nothing much I can do about it. You appreciate that for me to override the chairman of the corporation would be something-it would have to be very grave before one could do that sort of thing'' . . . inaudible . . . I said well thanks for trying to do something, Mr Minister . . .
Question: So, for then, the Minister left the matter, even though he understood that it was proposing a possible GATT breach, but he left the matter there?
Mr Macquire: He left the matter there and I say again the sale never went through.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr McGuire's evidence establishes beyond doubt that Mr Sinclair misled the Senate Committee in his letter dated 16 March, and he misled the Parliament in his 17 September statement. According to Mr Sinclair, the sanctions of both are, of course, identical. Under any previous Prime Minister his resignation would have been demanded by now. This veteran of assorted villanies now has yet another of a multiplicity of scars, any of which under any previous Prime Minister would have disqualified him forever from a ministerial position.

SPEECH.PARA: It may be appropriate now to look back in history at various statements made by the Prime Minister on the question of ministerial propriety. In the House of Representatives in July 1975 he said:

Ten per cent or even 50 per cent of the truth is as good a way of misleading this Parliament and the Australian people as a downright lie. A half truth, a partial answer, and the slipping over of the full facts are a misleading of this Parliament . . .
In a radio broadcast on 12 March 1978 the Prime Minister said:

One of my Government's first promises when we were elected just over two years ago was to restore the integrity and honesty of government. Without integrity-without the appearance and reality of integrity-no Government can hope to have the confidence of the people or the trust of the people.
My Government has demonstrated again and again our fundamental commitment to restoring integrity to public administration in Australia. Our record in this regard is without parallel in history.

And I certainly agree. Nobody who has looked at the record would dispute that the record of this Government on the subject of ministerial responsibility is without parallel in history. On another occasion, on the question of ministerial responsibility, as quoted by Mr Kerin, in the House of Representatives on 29 October and recorded on page 2691 of Hansard, the Prime Minister stated:

It is certainly true that Ministers cannot be aware of everything that occurs in their departments . . . But if a major blunder occurred in a department, of real importance to Australia, and if the minister were unaware of it, that minister should take responsibility for the mistakes of his department and offer to resign.

That is a statement which has grievous implications for the present Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon), if it is to be taken seriously. The previous Minister for Primary Industry of course, as I have already stated, under any previous Prime Minister would have been disqualified for life from ministerial rank. Mr McGuire's revelations have implications going well beyond establishing the fact that Mr Sinclair misled the Parliament. For example, a Department of Primary Industry officer was present at the May 1976 meeting to which Mr McGuire referred and must have been aware of the phone call to Mr Webster. Why was no memo written and recorded in the Department of Primary Industry files? Or was a memo written, filed and culled when the Department's files were subsequently sanitised, as they were?

This Murray-Goulburn deal, Mr McGuire stated tonight, ultimately fell through for reasons he did not state. But what other sales by private firms in that period from April to November 1976 at prices breaching GATT were discussed or authorised by the Minister, by the Chairman of the Corporation, and by other people? Is it not fortuituous that the export certificates for that very period are not in the Corporation files and that those export certificates alone are missing? The certificates for all products other than skim milk powder, for all exports by the Corporation trading as a principal, and for skim milk powder by private companies, for every period other than that crucial period are in the Corporation files. Only the certificates for that period are missing. Is that not fortuitous? Who had access to those certificates? Who has them now?

On 14 October I gave the Senate details of a meeting and phone call very similar to that now revealed by Mr McGuire. Needless to say, Mr Sinclair denied it in Parliament the next day. That information was given to me by a source that I know to be reliable. I also know the answer to the mystery of the fortuitously missing files. The files have been taken and are held by the former Chairman of the Dairy Corporation, Mr Webster. A typically sordid National Country Party deal has been arranged under which Mr Webster is guaranteed immunity from prosecution. In return, Mr Webster will not drop the missing documents which would further incriminate a guilty Minister. It is a matter for some reasonable speculation whether those files will survive any longer. Of course, there is always the nagging doubt, is there not, that somebody else had a photocopy of them before they were removed from the Corporation file. That is probably the best guarantee of all that the originals currently in the custody of Mr Webster will not be destroyed, as I am reliably informed other written evidence from the Department of Primary Industry was destroyed.

A statement was to have been made today by Senator Chaney. Unfortunately, that did not occur because of lack of time, and I do not blame Senator Chaney at all. He was to have stated when incorporating the speech made a couple of weeks ago by Mr Nixon, appropriately adjusted for the Senate, of course, that the Government believes that the documents now before the Parliament clearly demonstrate that the Government has tackled this issue both properly and thoroughly. It is now very clear from Mr McGuire's evidence alone that that is not so. The Government has not tackled this issue properly and thoroughly. It has not even covered up for previous and present National Country Party Ministers properly and thoroughly, much less exposed all the facts to the public, revealed all the facts to the public, properly and thoroughly.
I want to raise briefly a few other matters. On the question of the non-prosecution of Mr Webster, Mr Nixon stated:

The Australian Federal Police, the Crown Solicitor and Counsel are all of the view that there is insufficient evidence available capable of establishing beyond reasonable doubt the commission of any criminal offence by Mr Webster.

Firstly, Mr Nixon, in making that statement, reversed the chronological sequence. The original opinion to that effect came from some obscure Melbourne lawyer called Peter Clark, whom nobody seems to have heard of. It was endorsed by the Solicitor-General, who I think my learned legal colleague described a couple of months ago as a hired gun, and was accepted, at least in part, by the Australian Federal Police. There are many other aspects of the investigation and the presentation of the papers, not the least of which is the fact that the police report of 11 March was not tabled, on the advice of-guess who?-Lindsay Duthie, the Secretary to the Department of Primary Industry. This can be seen in document 110 of those that were tabled by Minister Nixon a fortnight ago. This is the same Lindsay Duthie who organised dry runs of Senate Estimates committees for all the first assistant secretaries in the Department on the morning before the Estimates committees were held just to make sure that they got their lines right and who, significantly, kept Mr Wallace right away from the Estimates committees.

The police investigation portion of the reports which Mr Nixon tabled a fortnight ago have not touched these heavy issues: Who pinched the export certificates from the Corporation's files? Who falsified the records of the Corporation's sales as stated by Mr Norwood in a letter of 28 September which is document 111? Was it the former Corporation employees Peter Foster and L. Page as alleged on the program AM on 28 October? If it was Messrs Foster and Page, were they acting on Mr Webster's instructions? Was Mr Webster acting, if not on the instructions of Minister Sinclair, at least with the knowledge of Minister Sinclair?

I could go on at great length about defects and deficiencies in the investigation which has so far been conducted. Of course, the greatest defect of all about the investigation which Mr Nixon has said will continue is that it is to be conducted by the Department of Primary Industry. Mr Nixon has said that the Department which was the subject of the inquiry will continue the inquiry and finalise all the outstanding matters. Apparently he expects us to be satisfied with that.

There is one other very curious matter to which I wish to draw attention in the documents filed by Mr Nixon. I could make a lot of other comments; I hope that I get an opportunity at a more appropriate time to do so. I mention in passing that the documents that were tabled were not in fact numbered. They had an index. Document No. 75 in the index-if anyone wants to go through the documents, as many people have, and number all the documents sequentially, it is No. 75-is a letter from Mr McCartney to Mr Nixon dated 18 August 1980 which is stamped 'Confidential'. What fascinates me about this document is that it is photocopied back and front-two pages-and the two pages have been typed by different typewriters. There is absolutely no doubt that the two pages have been typed by different typewriters. Moreover-I am not certain of this as I am not an expert on the subject but I will be seeking expert opinion on this-it appears to me that the words 'Page 2', which is written on the top of the reverse side of a single sheet of paper has been typed on the typewriter which typed the first page and not the typewriter which typed the second page.

There may, of course, be a perfectly innocent explanation for this but there are other possibilities, especially when one looks at the cramped style of what is purported to be page one as compared with the open typing style of what is purported to be page two. One of the possibilities is that this letter originally may have consisted of three pages. Pages one and two may have been retyped and put on to a single sheet, and then the same typewriter was used to type the words, 'Page two' over what could originally have been page three of the letter. If that should be the case, it obviously opens the possibility that sections of the original letter may have been deleted. If there were deleted, I presume that the Government would be running a grave risk to have done so without some consultation with Mr McCartney. Perhaps it decided it would take the punt for all the Country Party's faults. Nobody who has looked at its record over the years could ever accuse it of having been unwilling to take political gambles.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is the date of that letter?

—The date of the letter is 18 August 1980. As I said, there may be a perfectly innocent explanation for something which, on the face of it, looks very suspicious. If there is, I hope that such an explanation will be forthcoming very soon.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not intend to say much more tonight. It was quite clear to me, even before Mr McGuire's revelations on PM tonight, that there is still a great deal of information concerning this Dairy Corporation scandal that needs to be flushed out. Following Mr McGuire's revelations there is absolutely no doubt that a great deal of information is to be flushed out. I trust that at some time in the future a means of flushing out that information will be the subject of deliberation by the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not wish to go into any detail in relation to the matters that Senator Walsh has referred to but I wish to support, just briefly, the action taken by the Government to investigate this matter further. I suggest that it is not entirely unreasonable that the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon) would have the Department of Primary Industry investigate and report in relation to some of the matters. Whether that report is finally accepted or whether it is the subject of further discussion or committee consideration, if it is published, is a matter upon which this chamber can inform itself and make a judgment at a later date. But I resist the innuendo that there is something unreasonable or impossible in that course of action being taken. I do not want to create further debate at any length in relation to the matter. I believe that the reaction of the Government to date in relation to the report on the Australian Dairy Corporation, Asia Dairy Industries and other Asian subsidiaries-a report of one of the committees of the Senate-has been both prompt and detailed.

SPEECH.PARA: I agree that a number of matters still require explanation and that a number of matters possibly require further investigation, and I do not want to go beyond saying that. So far as the letter to which Senator Walsh referred is concerned, he was not a member of the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations at the time it investigated the Australian Dairy Corporation and Asia Dairy Industries. Therefore, he would not have available to him the material that was available to the Committee. Having had my attention drawn to that letter I will see how it compares with the material which the Committee has and see whether anything further needs to be said in relation to it. I do not wish either to stir a debate or to exacerbate the matter in any way but rather to acknowledge some of the points that have been made and leave it at that for the moment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Rae for his comments which to some extent pick up points that I wish to make on this matter. The only additional point I wish to make relates to the statement which was put down in the House of Representatives on 29 October. It was hoped that it would be put down contemporaneously in this place but that did not happen because of pressure of Senate business. It was hoped that it would be put down today during the 90 minutes allocated to tabling papers but that again was precluded through pressure of other business. The statement makes it quite clear that there are still concerns about certain elements of this matter, including elements raised by Senator Walsh in the Senate tonight. The statement, of course, predates the interview on PM this evening which was referred to by Senator Walsh and the transcript of which was incorporated in Hansard. I did not hear the broadcast and I have not had a chance as yet to read the transcript of it. I will quote from part of the statement which was put down by the Minister for Primary Industry, Mr Nixon, and which was to have been put down in similar terms by me.

SPEECH.PARA: First, I just draw to the Senate's attention the fact that the Government has made a very early response and therefore not yet a complete response to the matters raised by the Senate Committee. As was pointed out by the Minister for Primary Industry, it is generally accepted policy that the Government undertakes to give a detailed response to the recommendations of parliamentary committee reports within six months. In line with this policy, the Minister will be requesting the Auditor-General to report on the Holland Milk Products Inc. rebate arrangement and his Department to report on the ownership of the Dairying Industry Stabilisation Fund, which is irrelevant to the matters raised tonight in time for the Government to respond further to the Senate Committee report during the 1982 autumn sittings of Parliament. By that time, the Government should also be in a position to comment on the general issues of principle, which again are not relevant to the points raised by Senator Walsh tonight.

What is relevant, however, is the fact that, as was pointed out in the House of Representatives some weeks ago now, the advice from the Australian Dairy Corporation is to the effect that it is not possible to determine precisely whether the actual net f.o.b. price was in breach of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade minimum price for skim milk powder.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is the next case.

—Yes. There are two aspects of concern and these matters were adverted to by Mr Nixon some weeks ago. I think they are basically the substance of the matters which were again raised by Senator Walsh in the Senate tonight. I quote from the statement:

SPEECH.PARA: The first relates to conclusions reached by the Management of the ADC that a deliberate effort had been made by past ADC Management to establish incorrect records in order to be able to demonstrate that the GATT minimum price had not been breached.

The second is the inability of ADC Management to locate certain documents in respect of this matter. The report states that during the period in question the then Chairman of the ADC, Mr Webster, abolished the central filing system. While that system has since been restored, the earlier action has resulted in difficulty being experienced in locating some documents relevant to that period.

I draw to the attention of the Senate-what has been said by Senator Walsh may be thought by some honourable senators who have not read the statement put down in the House of Representatives to be a matter of discovery-the fact that the statement put down by Mr Nixon on behalf of the Government does advert to the fact that documents are missing. Mr Nixon went on to say in the statement that he had asked his Department to investigate all aspects of the report and that he would make further information available at the appropriate time. In that context, I express agreement with the view put forward by Senator Rae a few minutes ago that that is an appropriate initial course to be taken, and whether any further steps need to be taken is a matter to be judged in light of what that investigation shows. But to suggest at this stage that there is something sinister in taking that step is to presume a situation whereas, as Senator Walsh himself has conceded, there can be innocent explanations for some of these matters.

I do not think it will assist the Senate, the Australian public or anybody else if I simply repeat what has been put down in a statement in the other place. I have referred to the most relevant passages of the statement, in answer to the matters raised by Senator Walsh tonight, which indicate that the fundamental fact which is central to the concern expressed by Senator Walsh, namely that there are missing documents and so on, is something which is on record and which is the subject of investigation. The significance of the statements by Mr McGuire on PM tonight is something on which I cannot comment. I have not read the statements and I certainly have not had the chance to put them in the context of the information that has been put down. I will have the opportunity, no doubt, to do that at a later time in the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 10.59 p.m.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Federal Court of Australia: Industrial Division

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry, upon notice, on 19 August 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the total amount of land owned by foreign investors in Australia.
(2) Is the Minister for Primary Industry aware that this amount is rapidly increasing, to the extent that during the past 4 years foreign interests have bought 13.8 million hectares of rural land.

(3) Will the Minister confirm that at its meeting in Darwin on 3 August 1981, the Australian Agricultural Council failed to approve the appointment of an agricultural member of the Foreign Investment Review Board.

(4) In the circumstances, will the Minister advise the Council to reconsider its decision or, failing that, does he agree that a Senate Select Committee should be established to inquire into the extent of foreign ownership of rural land, and the effects which such ownership has had on Australian agriculture.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industry has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Commonwealth is in consultation, through the Foreign Investment Review Board, with State governments on measures that might be introduced to establish a register of beneficial foreign ownership of rural property because information is not at present available on the total amount of land owned by foreign investors in Australia.

(2) Foreign Investment Review Board statistics made available to my Department by the Treasury indicate that there has been a substantial increase in new investment by foreign residents in recent years, part of which has been attributable to intending migrants. Details are set out in the attached figures. These figures relate to proposals approved by the Government; they do not indicate whether all the transactions actually took place nor is statistical information available on sales by foreign interests to Australian residents of previously foreign owned land. This information will not be available until comprehensive procedures are established, should the State governments decide to introduce such measures in pursuance of the consultation now proceeding.

(3) I confirm that at its meeting in Darwin on 3 August 1981 the Australian Agricultural Council did not adopt a recommendation put forward by New South Wales to seek the appointment of a Council nominee to the Foreign Investment Review Board. When the Board was set up in 1976 it was not intended that the members of it represent particular sectors of industry and commerce.

Council considered the matter and agreed as an appropriate alternative, that there should be a co-ordinated Commonwealth/State approach to the question of foreign investment in rural land and, inter alia, that the Board should continue to consult the States in respect of all major proposals for foreign investment in rural land.

This approach recognises that while the Commonwealth has overall responsibility for assessing foreign investment proposals, the States have responsibility for matters such as land administration and agricultural production.

(4) Councils' decision was made only three months ago and I see no reason to reopen the matter so soon after its consideration. However, it is open to another member or members of Council to request reconsideration of the decision should they wish to do so.
It is for the Senate itself to decide whether it wishes to conduct an inquiry into the extent of foreign ownership of rural land and related matters.

It will be of interest to the honourable senator, however, that the Council also agreed that the States would co-operate with the Commonwealth in obtaining a factual basis on which to assess the extent and effects of foreign investment in rural land.

The tables presented below provide information on proposals by foreign interests for the acquisition of Australian rural properties since 1 April 1976 that have been approved by the Government under its foreign investment policy. These statistics exclude proposals which have been approved but which the Foreign Investment Review Board has been advised (as at 30 June 1981) will not be implemented.

It should be noted that the $350,000 exemption threshold for the acquisition of real estate normally would not apply to proposals for foreign interests to acquire Australian rural properties as most rural properties constitute businesses within the meaning of the Foreign Takeovers Act. QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 27 August 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister for Communications planning to remove controls over the supply of telephone equipment.

(2) Does this mean that Telecom Australia no longer will be able to enforce a policy of preference for local manufacturers of equipment such as handsets, loudspeaker phones, pushbutton dialling equipment and so on.
(3) Is the Minister aware that this, in turn, will threaten the future of an industry worth $230m employing 8,000 Australians.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Committee of Inquiry into Telecommunications Services in Australia, has been directed to examine the question of supply of telecommunications equipment in Australia, as part of its review of the extent to which the private sector could be more widely involved in the provision of telecommunications services.

In addition, Mr Malcolm King, a consultant to the Department of Communications and Member of the Committee of Inquiry, has already carried out a preliminary analysis of the relationship between Telecom Australia and suppliers of telephone attachments in the private sector, including the opportunity for Australian manufacturing industries to compete in the design and manufacture of telephone equipment. This work will be directly relevant to the consideration of the Davidson Inquiry.
I expect the question of controls over the supply of telephone equipment will be fully canvassed, therefore, by the Davidson Inquiry.

(2) In the past, Telecom has not had a monopoly over the supply of telephone equipment although it has supplied a large proportion of the market. In supplying its part of the market, Telecom has had to take account of the Government's former policy on local preferences and its own commercial judgment on factors such as security of supply and technical compatibility with the telecommunications network. I expect Telecom will continue to make decisions based on a variety of considerations in the future.

(3) The Government appreciates the importance of the Australian telecommunications equipment industry. This concern for the future of the local industry is reflected in the Government's direction to the Davidson Committee to have particular regard to the scope for and ability of Australian industries to compete and participate in the telecommunications equipment industry.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 9 September 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Attorney-General aware of the alarm expressed by teachers and schools throughout Australia over the implementation of the Copyright Amendment Act 1980, under which teachers and their schools can be held liable for copying and distributing to students full texts of certain educational matter covered by copyright.

(2) Does the Attorney-General agree that while teachers respect the rights of copyright owners, they still have a right to provide their students with the best educational material available and that in some instances that necessitates the copying and distribution to students of full texts of works covered by copyright that may not be commercially available in sufficient quantity at a given time.

(3) Will the Attorney-General consider a system of blanket licensing, funded by the Commonwealth in respect of copyright fees, or reimbursement or subsidisation of education copyright fees, so that teachers can maintain their instructional standards without the threat of prosecution for doing so, since a teacher's workload already extends well into his private time and more time will be wasted keeping records for the statutory licence procedure.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Acting Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Concern has been expressed in regard to the Copyright Amendment Act 1980. In the first instance that concern had been based upon the assumption that the Act had introduced a new liability as suggested in Part (1) of the question. In fact, liability for infringement had been provided for by the Copyright Act and was not introduced by the amendment. The Copyright Amendment Act 1980 extends to educational institutions a new statutory licence to make multiple copies of some categories of works without the need previously required of obtaining the permission of copyright owners. That statutory licence is subject to those insitutions meeting claims for equitable remuneration by copyright owners except where the Act provides for free copying. Since that has become better understood, concern expressed has related to particular provisions of the amending Act. The Attorney-General's Department is monitoring the operation of those provisions.

(2) The Copyright Amendment Act 1980 does recognise that teachers have special needs for making educational material available to students. Section 53B (2) provides that the copyright in a work is not infringed by the making of copies of the whole or a part of that work by an educational institution for the teaching purposes of that institution. Section 53B (5) qualifies this by providing that sub-section (2) does not apply in relation to copies of more than a reasonable portion of a work that has been separately published unless the person making the copies is satisfied, after reasonable investigation, that copies (other than second hand copies) of the work cannot be obtained within a reasonable time at an ordinary commercial price.

(3) The proposal for a system of blanket licensing was very extensively considered before the amendments embodied in the Copyright Amendment Act 1980 were formulated. The proposal was rejected by the Franki Committee on photocopying and was opposed by the Working Party of the Australian Education Council. It is understood that that remains the position of the Australian Education Council. A blanket licensing scheme under which the Commonwealth was required to fund the payment of remuneration to copyright owners would not be appropriate.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Keeffe Sen J.B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Trade and Resources, upon notice, on 9 September 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Can the Minister inform the Parliament which company(s) own the silica mining complex at Cape Flattery, Cape York, North Queensland.
(2) What royalties are currently being paid to the Queensland Government and what is the total amount of royalties paid since the mine was first opened.
(3) Have any royalties or funds of other sorts been paid to the Hopevale Mission; if so, what is the total amount.
(4) What steps are taken to rehabilitate the mine area and has the Commonwealth Government concerned itself with the protection of the environment on the site.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Trade and Resources has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The silica sand mining complex at Cape Flattery, Cape York, North Queensland is owned 100% by Mitsubishi Corporation.
(2) and (3) The Department of Trade and Resources has been informed by the Queensland Department of Mines that:

The current royalty rate levied on silica sand produced in Queensland is 2 per cent of the f.o.b. value or 25c per tonne whichever is the greater amount. Actual payments from any individual operation are confidential. The Department is not aware of any amounts that may have been paid to Hopevale Mission.

(4) Responsibility for regulation of all mining operations on the site rests with the Queensland Government. As far as I am aware, there are no matters concerning mining at Cape Flattery which require Commonwealth decisions.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Veterans' Affairs upon notice, on 9 September 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Was a decision announced in the 1981-82 Budget Speech to extend the service pension to Australian mariners who served in a theatre of war during the 1939-45 war from February 1982.
(2) What is the reason for delaying the extension until next February.
(3) How many mariners will qualify under this extended eligibility.
(4) Why was the extended eligibility not granted to mariners from Allied countries.
(5) Will the Government reconsider its decision not to include mariners from Allied countries in the extended eligibility.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.

(2) The decision to extend service pension to Australian mariners who served in a 'theatre of war' in the 1939-45 War has yet to become law. The administrative details of establishing identity and eligibility of Australian mariners need to be resolved and the delay of the extension until February 1982 was mainly to permit sufficient time to finalise these arrangements. Other extensions of service pension eligibility have had effect from February or later following the Budget announcement.

(3) The exact number of Australian mariners who will be eligible is not known nor is it known how many will apply for the service pension. The best estimate that can be made is that approximately 3,400 mariners and 2,000 wives may satisfy age and income tests for service pension.

(4) In considering the competing demands of various groups for the extension of Repatriation benefits, the Government decided that extension of service pension eligibility would, at this time, be limited to Australian mariners.
(5) The Government has no plans at present to extend service pension to mariners from Allied countries.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Federated Millers and Mill Employees Association

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mulvihill Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 15 September 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What were the legal firms which represented the various factions involved in a case before Mr Justice Evatt in the Federal Court on 23 June 1981 involving members of the Federated Millers and Mill Employees Association, pursuant to section 171C and 171D of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act 1904.
(2) What were the total costs involved.
(3) Have any of the parties sought legal aid.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Acting Attorney-General has supplied the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The proceedings apparently referred to in the question are Adler V. Dowdell, Nielson and Federated Millers and Mill Employees Association of Australia. The solicitor for the applicant was Messrs Maurice May and Co., 321 Pitt Street, Sydney. The solicitor for the respondents was Messrs David Landa Stewart and Co., 187 Macquarie Street, Sydney.
(2) I am not aware of the costs.

(3) In so far as the question would extend to applications to the Australian Legal Aid Office it would be inappropriate to provide an answer having regard to the established concern of that office to observe, in relation to persons who seek its assistance, the confidentiality of which attaches to the relationship of solicitor and client. Successive Attorneys-General have taken the view (see, for example, answers to Senate Question No. 965, Hansard, 28 October 1981) that in ordinary circumstances an applicant for legal aid from the office has the right to have kept confidential not only the grant or refusal of aid but, also, the very fact that an application has been made. This approach has not been adopted to the same extent in relation to applications for assistance, under the Conciliation and Arbitration Act and, accordingly, I am able to say that no application has been made for the grant of financial assistance under that Act.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Trade and Resources, upon notice, on 23 September, 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Have Rylance Collieries and Brickworks Pty Ltd applied for a licence to export coal to be mined at Redbank Plains (mining lease 587-surface).
(2) Is the Minister for Trade and Resources aware that the Redbank Plains mine will severely adversely affect existing local suburban communities.
