ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Trade and Resources has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Because of commercial considerations, it is not the practice to disclose whether or not particular proposals have been submitted either to my Department in relation to the granting of export approval or to the Foreign Investment Review Board for examination under the Government's foreign investment policy.

(2) I am aware of expressions of community concern relating to mining in the Redbank Plains area. There are procedures established under the Environment protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974, to facilitate consideration of such concerns.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, upon notice, on 13 October 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) On what date did the Federal Government, with the Tasmanian State Government, commission Mr Peter Waterman to produce the South West Tasmanian Resources Survey.
(2) On what date did the Federal Government receive the final survey document.
(3) What was the total cost of the survey and what costs accrued to the Federal Government for the survey.
(4) Does the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment agree that the report is the most comprehensive ever undertaken on the region.
(5) Why has the Minister not presented the report to the Parliament.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Home Affairs and Environment has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) On 18 February 1977, the Commonwealth Government entered into a formal agreement with the Tasmanian Government under the States Grants (Nature Conservation) Act 1974 for a survey of the resources of the State's South West. The South West Tasmania Resources Survey Steering Committee, which consisted of Mr P. Murrell (Chairman), Director-Tasmanian National Parks and Wildlife Service, Professor J. D. Ovington, Director-Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service and Dr P. Tyler, Reader-Department of Botany, University of Tasmania, commissioned Mr Peter Waterman to lead the survey.

(2) Although I received unofficial copies of the report in mid August, it was not until 14 October 1981 that I officially received two copies of the report from the Chairman of the South West Tasmania Resources Survey Steering Committee in accordance with Section 5 (2) of the Commonwealth-State Agreement.

(3) The Federal Government allocated $351,322 to Tasmania for the conduct of the survey, the total cost of which was $450,732. The Tasmanian Government also provided services and resources which were not costed.

(4) The survey described and evaluated the natural resources of the South West, including wilderness values, in order to identify those attributes of the area which may require reservation as a National Park. The Survey published over 60 discussion, occasional and working papers and contains sufficient data to enable preparation of regional management plans by the Tasmanian Government to commence.
(5) The report was presented to the Parliament on 20 October 1981.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry, upon notice, on 13 October 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Are fishermen in Queensland permitted by the Queensland Fish Board to export only 40 per cent of their prawn catch to Japan, while seafood processing companies which operate outside the orbit of the Queensland Fish Board are premitted to export some 70 per cent of their prawns to Japan.
(2) Are primary producers in Queensland being discriminated against in favour of manufacturing industry.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industry has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Not as far as I am aware, although the practices of the Queensland Fish Board are a matter for the State Government. As far as the Commonwealth Government is concerned I can advise that an export permit is issued for all prawns submitted for inspection which meet the requirements of the Exports (Fish) Regulations. The regulations are applied uniformly irrespective of whether the product is processed by the Queensland Fish Board or other processors.
(2) I am not aware of any such discrimination.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry, upon notice, on 13 October 1981:

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Australian Dairy Corporation: Public Relations Consultants

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry, upon notice, on 15 October 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did the Minister for Primary Industry say in answer to Question on Notice No. 31 (Hansard, 24 February 1981, page 36) that Geoff and Mary Wilson were then currently retained by the Australian Dairy Corporation as public relations consultants.

(2) Did the Department of Primary Industry inform Senator Walsh, in a written answer provided on 14 October 1981 to a question asked at Senate Estimates Committee H on 22 September 1981, that the Wilson consultancy had been terminated in April 1980.
(3) Which of these conflicting answers is correct.
(4) Will the Minister explain how it is possible for either himself or his Department to supply incorrect information in answer to Senate questions.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industry has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.

(2) The Department of Primary Industry advised that the Wilson consultancy was not currently employed by the Australian Dairy Corporation and that the last consultancy arrangement terminated in April 1980.

(3) and (4) The apparent conflict arises because the broadest possible interpretation was placed on the term 'currently retained' when replying to the question on notice on 24 February 1981 in order that comprehensive information was supplied to the honourable senator.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry, upon notice, on 28 October 1981:

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 20 August 1981 (Hansard, page 145) Senator MacGibbon asked me a question, without notice, in my capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs in the Senate. The question concerned press speculation about the method and cost of an evaluation of the objectives and implementation of the report of the Review of Post-arrival Programs and Services to Migrants (the Galbally report).

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs has supplied the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

(1) The report of the Review of Post-arrival Programs and Services to Migrants-the Galbally report-was the most thorough review of services to migrants this country has undertaken. In accepting the recommendations of the report (30 May 1978) Hansard p. 2727) the Government accepted a commitment to an independent evaluation of implementation.

(2) In the three years since the Prime Minister tabled the report, the Government has significantly expanded and improved the post-arrival programs and services available to migrants. It is timely to conduct an evaluation of the objectives and implementation of the report, to ensure that taxpayers' money is properly spent. This is consistent with the Review of Commonwealth Functions decisions and with our firm commitment to migrants.

(3) I should point out that the Australian Institute of Multicultural Affairs (AIMA) is an independent statutory body established to advise the Government on matters relating to multicultural affairs. It can readily bring together the skills, expertise and access to the ethnic communities necessary to carry out a thorough evaluation. No other body is in a better position to conduct this sort of evaluation.
(4) The evaluation will-
(a) assess the effectiveness of the implementation of the Galbally report's recommendations;
(b) determine whether the report's overall objectives are being achieved;
(c) determine whether the report's objectives and recommendations remain valid; and
(d) recommend whether the objectives and recommendations should be pursued in the future and what changes (if any) should be made.

(5) The government is committed to funding those Galbally programs which evaluation demonstrates are both needed and effective. The evaluation process will commence shortly and consultations with interested parties, including State Governments and ethnic communities, will be part of the process.

(6) There is no substance in the newspaper report that an additional $460,000 is to be provided for the evaluation. Most of the cost will be met from existing funding and other resources and additional funds of up to $150,000 will also be available.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 9 September 1981 (Hansard, pages 558 and 564), Senator Lewis and Senator Teague asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Education, questions without notice concerning the consolidation of State College of Victoria, Hawthorn and the Institute of Early Childhood Development.

ANSWER.PARA: I indicated that I would refer the matter to the Minister for Education who has provided the following statement:

The States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) legislation presently before the Parliament provides for sufficient funds to meet the recurrent grants for all colleges of advanced education in the 1982-84 triennium if acceptable proposals for consolidation are received before the end of this year.

I am aware of the special contribution made by both SCV Hawthorn and the Institute of Early Childhood Development to the preparation of specialist teachers. The Government's policy will enable these particular contributions to be maintained within the level of resources available to advanced education.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 22 September 1981 (Hansard, page 849) Senator Jones asked me a question, without notice, in my capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry in the Senate. The honourable senator's question was as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Is it true that the Department of Primary Industry requests other departments to undertake species tests on behalf of that Department? If so, what direction has been given to any department and which departments have undertaken those tests? Has any direction been given in relation to species tests of meats contained in export cartons? What tests have been undertaken to determine types of meat-in particular, kangaroo, buffalo, horse and donkey? Can the Minister inform the Senate of the time and date of such tests?
The Minister for Primary Industry has supplied me with the following information:

Following the detection in the United States of America of substitution in meat exported from Australia the Department of Primary Industry introduced a species testing program for beef products exported to the United Staes of America. Assistance was obtained from a number of laboratories both Commonwealth, State and private, throughout Australia, with ability to undertake the required test. Two tests were used; an agar gel diffusion test (AGDT), most commonly, and an iso-electric focusing test (IEFT), on a limited number of samples. Procedures to be followed in the AGDT were advised to participating laboratories in early September and the assistance of the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation Division of Meat Research obtained to evaluate these and other candidate tests in terms of reliability, sensitivity, specificity, simplicity and cost so that standardised procedures may be drawn up. The test methods for the ADGT which are in routine use have been approved by the United States Department of Agriculture as have the sampling procedures being employed.
The laboratories that have performed species tests on export meat for the Department of Primary Industry are:
New South Wales-Australian Government Analytical Laboratory (AGAL);
Queensland-Quantum Ltd, Government Chemical laboratory, Department of Health, Queensland (State Government);
Victoria-Veterinary Research Institute, Department of Agriculture (State Government), AGAL;
South Australia-Department of Science and Technology (State Government), AGAL;
Western Australia-AGAL;
Tasmania-Mount Pleasant Veterinary Laboratory, Department of Agruculture, (State Government).

From 14 September the population sampling program on meat being held in store for export to the United States of America was progressively replaced by a planned program of statistical sampling and testing of meat from all registered export establishments. Export meat from any species and for all destinations is included in this testing program. Detailed directions have been given to inspection staff on the statistical procedure to be used in selecting samples for testing and over 2500 samples per week are now being tested.

ANSWER.TO.QWN.TITLE: Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting: Police Activities

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 23 September 1981 (Hansard page 889), Senator Keeffe asked the following question, without notice, of the Attorney-General:

ANSWER.PARA: Was the Attorney-General responsible for directing an alleged member of the Victoria Police Force, a Detective Sergeant Fisher, and another police colleague to visit the Victorian Aboriginal Health Service, 136 Gertrude Street, Fitzroy, at approximately 1.30 p.m. on Friday, 18 September 1981, for the purpose of interviewing Mr Gary Foley, a member of the Aboriginal Health Services? Did the Minister also direct police to carry out active surveillance of Mr Bruce McGuinness, another respected black activist, who is the national director of NAAIHO-the National Aboriginal and Islander Health Organisation? Is this part of the campaign initiated by the Australian Government to prevent Aborigines from meeting and talking to representatives of black African countries? Is the Minister aware also that, as far as I can ascertain, no Detective Sergeant Fisher is a regular member of the police force in Victoria? As the Australian Government is responsible for security arrangements at the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting and has taken the extreme measure of having members of the Australian Federal Police sworn in as members of the Victorian Police, can he advise whether Detective Sergeant Fisher is in fact a member of the Australian Federal Police at other times? Can the Minister also advise whether members of the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation and other security organisations have been sworn in as Victorian security officers during the currency of the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting?
The Minister for Administrative Services has provided the following answer to those aspects of the honourable senator's question relating to the Australian Federal Police:

I have had enquiries made into this matter and am advised by the Australian Federal Police that it has no member by the name of Detective Sergeant Fisher. I am further informed that no members of the Australian Federal Police visited the Victorian Aboriginal Health Service at the address indicated on 18 July 1981.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 13 October 1981 (Hansard, page 1090) Senator Robertson asked me a question, without notice, in my capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry in the Senate. His question concerned the operation of prawn trawlers in northern Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Primary Industry has supplied me with the following additional information:

On 4 November 1976 applications were invited from persons who satisfied any one of five published criteria to fish for prawns in the area known as the northern prawn fishery which extends from Cape Ford, Northern Territory, to Cape York, Queensland, as from 1 January 1977.

Applications received up to 1 December 1977 were considered and at that date, 286 had been approved. Five additional applications were subsequently approved following consideration of supporting information sought from the applicants prior to 1 December 1977 and received after that date. Following hearings before the High Court of Australia, an additional vessel was licensed to operate in the fishery in 1980.

The boatbuilding subsidy payable under the Bounty (Ships) Act 1980 is payable for the construction of boats, including prawn trawlers which comply with the minimum dimensional requirements specified under that Act. Since 1973, over 100 trawlers constructed under the scheme are known to have been used in the northern prawn fishery.

ANSWER.TO.QWN.TITLE: Use of Hobart by Japanese Fishing Vessels

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 13 October 1981 (Hansard, page 1091) Senator Townley asked me a question, without notice, in my capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry in the Senate. His question concerned access by Japanese tuna longliners to the Australian fishing zone and calls by these vessels to the port of Hobart.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Primary Industry has supplied the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

Negotiations on a new tuna longline agreement for the twelve months commencing 1 November 1981 have now been concluded. Under the new agreement, access by Japanese tuna longliners has been maintained to waters south of Tasmania, south of 40*S Latitude and east of 140*E Longtitude, except for the 12 mile excluded area. Additional area and catch restrictions to those instituted under the previous agreement have been agreed in respect to Japanese operations in particular waters between 30*S Latitude and 40*S Latitude which are of importance to Australian fishing operations. However it is not expected that there will be any significant effect on port calls at Hobart by the tuna longline vessels.

The Government is aware of the economic significance of calls by longliners to the port of Hobart and other Australian ports and this matter has been taken into account during the negotiations with the Japanese.
